PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests I present the Committee's report relating to the need for oral declarations of interests by members.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Madam Speaker, the report which I have just tabled recommends an amendment to those resolutions of the House which require the registration and declaration of members' interests. Under the standing resolutions adopted by the House on 9 October 1984 there are two distinct requirements imposed upon members. The first requirement is for members to provide written statements of interests within 28 days of making an oath or affirmation as a member and to notify any alteration of those interests within 28 days of the alteration occurring. The second requirement is for members to declare orally any relevant interest if they should participate in debate or proceedings in the House or a committee. It is this second requirement which the Committee has recommended should be deleted or, alternatively, substantially amended.

SPEECH.PARA: The requirement for oral declarations of interests is contained in resolution 4. The wording of the relevant part of the resolution is as follows:

That, notwithstanding the lodgment by a Member of a statement of the Members' registrable interests and the registrable interests of which the Member is aware (1) of the Member's spouse and (2) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Member for support, and the incorporation of that statement in a Register of Members' Interests, a Member shall declare any relevant interest-
(a) at the beginning of his or her speech if the Member should participate in debate in the House, committee of the whole House, or a committee of the House (or of the House and the Senate), and

(b) as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the House, committee of whole House, or a committee of the House (or of the House and the Senate) if the Member proposes to vote in that division . . .

The only exception provided to the requirement is that it shall not be necessary for a member to declare an interest when directing a question seeking information in accordance with standing orders 142 or 143.

The Committee received legal advice that the term `relevant interest' used in the resolution should be read as `registrable interest'. This means that, in addition to having to provide written statements of a whole range of interests covering such diverse matters as shareholdings in a company, ownership of real estate, disclosure of assets or liabilities and even being a member or patron of a local community or sporting organisation, members are required to remember to make oral declarations of those interests if they participate in debate or proceedings in the House or a committee. The effect of the requirement is that it would be necessary, for example, for a member to have to remember to declare orally the fact that he, his or her spouse or dependent child was a member or patron of a local community organisation if any matter remotely relating to the aims of that organisation were to be considered in the House or in committee. This is a quite ridiculous situation which, the Committee believes, goes way beyond what was intended by the House when the requirements were adopted.

The written statements of interests provided by members are included in a publicly available register. In addition, copies of the statements are tabled in the House. Any oral declaration is effectively a duplication of this publicly available information. Failure to make oral declarations of interests could be considered by the House to be a contempt. However, the Committee believes that there may well have been occasions both in the House or in a committee when members have unwittingly failed to make such declarations. It believes that this additional requirement is unnecessary and confusing and places a burden upon members which can be overlooked and which serves no real purpose.

The Committee recommends that the requirement for oral declarations of interests should be abolished. This could be achieved simply by deleting resolution (4) of the requirements. Alternatively, if the House is unwilling to abolish the requirement completely, the Committee recommends that resolution (4) be amended to require an oral declaration to be made only when a member, his or her spouse or dependent children hold a pecuniary interest which could conceivably bring the member into a potential conflict of interest situation in proceedings in the House or in committee. This is a matter which the Committee believes requires prompt correction. Accordingly, it requests urgent consideration of the matter by the House in the belief that any new requirement should be effective from the first sitting day in 1989.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Humphreys, for Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill's genesis is a request from the South Australian Government that the National Crime Authority Act 1984 be amended to enable the appointment of additional members to the National Crime Authority for specific investigations. The South Australian Government has indicated that such an amendment would allow the appointment of an additional member to undertake a proposed South Australian reference to the National Crime Authority in relation to allegations of criminal activity and corruption in South Australia. Further, the South Australian Government has formally agreed to fund the establishment of a National Crime Authority office in that State.

The National Crime Authority is a highly skilled body working in the most complex areas of organised crime. It is a relatively small body which has demonstrated an ability to investigate across the broad spectrum of criminal activity. The Authority was established, in part, as a viable alternative to the then growing proliferation of royal commission-type inquiries which were undertaking investigations into a variety of subjects, and in particular various aspects of organised criminal activity. The Authority's independence, coercive powers, knowledge and expertise in the fight against organised crime together with its focus on the gathering of admissible evidence make it the best alternative to deal with allegations of criminal activity and corruption of the kind being made in South Australia. The South Australian Government has already had the benefit of a report from the National Crime Authority on certain South Australian investigations during 1986 and 1987 so that the Authority has a knowledge of the South Australian criminal environment.

The Inter-Governmental Committee has considered this Bill and supports the Commonwealth introduction of this Bill. The Inter-Governmental Committee will consider approving a South Australian reference pursuant to section 14 of the National Crime Authority Act on 24 November 1988.

It is against this background that this Bill amends the National Crime Authority Act to allow the Inter-Governmental Committee, which consists of the Commonwealth Minister and a Minister from each participating State, to create additional offices of member of the National Crime Authority in relation to a specific Commonwealth or State reference. These additional offices can only be created where a reference to the Authority has been made and the Inter-Governmental Committee, having regard to that reference and any related references, thinks that the appointment of an additional member of the Authority is necessary to enable the Authority to perform its functions. For example, where the Inter-Governmental Committee concludes that a reference requires that the member undertaking it have special skills or expertise or that the Chairman's and two members' resources are fully utilised, then it can create an additional office of member to conduct that reference. These amendments will provide the Inter-Governmental Committee with the power to increase the number of members of the Authority to enable the Authority to deal with additional matters warranting referral to the Authority without impeding the Authority's current activities.

The Bill provides that the additional member will be appointed to undertake a particular reference and any related references nominated by the relevant Commonwealth or State Minister. For example, where an additional member is appointed to undertake a South Australian reference and the criminals involved in South Australia also operate or have connections in Victoria, the Victorian Minister may state that a resultant Victorian reference is related to the South Australian reference. The additional member would then undertake both the South Australian reference and the related Victorian reference.

It will be the function of the Inter-Governmental Committee to recommend unanimously a person for appointment to an additional office of member and any advice to the Governor-General with respect to the appointment is required to be consistent with the recommendation under proposed new subsection 7 (8AB).

An underlying premise of the Bill is that the facility to appoint additional members will be used for dealing with additional Commonwealth or State references and will allow the number of members of the Authority to fluctuate in response to the number, nature and status of the references made to it.

The powers and functions of the additional member are limited to the original reference or any related references. The Bill provides that an additional member ceases to hold office upon the withdrawal of the original reference in relation to that member or the completion of the original reference or any related references.
I commend the Bill to the House. Explanatory notes will be circulated.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 November, on motion by Mr Punch:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Sports Commission Bill 1988 establishes the Australian Sports Commission as a statutory corporation with responsibilities for coordinating the national sporting effort at all levels and assisting elite athletes. The establishment of the Commission will merge the functions and administrations of the Australian Institute of Sport and the current Australian Sports Commission and some functions of the Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The establishment of the Commission will remove the existing overlap in responsibilities for sport that has arisen. The Institute of Sport and the present Australian Sports Commission were set up separately to fulfil separate functions at that time. It has now been thought better to bring them together under one statutory corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will focus responsibility on the Commission for sports development at all levels. The Institute of Sport will retain an identity within the Commission, remaining responsible for the development of elite athletes and other existing programs within the current Commission, such as Aussie Sports and sports development, drugs and sports, sports talent development programs and the Australian Sports Aid Foundation, and will continue many of those programs, of course, developed under the former Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), who is in the chamber at present. I think Australian sports should congratulate him on the wonderful work he did for sport over so many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great sportsman.

—He is a great sportsman and he was a great Minister. The objects of the Commission are listed in clause 6 of the Bill and include providing leadership in sports development, encouraging participation in sport, assisting elite athletes, improving coaching standards-which is very important in Australia across the whole range of sports-fostering international sporting cooperation, and encouraging private sector funding. The latter, of course, is important as we develop our links with the private sector to encourage it to enter into many sponsorship deals for sports, not only the big name sports but other sports. Of course, that will include the Olympic Games if Australia is successful in two years' time.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the Commission are listed in clause 7. They include advising the Minister, undertaking research and development in relation to sport, including sports science and medicine, another very important area. I have some very good friends in the sports medicine area, two excellent physios whom I know well, Ross Smith and Mary Toomey in Melbourne, who are connected with the Olympic movement. Ross was one of the physios who attended the Olympic Games and Mary is connected with the ladies hockey team. Although she did not attend the Olympic Games, she has been with the team through many programs. Of course, that team was successful in winning a gold medal at the recent Seoul Olympics. The Commission manages its facilities and acts as an advisory body raising money through the Australian Sports Foundation and other bodies set up by the former Minister. It assists other bodies, including State and Territory organisations and the Australian Olympic Federation.

As the honourable member for Gilmore (Mr Sharp) said last night, to hold the Olympic Games in Melbourne would bring benefits. I support the member for Gilmore when he referred to the lack of policy by the Democrats on the Olympic Games. I suppose we should expect no more from the Democrats when they say that they will support the bid by Athens for the 1996 Olympics. That comment is easily put down by quoting remarks made on several occasions by the President of the Australian Olympic Federation, Mr Kevan Gosper, who has said on many occasions in the past couple of weeks that 1996 will be the centenary not of the Greek Games but of the Olympic Games. If Athens is unable to put together a submission that is worthy of the Olympic movement, it is most likely that the 1996 Olympics will not be held there; if it can put together a good submission, obviously its bid will be favoured. However, I think Australia has an excellent chance and will probably be favoured if Athens is unable to put together a successful bid.

The Olympic Federation of Australia recently selected Melbourne from three excellent Australian bids and I am quite sure, as Mr Gosper has said, that any of the three cities that nominated-Brisbane, Sydney and Melbourne-could have held the Olympic Games, albeit a little differently in each city, reflecting their different characters. I believe that Melbourne won the bid for a number of reasons, one being that at present already half the facilities are available and there has been a separate announcement in connection with the Victorian Football League and cricket authorities that $100m will be spent on upgrading the Melbourne Cricket Ground to make it into probably the world's finest stadium with seating for 110,000 people. That is a separate issue altogether from the Olympic Games. I believe that there will be a proposal for work additional to the $100m to be spent now if Australia is successful in Tokyo in 1990, where a decision will be made on the venue for the 1996 Olympic Games.

Under this Bill, the Australian Sports Commission will have a lot to do with the Olympic Games if the Australian bid is successful and in the time running up to that the coordination of many programs for different sportsmen will be an integral part of the Commission's work, in conjunction with Federal and State governments of the day and the city of Melbourne in order to put together a successful submission. If we are successful, there will be great benefit not only to Melbourne and the Australian sporting world but also to the Australian economy, particularly on the east coast, because I envisage a number of packages being sold. One could incorporate a week in Melbourne for the Games, a visit to Sydney for four or five days, a few days in Brisbane and then the return trip home, in all two weeks to 2 1/2 weeks. The east coast will see massive development if Australia gets the 1996 Olympic Games. Many people have forgotten that, if Melbourne wins the bid, a number of infrastructure improvements will be required not only in Melbourne but also in Sydney and Brisbane, particularly in terms of accommodation, because I suspect that many of the 300,000 or 400,000 people who are expected to come to Australia will visit those cities as they travel up and down the east coast. The injection of billions of dollars into the Australian economy right across the country will be of great benefit for many decades.

Whilst the Melbourne committee, as did the other committees, brought forward proposals with varying degrees of profitability, that is beside the point. The Melbourne committee's bid has a profitability of slightly in excess of $80m but it would not matter if it broke square or finished a fraction in the red because one would never, in effect, finish in the red as massive amounts of money would come into the economy because of the invisibles through tourism and infrastructure development, and it would go on and on for the next decade at least. It would be absolutely astronomical and would amount to billions of dollars. It is a project that Australia and all Australians will get behind because we can not only win the bid for 1996 but do a very good job for Australia and the Olympic movement.

The Bill to establish the Australian Sports Commission as a statutory corporation sets up the Commission to assist in the many sides of sporting administration today and the many fields that we have in sports science, coaching and other areas. It is a very big and growing industry. I use that word industry deliberately-sporting administration and sport in general. I am quite sure that, under certain guidance, we can quite happily abide by the rules that we have laid down and that the former Minister, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown), laid down, particularly in relation to drugs. We can have a thriving sporting industry that will not only benefit sportsmen and elite athletes but the whole of the community and the health of the community. I commend the Bill to the House and I am sure it will see a quick passage through both Houses of this Parliament.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Holding)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House to debate cognately the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 with the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988? There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating cognately two pieces of legislation-the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. The Opposition is not opposing either of these pieces of legislation, although I will have some more trenchant criticisms to make about the second Bill in a few minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill contains a number of standard amendments to the Social Security Act. We are particularly concerned about the amendment that relates to the application of an assets test to the family allowance supplement (FAS) and I shall be moving a second reading amendment to that. The Government intends to apply an income test to recipients of FAS, but we point out that income alone is not necessarily a complete test of financial need. For example, families which have substantial net assets that for various reasons they may not be able to realise at the appropriate time cannot necessarily rearrange their finances in such a way as to minimise income to qualify for the FAS. This would be particularly the case with farming families during a period of drought, of recession due to economic circumstances over which they have no control whatsoever.

The Government has argued that FAS is a supplement, not a basic income support. It has been in place for only the last eight to 10 months and is seen by the Government as one of the centrepieces of its social welfare policy. It is in that context that the Opposition parties are concerned that the compassionate elements of the Government's apparent policy are totally ignored in the application of this proposal. The measure has a sudden death effect, in that families whose assets are deemed to be worth more than $300,000 will get no FAS, regardless of the circumstances in which they are currently placed. Furthermore, there is no provision for a tapered withdrawal. Assets other than those defined as a family home will be subject to assessment. The savings from this proposal will be $41m in a full year.

The assets tests on FAS and also Austudy have caused us some difficulty because, effectively, they are two different tests. A family on a farm worth, say, $400,000 and earning little real income would not qualify for FAS for its 13-, 14-, or 15-year-old children because, as I said, the assets test cuts out at $300,000 and, therefore, they would be disqualified. However, when the same child or children turn 16 they could qualify for Austudy because the assets test would allow a discount of 50 per cent; that is, the farm asset would be deemed to be worth only $200,000, although notionally it is worth $400,000. Quite clearly, there is no consistency whatsoever in this approach and that is why we are strongly suggesting that the normal provisions should have been included in the Act by which hardship could be taken into account if families found themselves in difficulties through no fault of their own.

The Bill does not amend section 7 of the principal Act to include FAS in the list of pensions, benefits and allowances to which this financial hardship provision should apply, as it does to aged, invalids', wives', carers' and widows' pensions, supporting parents' benefits, unemployment and sickness benefits, sheltered employment and mobility allowances. In fact, it covers everything except access to FAS. This is an anomaly which we have drawn to the attention of the Government. I think we need to ask: Why is there no hardship provision? Accordingly, I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for introducing an assets test on the family allowance supplement without providing a mechanism to enable benefits to be payable to those families who may fail the test but still suffer genuine financial hardship.

The proposal we have put forward in this amendment is consistent with the coalition's policy. We are not opposed in principle to an assets test on other social security benefits. We have opposed Labor's assets test on the age pension for reasons which I enunciated in our recently released retirement incomes policy. We have said there that a modified assets test will be administered to ensure that persons in genuine need are not precluded from the age pension, and in particular we have referred to the effect of the assets test on people living on family farms which they intend passing on to their close relations who are already working on the farm and drawing their primary income from it, who are unable to sell their property due to market conditions; who remain or settle on relatively small or non-viable land holdings on which they cannot generate an income beyond the age pension income test limits; or who are unable to subdivide and sell their land due to government restrictions. We have emphasised that under those circumstances the assets test will not apply to those retirees. Therefore, one can genuinely question why it is that people under FAS are being treated differently from all other recipients of benefits. This is a matter which we once again draw to the attention of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe)
I refer also to clause 8-the secrecy provisions. At the committee stage I will be moving a substantive amendment which I understand has the support of the Government.

I move on to the second Bill, the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. As I said in my opening remarks, we are not opposing this Bill. However, we are not at all happy about the elements in the Bill relating to the income assessment of market-linked investments. It is fair to say that one of the reasons we are not opposing the Bill in its entirety is that one of the cunning acts of the Government over recent years has been to put together an omnibus Bill which contains all sorts of other things, as is the case in this Bill. It has included rent assistance, a reciprocal social security agreement with New Zealand, and amendments to the Commonwealth Employees (Rehabilitation and Compensation) Act. Since we cannot oppose those elements of the package, it makes it extremely difficult effectively to oppose the Government's proposals in relation to income assessment of market-linked securities.

However, I must emphasise that the Opposition is thoroughly disturbed and concerned about the background to this particular set of changes. It represents the seventh change to the income test in the last 5 1/2 years. It is seen by pensioners and by representative organisations across Australia as an outstanding example of how the Government has made an art form of creating concern in pensioner communities about the long term objectives of its non-policy in relation to these matters. The emphasis has been consistently on revenue protection and on increasing revenue at all costs. While we do not object to that as a principle, one has to say that it is the role of Government to sell its policy and let everybody know well in advance precisely what its objectives are and what it is trying to achieve, and in that context to be able to explain the objectives and the changes it makes.

The Minister has said on numerous occasions that he wants retirement income policy to be based on such undoubtedly pristine principles as adequacy, fairness, security and sustainability. These are his own words; his four central principles of any retirement income policy. He talks about the need for level playing fields and for a fairer system. Pensioners, especially, look at the changes which came out of the Budget proposals and ask, `What is fair about this? What is fair about establishing three sets of pensioners?'. What is fair about saying to pensioners who take market-linked securities as a means of protecting their long term asset position and creating some income as well, compared with a pensioner who is able to put his money in real estate or on the stock market independently, while they are subject to the provisions of capital gains tax, they are not subject to the same onerous provisions proposed in this amendment? One can go further and say that if pensioners are really smart they could invest their money offshore and would not be caught by any of the Government's tests or proposals. Therefore, the Minister's allegation that he wants to have a level playing field is simply nonsense when we actually see what the Government's proposals are and the direction of its policy in recent months.

The Budget, when it was announced, said that the Government's intention was to change the treatment of market-linked investments for pension income tests, that it intended to apply a formula that would take account of unrealised investment growth over the previous three years which would then be deemed income for the current year. This formula was different from that applied over the previous eight years. Since 1976 the Department of Social Security's own manual of instructions has stated:
If the investment is market-linked; i.e. the value can vary up and down, income is assessed only on maturity or where a withdrawal is made, regardless of when the investment was purchased.

I quoted that for the benefit of the House because when the debate was in full swing and shot and shell were flying backwards and forwards on this issue, the Minister said publicly that that statement was never made.

TALK.START.PARA: —When you were scare- mongering.

—He claimed that nobody had ever told pensioners who were involved in market linked securities that they were subject to those provisions. In other words, they had imagined for the last eight years that what they were doing was legally correct. The Minister was determining-incorrectly, as I pointed out-that they were acting incorrectly when in fact that was not the case. I point out once again to the Minister that it would be very useful if he got accurate advice on what are the provisions in the regulations before he goes off half-cocked about these things. The change was intended to correct the situation which, according to the Government, saw many investments, particularly property trusts, marketing products which effectively disguised the income component in capital growth. Again, according to the Government, it simply maximised leverage on the invested funds so that no income was generated, thus no dividends were available for distribution to the investor and, consequently, the income test was not activated.

SPEECH.PARA: Some pensioners were able to protect fully their capital investment and gain access to the maximum pension at the same time. We objected to these proposals principally because of their retrospective nature and the effect they would have on people who had purchased those market-linked securities over at least the last eight years. I think the record is quite clear that the Government had no choice but to back down in the face of concerted pressure from the coalition, from pensioner groups, and from the investment industry. The Minister said only a few moments ago that I was scaremongering. I obviously had good company because the Premier of Victoria was clearly doing precisely the same thing. I have not heard the Minister suggest for one moment that the same rule should apply to the Premier as obviously applies to me. He was extremely concerned about the impact on pensioners and their attitudinal position in relation to the State election. He knew it would have been to his disadvantage because of the frustration and growing concern in pensioner communities throughout Australia about their inability to plan ahead when faced by a government that constantly changes the rules of the game halfway through the match. That was the basis of our complaint. That was the basis upon which we argued the case. I am pleased to say that we were able to prove our credentials to the pensioner community on that issue.

We still have the serious anomalies which the Government has found some difficulty in facing up to. The Minister would agree that there are a number of exemptions to these proposals which are included in the Act. These will be shareholders in private companies or in shares listed on the stock exchange, or private holdings of real estate. When will the Government extend the Bill to cover all other direct investments? If it is serious about a level playing field I argue, as do pensioners, that one of the areas of major concern which the Government has completely ignored is the protection of pensioners' assets in the face of major inflationary pressures.

No doubt the Minister has seen, as I have, tables of figures which demonstrate very clearly that when we take into account the impact of the 50 per cent loss for every dollar which is obtained above the pensioner income threshold, the effect of direct income tax and inflation and the effect of the new 11 per cent denied income which will be taken into account in these new proposals, many pensioners face a loss of up to 70c in the dollar on the additional income which they can earn from various investments. Fortunately, the marketplace has adjusted to some extent and there has been a trend in recent months towards capital protected securities and, no doubt from the Government's point of view, for a number of reasons these have some real attractions.

If investments are made in such capital protected securities, the rate of return is known in advance and the pensioner knows precisely what he will get and the Government knows precisely what it should take into account; there is no room for variation. Our major concern is that by making market-linked securities less attractive, the Government has effectively required pensioners who have relatively small amounts of money-and I am told by the Department that the average amount is $18,000, so we are not talking about rich pensioners, which has been the tendency of the Minister in the past-to invest in capital stable products. If a person has $18,000 he or she is not unreasonably interested in trying to get the `biggest bang for the buck', because he or she cannot depend on the level of the pension or part pension. People want to maximise their capacity to earn money and at the same time maximise the protection of their investment and, in particular, their capital. I am afraid that in the context of the Government's proposals these two clear objectives do not appear to be adequately covered. We think it is both naive and myopic of the Government to maintain the view that the inconsistencies it is creating through the exemptions in this provision will not create the opportunity for future income test avoidance. Managed investments should not be singled out when they had very tangible benefits which require recognition and endorsement by the Parliament. Professional management and portfolio diversification are two of the most obvious benefits which can considerably reduce the overall risk of pensioners making relatively small investments and who have no other means of financial support, apart from possibly their homes on the one hand and their access to the pension on the other.

If it is the objective of the Government-and I strongly doubt that it is-to minimise access to the pension for those who have the capacity to remain independent of it, the approach the Government has taken in recent months to this whole area of pensioner investment has been thoroughly unsatisfactory. The lack of any indexation for inflation-the 11 per cent deemed rate of return-will be a major disincentive to pensioners to enter into market-linked products which have sold badly since 9 September and most funds are now being invested, as I said, in capital stable products-investments which provide a regular income and greater security and which we would support. The coalition believes that the preservation of pensioners' hard-earned capital can only be achieved by assessing the real return on an investment.

The Minister will no doubt claim that the 11 per cent figure which he has used means that if one gets investments which return say 25 per cent or so-and there have been cases of that over the last two or three years-the remainder is not taken into account and for all intents and purposes a significant degree of capital protection is provided. One of the debilitating characteristics of this proposal is that where the return is less than 11 per cent the company may apply to the Department for a variation in the requirement below that amount which at least gives some flexability in the market. I should also note that it cannot go above 11 per cent without an amendment going through the House.

In the final analysis, I simply put to the Government the proposition which I hope is being examined in the context of the work which I gather the Cass inquiry is still doing on the question of the definition of income. It is a fundamental fact that there are major variations in the definition of income under the Income Tax Assessment Act on the one hand and under the Social Security Act on the other. While I do not for a moment resile from the reality that the Government is not dealing with the same issue in all respects, nevertheless there is very real concern in the pensioner community as to why some pensioners, investing privately in real estate or in the share market, are subject to the indexation provisions of the capital gains tax which effectively protect the growth of their investment while others with a similar level of investment in market-linked securities will now be subject to this 11 per cent rule. It is these inconsistencies which cause such confusion among pensioners. Certainly, it would be to the advantage of the Government and the Parliament as a whole for these matters to be rationalised. I am therefore concerned that the Government has rushed into this matter.

The saving which the Government anticipates making is extremely small. In a full financial year it will be $4.2m. The original Budget proposals were estimated to save $18m in 1988-89. The Department got its numbers very wrong in terms of the anticipated effects. The Minister claimed that only 33,000 people would be affected. I find it very difficult to understand how he reached the figure of $18m if only 33,000 people were affected. The average investment, according to the Department, is only $18m. This merely demonstrates the fact that when the retirees responded to the proposals of the Government, the reaction made it absolutely clear that we were talking about hundreds of thousands of people who either were going to be affected or would be affected in the future, and not the 33,000 that the Government was claiming would be affected. It is because of the effect of those changes that there were such major concerns in the community. In addition, the perception of the objective of the Government-which is greater equity in the system-was not being adequately addressed.

I end my remarks on this particular aspect of the Bill by emphasising that, as far as the Opposition is concerned, the equity aspects are still not being addressed. Maybe we will wait forever for the Cass inquiry to come up with something more useful in this particular area. Quite clearly, it is the responsibility of the Government to come up with a formula which affords pensioners better protection for their assets in retirement while at the same time ensuring that they are encouraged to maximise their return, which in turn may trigger the income test where that would be applicable. There is a fundamental inconsistency in the Government's approach. On the one hand it says it would prefer fewer people to be absolutely dependent on the pension. We agree with that objective. At the same time it can be strongly argued that it has not taken the necessary action to enable and encourage people to use their money as wisely as possible and to achieve much greater independence.

The second point I want to raise relates to the question of rent assistance, which is also covered in this legislation. Rent increases facing many pensioners in fairly tight financial circumstances in our metropolitan areas, especially in Sydney and Melbourne, are well recorded. The increases in rent assistance which the Government is making are not grand in terms of their size. They are particularly slow in that they are not to be introduced this financial year. They will not come into effect until the next financial year, although that was not stated in the press release put out by the Minister. He was less than honest on that particular point.

The fundamental difficulty we are facing is not just the provision of rent assistance but the actual provision of housing. One of the great crises we are seeing in Sydney is that with the record increases in real estate values low cost rental accommodation is virtually something of the past. Many people on low incomes, whether they be pensioners or single income families of mothers with children, run the major risk of being forced out to the periphery of the community, where they have no communication and very little, if any, capacity to get employment. In other words, we are putting them into a situation of geographic isolation where the problem will be compounded, not solved.

I am surprised-in fact, I am disturbed-that the Government appears to have ignored one major possibility; that is, encouraging organisations such as the Smith Family, the Sydney City Mission, the Salvation Army, the St Vincent de Paul Society and other excellent community organisations around Australia which have over the years demonstrated a great capacity to support people in need by providing low cost accommodation. There is nothing in the Government's programs, either in this Department or in the Department of Community Services and Health, which adequately addresses this fact. It might have been much wiser to have allocated more of the hundreds of millions of dollars involved in this bandaid approach to rental increases next year to encouraging those organisations to buy old buildings, to refurbish them and to rent them out to people requiring low cost accommodation. By doing that we would at least stem the rot in terms of the fundamental diminution in the community's store of low cost accommodation. We could hold the position and then try to rebuild on it, using the private sector organisations, which are so able in this area. Instead, the Government has depended absolutely on the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. I think the record would suggest that there are weaknesses in the handling of low cost accommodation through that means. I think some basic lateral thinking is well and truly overdue.

I return to two other subjects, one being the reciprocal social security agreement with New Zealand. The Opposition welcomes that agreement. There has been major community concern for a long time about New Zealanders coming to Australia, allegedly immediately going onto unemployment benefits paid for by the Australian taxpayer. As I said, there has been great community irritation at clear evidence in some suburbs of Sydney that precisely that situation has been occurring. The Opposition welcomes the fact that the provisions have been significantly tightened up. The New Zealand Government is accepting responsibility to pay its own citizens in Australia for the first few months after they move here. The deliberate intention is to minimise the access of New Zealand citizens to Australian unemployment benefits and, hopefully, other social security benefits.

I have no comment to make about the amendments to the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. They are obviously necessary changes to legislation which went through the House some months ago. While we did not support some aspects of that legislation it is a subject of considerable importance in terms of expenditure and the need to give every encouragement to people who are forced out of the work force due to work related injuries to be rehabilitated and to re-enter the work force if that is at all possible. I conclude my observations on that point.

As I said, we will pass both Bills. We are very concerned about the Government's handling of the market linked securities issues. It is a classic example of the shambles that this Government has allowed to be created by its inability to establish in advance the clear principles against which it wants its own policies to be tested. I have quoted from Hansard the Minister's own words as to what he claims are the objectives of Government policy. The record will show that his objectives have not been achieved in a sensible and coherent way, above all in a way which gives equity-the very word which he gives much weight. Above all, he has not required or established a level playing field-again a concept which was very dear to the Minister's heart. There is every reason for the pensioners of Australia being thoroughly dissatisfied with the way in which this Government has handled these affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 before the House this morning are a continuation of the major review that this Government has made in the area of social security legislation. It should be remembered that the Social Security Review, which was established in 1985, is the first major comprehensive review of Australia's social security system since it started over 40 years ago. It was a system that governments of the complexion of those who sit opposite had allowed to grow like Topsy. It seems a little strange that the shadow Minister for social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), talked about elements of confusion about the direction of this Government in the area of social security. It should be acknowledged that, through the Social Security Review, this Government has commenced a very steady and logical review of a number of the areas in this portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill does a number of things in the area of payments for children and sole parents. It also includes programs for the long term unemployed. I will speak about some of those matters, but I want to address my remarks mainly to the Social Security and Veterans Affairs' Legislation Amendment Bill. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill implements the first step in achieving an integrated child payment system, which is important. Whilst everybody acknowledges that a wide range of good things have been done in this area, there has been some inability to put all the pieces into place and to understand how they associate with each other. This Bill goes some way towards ensuring that the things that are being done will be more understandable.

The Bill also puts into place the social security elements of the two schemes that were announced in the Budget, the jobs education and training scheme for sole parents and the new start scheme for the long term unemployed. These schemes are quite exciting because they target people who are in need of special assistance but who, for some reason or another, have been prejudiced by other programs. The Government has tackled many of these problems in a targeted fashion. It has tried to put in place programs and schemes which will benefit those most in need. One of the elements of the new start program is the allowance that will be payable to people recommencing work. The employment entry payment of $100 will go towards the short term costs of going back into the work force. This provision arose out of the social security review and will be of great assistance to people re-entering the work force.

As I have said, I want to address my remarks mainly to the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and in particular the rent assistance provisions. Before doing so, however, I do not think I can leave uncommented upon the remarks of the honourable member for Bradfield and his second reading amendment. In addressing the Bill, he continued to engender unnecessary concern in the community. Most people who consider the income and assets provisions of the legislation will realise that the Government has attempted to be as fair and equitable as possible in its implementation of the various schemes. That is perhaps what we need to consider. Market-linked growth investment packages and other such packages have been pushed upon pensioners to allow them to get around the present provisions. It does not seem fair that those who have the opportunity to go into such schemes should be treated differently from those who do not. The honourable member for Bradfield talked about the Government's failure to create a level playing field, but he has to realise the honest attempts in this legislation to do that and to treat these investment packages fairly and equitably in regard to social security benefits.

The rent assistance provisions in the legislation were announced in the Budget. Housing-related poverty and inadequate housing are problems not only in Australia but internationally. It is estimated that 100 million of the world's population have no housing at all. The General-Secretary of the United Nations, Perez de Cuellar, marked the inauguration of the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless by reminding us that the problem of shelter posed an immediate and long term threat to the welfare and development of the international community. He went on to say:

Let us bear in mind that a society is judged not so much by the standards attained by its most affluent and privileged members as by the quality of life which it is able to assure for its weakest citizens.

By international standards, Australia can be regarded as a well-off, well-housed nation; but it may surprise many to learn the extent of the housing problem in Australia. A study by the Department of Housing and Construction into homelessness and inadequate housing which was released in 1985 indicated that an estimated 40,000 people slept out of doors or in refuges and an additional 60,000 were on the verge of homelessness. A further 100,000 lived permanently in caravan parks. At the same time, over 700,000 households were estimated to be living in poverty.

Housing costs, particularly for people in the private rental market, have long been recognised as a major cause of poverty. Extensive research has shown that the level of poverty, after taking into account housing costs, has increased since the early 1970s. In 1972-73, the first main report of the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty found that the number of people living in poverty after housing costs were taken into account was 6.7 per cent. In 1981-82 it was 10.7 per cent. The 1970s saw an increase in housing-related poverty of about 60 per cent.

Research has given every indication that this alarming trend has continued during the 1980s. In an article in the National Economic Review last year, King estimated that by 1985-86 the number of people living in poverty, after taking into account housing costs, had increased by a further 10 per cent. The burden of housing costs falls heaviest on single parents and, in particular, on those single parents in the private rental market. In 1981-82, 40.8 per cent of all single parents were living in poverty after taking into account housing costs. Of single parents in the private rental market, 61 per cent were found to be in poverty after taking into account housing costs. At the same time, 20.6 per cent of young single people aged 15 to 24 years were found to be living in poverty after taking into account housing costs.

This Government has taken several major steps, as an integral part of an attack on poverty, to provide assistance to low income families renting privately. In its historic family package, the Government increased the rate of non-taxable rent assistance to unemployment beneficiaries with families from $10 to $15 a week and extended eligibility for rent assistance to low income working families. From June 1989, maximum rent assistance to pensioner, beneficiary and low income working families with one or more children will be increased by 33 per cent, or $5 a week. From December 1989, the maximum rate of rent assistance available to beneficiaries without children will be increased from $10 to $15 a week. In June 1990, a further $5 a week increase will be paid to all recipients, with an additional $5 for those with three or more children.

The honourable member for Bradfield described these proposals as not grand and their implementation as being slow. It is always interesting to ponder, when those in charge of the Opposition's economic policy talk about the need further to reduce government outlays, in what areas the Opposition would cut back. In what areas would the Opposition not provide increases? Perhaps the increases implemented in this legislation are the sorts of increases that would not get through the rigorous test of the economic leaders of the Opposition.

I suppose that there is some hope. At least the honourable member for Bradfield recognised that rent assistance alone was not going to cure the problem of housing-related poverty. But he was not gracious enough to concede that the Government is attempting to tackle this problem with a multi-disciplinary approach. It is not, as he said, just a matter of being able to ensure, by increasing the amount of income payments, that we cure this. Of course it is by the provision of adequate housing, and the Government has in place a review, under the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), which will be looking at these matters.

The honourable member talked about other programs using non-government organisations. If I am correct, the Opposition went into the last election with a policy of washing its hands of public housing; that it would allow public housing to go back into the administration of the States. One has to wonder what its real concern is and whether it wants to put into place a national program to really address these problems.

Through all the measures since the election of the Labor Government in 1983, there has been an increase of 150 per cent to 200 per cent in rent assistance for low income and pensioner beneficiary families. This Government has a landmark commitment to social justice. The Government has recognised that access to adequate and affordable housing for all is a fundamental element of social justice. The measures in the legislation which increase rent assistance to low income families are part, and, as I said, only part, of the strategy aimed at achieving these social justice objectives.

I think that the New Zealand reciprocal agreement provisions of the Bill are welcomed by all members of the House. I congratulate the Minister and the Government on the progress that is being made with a reciprocal agreement with Malta. This is very significant for a number of people living in my electorate, and I think they are pleased that there has been at least some movement on this particular agreement. The provisions of the Italian reciprocal agreement, which are being put in place in practical terms, are another part of our measures that have been well received in the electorate.

This Government, through the Cass Social Security Review, has embarked upon a wide-ranging review of social security legislation. But it does not just finish at the level of having some body of government review policy; it also allows for consultation. That is very important. The paper on retirement incomes has been well received, but it is very much a paper that is put forward to the community for discussion. It is to be hoped that that opportunity is not ignored and is taken into account. It is unfortunate that, throughout the whole process of the social security review, the Opposition has done little to participate and has not taken the opportunity that has been offered.

The other matter I mention by way of talking of consultation is the Prime Minister's task force. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, are a member of that task force in your capacity as the honourable member for Moore. The honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay), who was previously in the chair, is involved. I see in the chamber the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey), who is also on the task force. This is again a bridge, another opportunity to bring the actions of this Government to the community and provide consultation and participation in decision-making, which is also a very important aspect of social justice-being able to involve those who are subject to requirements of government policy in a say in the formulation of that policy. Sometimes, at this place, because of the remoteness of the national Parliament, that is overlooked. That is not so in the area of the range of social security measures and in veterans' affairs, where the Government has gone out of its way to ensure that the opportunity is given for participation. I therefore have great pleasure in supporting these two Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend the few minutes that are available to me in focusing attention on two aspects of the legislation before this House, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and cognate Bill. However, before doing so, I want to read the amendment to the motion for the second reading which my colleague the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) proposes to move in respect of the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. That Bill is being debated cognately, so, of course, the honourable member is unable to move the amendment until we later come to deal with that Bill specifically. Due to the limits on time that will arise on that occasion, I have indicated to him that I will read the amendment to which he briefly referred. His amendment is:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for the confusion it has caused to pensioners and those planning their retirement incomes by its many changes to the income test during its period in office and for its failure to create a level playing field for pensioners in respect of their investments'.

The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) said that the previous Government allowed social security, in particular the arrangements for the age pension, to grow like Topsy. I do not believe that that was the case; but even if it was, the present Government has committed an offence far worse in terms of the confusion that is now arising in the area of the administration of the age pension. This Parliament has seen the development of our retirement incomes policy over a long period. The age pension has been in place for many years. It used to be a combined assets/incomes test. Then there was a period when that combined test was separated so that there was an assets test and an income test. At that time the penalty for having assets or income beyond a particular threshold was 100c in the dollar. In other words, if one exceeded the income threshold by $1 per week, one lost pension at the rate of $1 per week. Similarly, if one had assets beyond the assets test threshold and a 10 per cent earnings rate was assumed, one lost pension at the rate of $1 for every $10 of capital that one had. So one had to be investing one's funds at better than 10 per cent in order to be better off.

Then it was recognised that that type of testing was punitive and it discouraged people from saving because there was no reward for effort, no benefit from getting beyond the threshold. So a major reform was introduced-the tapered means test. The purpose of that reform was to give reward for effort, reward for saving, reward for postponing current expenditure to one's retirement years. So if one did have a nest egg of investments, of income earning resources, one would at least benefit by 50c in the dollar in respect of one's savings as compared to the person who had made no savings and no postponement of earlier expenditure.

This Labor Government is going back to the punitive 100c in the dollar days. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) looks and queries. I draw to his attention two things. First, when the tapered means test was introduced there was a substantial area of clear water between the tax threshold and the income test threshold. Now that is not the case. There is very little clear water between the tax threshold and the level of income at which the pension is received. The clear water was previously created by virtue of the fact that the pension was tax free. Pensions were, sensibly, made part of taxable income, because they are people's income; but that was done against a policy background of the Minister's predecessors in the Whitlam Government of planning to abolish the asset and income test. Therefore, it seemed sensible to take the logical step of treating pensions as part of people's normal income that should be subject to tax.

However, by virtue of the reimposition of the assets test, the tightening of thresholds in terms of the incomes test and the lowering of the tax threshold in real terms, pensioners are now being faced with an effective marginal tax rate not of 50c in the dollar-the withdrawal rate of the pension-but of 62.5c in the dollar, which is the combined effect of the income test and the income tax test. But worse still, this Government has reintroduced an assets test. In doing so, it has set moderate thresholds, but it is now doing a number of things; first, to convert what in the past have been counted as assets into income. Why? It is because the income test threshold is lower than the assets test threshold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Market-linked investments have been income tested since 1980.

—I am not disputing that; of course they have. But the income, not the capital growth, has been tested. Under the legislation that the Minister is introducing, albeit without a retrospective effect, he is deeming the capital gain within the market-linked investment as income. The Government deems it to be income without any benefit of indexation which it provides to taxpayers and to its wealthy friends, who get the benefit of a capital gains tax that is inflation proofed. The Government is imposing on poor pensioners who achieve some savings and seek to maintain the real level of their income by going into market-linked investments a test on the nominal gain that is achieved by those market-linked funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Worse still, if a small investor feels that he or she does not have the know-how to go into the market and buy a portfolio of shares but goes through a managed fund, the Government requires that that person be assessed not only on the income received by the fund but also on the capital gain received by the fund. I would not mind if the Minister said, `Those funds can't get the benefit of negative gearing, because that is a distortion designed to postpone not only the realisation of the capital but also the realisation and receipt of the income'. If the Government treated the real income of those funds as though it were the income of the pensioner, I would not object. The private investor can go to a portfolio, publicly listed investment company, invest direct and be subjected only to the income test. That is totally unfair as between various groups of pensioners. I suspect that, in order to catch a larger number of small investors, the Government will bring in an assets test by deeming the capital gain within a portfolio investing public company to be income, and another large group of pensioners who postpone expenditure in their working lives until their retirement will be penalised and punished as a consequence of their prudence and desire to maintain their real standards of living in retirement.

I refer now to the second point, the way in which the Government is returning to the old, vicious 100c in the dollar assets and income test. With the assets test, we bring into account assets as though there is an assumed yield of 10 per cent; thus there is 100c in the dollar withdrawal of the pension for someone who has assets yielding 10 per cent. It is necessary for those retirees to obtain a substantially higher yield than that. On average, the yield of small investors about whom I am concerned would not average much more than 10 per cent, even in these days of high interest rates. We find that this legislation introduces a whole lot of artificial definitions. I have said before and I will say again that for income test purposes the same definition of `income' should be used as is used for income tax purposes. If it is good enough to use one definition of income for tax purposes, it is good enough to use it for income test purposes. It might well be said that the reverse is true, but the aged, the retirees who need permanent, long term income support, require some degree of certainty. They must put in tax returns and they must put in returns to the Minister's Department for their social security entitlement. They should be able to put in the same return and be assessed for income tax liability and income test pension reduction.

If there are to be exceptions, it would be fairer to make those exceptions specific; they should be made clear and there should be some justification of why cases are to be separate and distinct. I have given an illustration, that is in the use of negative gearing, where there would be justification to postpone not only the capital gain but also the income receipt. While the Government is allowing other pensioners to benefit from capital gain by not realising their assets, it should allow those who invest in market-linked securities to do the same thing. The honourable member for Scullin referred to the topsy way in which, under previous governments, social security policy arose. There is utter and complete confusion amongst the pensioner community about the definition of income and assets for pension purposes. There is confusion in the legislation on a number of other factors as well. It is interesting to look at the manuals that the Department puts out. In relation to beneficiaries the manual states:

In contrast to the situation applying to bank accounts, bonds et cetera where interest accrues over a period of time, the dividend on a share is determined and declared at a point in time. Only those persons who are registered as shareholders on the day the relevant share register is closed for dividend purposes have an entitlement to the dividend. Accordingly, share dividends should be treated as income only in the fortnight of receipt.

That is all right for a beneficiary and it is some explanation. However, we find that under chapter 5 of the directions given to social security offices in relation to pensions, the instruction is as follows:

In contrast to the situation applying to bank accounts, bonds etc., where interest accrues over a period of time, the dividend on a share is determined and declared at a point in time. Only those persons who are registered as shareholders on the day the relevant share register is closed for dividend purposes have an entitlement to the dividend. Share dividends that have been paid are taken into account in calculating the amount to be maintained on an annual basis.

Why? What is the legal justification for counting a dividend on an annual basis for a pensioner but on a fortnightly basis for a beneficiary? The system is crazy and it is time these anomalies were closely examined to achieve some coherence. Then we find-and this is something that the Minister may take up, because it would probably save him revenue if he were to pursue it-that there is a lack of logic in the topsy way in which the definition of income has arisen and interest received by a pensioner is brought into account before tax. No allowance is made for the tax that a pensioner pays on interest. We find that the Department has given careful, coherent and logical thought to dividends. It states:

Dividends are accompanied by a `Shareholder Dividend Statement' which may also include a figure under the heading `Imputed Credit'. This figure should be ignored and regard had only to the cash dividend.

In fact, those pensioners who invest in interest income find that the income is brought into account at a pre-tax value, and those who bring their dividends into account find that that occurs at a post-tax value. I ask what is the logic of that. I am not suggesting which way we should go but it is yet another illustration of the many confusions that exist in the definitions now being used because the Department has constructed a whole range of artificial definitions. It would argue that it is doing so on the basis of some legislative authority because, under the Act now, income in relation to a person means personal earnings, moneys, valuable consideration or profits, whether of a capital nature or not. So every profit of a capital nature is brought into account in determining a person's pension entitlement if he realises-that is the result of the High Court decision-the asset.

The exception is in relation to managed funds. There, legislatively, we are about to say that unrealised gains are to be calculated. We make this special exception for those who happen to choose that form of investment. There is a series of exceptions that relate to a capital gain, including the exception of a domestic asset and I raise, and I have raised before, some concerns about that. Interestingly enough, the Department administratively-it may be based on some legal ground and I cannot see the authority for it-argues that a house is a domestic asset. I would have thought that a domestic asset was more of the nature of furniture, garden tools and crockery in the house. But a house is being regarded as a domestic asset, and if it has been lived in as the domestic asset of the family for a period of up to 12 months it is not brought into account if it is disposed of. But if the poor pensioner goes into a nursing home and uses the entitlement of not selling his or her house for 12 months because it is then still being counted as the home, when that house is sold, and if it is sold for a capital gain, under this interpretation that pensioner could be denied the pension for upwards of 12 months, I presume, because I cannot find in the manual whether that gain is to be attributed to a fortnight as it is with the beneficiary or is to be spread over 26 fortnight periods, a 12-month period. There is the anomaly.

It is clear that, if a pensioner has a beach house and reaches the age when he can no longer take advantage of it and decides to sell it, and if that beach house is sold for more than its purchase price, the capital gain is brought into account as a profit under that definition and it is not clear whether it is to be fortnightly or spread over a 12-month period. There is a significant number of pensioners who could be rearranging their affairs because of their personal needs and who, in the rearrangement of those affairs, could be totally denied a pension for 12 months; and there is another anomaly which needs urgent clarification.

Although one can see perhaps the reasons why the Minister has introduced this proposed legislation about market-linked securities, it has been done in a patchwork, bandaid way and there is an urgent need for a major review of how income should be defined for pension purposes. Income should not be redefined to achieve a de facto lowering of the threshold applicable to the assets test. I believe that every person aged 65 and over should be entitled to a pension except to the extent that he has benefited from a tax concession through superannuation schemes. People should be entitled to one thing or the other, the tax concession or the pension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harvey Mrs E.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure for me today to be able to speak for the Government on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. As the member of parliament who has the oldest electorate in the country, that is, the electorate with the highest number of retirees and the highest mean age of any electorate, questions of social security and veterans' affairs, particularly the area dealing with age pensions, are of great interest to me and, naturally, of great interest to my constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole question of pensions and retirement income and the way in which this Government is treating retired people has been very much in the media lately-with good reason, of course-but there has been a lot of misinformation and a lot of rumour that has not been answered and a lot of untruths that have not been answered. Some of these are due simply to ignorance but a lot are due to deliberate campaigns of misinformation which are spread in some cases by our political opponents and in other cases by other politically motivated groups in the community. As a result of this I have been speaking to a lot of pensioner and senior citizens groups in my electorate as well as to individuals, finding out what they think of the whole thing, also allaying some of their fears, and correcting some of the misinformation and wrong ideas prevalent in that group.

One thing I have discovered in the last few weeks by going around and talking to pensioners is that on the whole they are a very reasonable group of people. They understand that our population is ageing. They understand that, as a result of that our age pension bill will of necessity increase to a large extent in the next few years and they understand that, as a result of the population ageing, the number of people in the work force and the number of people paying tax to support that bill is not growing at the same rate. They understand, therefore, that a certain degree of income and assets testing is necessary. There are, of course, many unreasonable people who think that, irrespective of what their assets and income are, they are entitled to a full pension. Their usual argument is, `I paid tax all my life and therefore I deserve a pension'. I usually say to them, `Didn't you get anything else for your taxes during your life? Didn't your children go to school? Didn't you get health care? Didn't you get hospital care? Didn't you get roads and didn't you get the myriad of other community services that come directly from the Federal Government or through the State or local government? Is that all you expect your taxes to go towards: a pension when you retire, irrespective of your other assets and income?' Some are quite irrational and unreasonable and stick to that view but the vast majority of people realise that the amount of money available for pensions is not unlimited and there must be a certain degree of income and asset testing and targeting.

The Cass Social Security Review, which was recently released, identified particular groups of pensioners and retirees who need special attention and have special needs. One of these was a single pensioner, a person in receipt of a single rate of pension, whether that person has never married or is widowed. Professor Cass acknowledged that people in this group in particular had difficulties because they cannot benefit from the economy of scale as a married couple can. This is one of the things and one of the complaints that I come across as I go around to pensioner groups. Even though one person does not eat as much as two people, that does not mean to say that the electricity bill is less or that the other overheads are any less than they would be for two people. This is a reasonable grievance and it was addressed and recognised by Professor Cass in her report.

The other group identified as being in need was people who do not own their own homes and who are paying rent, particularly people paying rent on the commercial market who are renting privately. I am pleased to say that in South Australia there are not a lot of people in this group. The South Australian Housing Trust, our local public housing authority, manages, to its credit, to look after the vast majority of pensioners who do not own their own homes and they, therefore, are paying a very moderate rent. I understand that in other States a greater proportion of pensioners are paying rent at commercial rates, and they are in great difficulty. So the question of rent allowance and rent assistance and a possible increase in that area is something that should be very much to the fore in the minds of Government members.

When I go round to pensioner groups and say that those people who are paying rent are in need, all the home owners jump up and say, `Even though we are not paying rent we, too, have considerable expenses in maintaining our home. We may not have this regular payment going out once a week or once a fortnight, but we have big lump sum payments when the hot water system breaks down, when the gutters need replacing or when we need to do some painting or some major repairs'. Perhaps we should be looking at this, not necessarily with any sort of house maintenance payment in mind but with a view to providing further assistance through local government authorities to provide these handyman services.

As far as pensioners are concerned, we recognise that they have needs and there are things to be done-in particular the rate of the pension could be increased; Professor Cass has suggested that over the next few years it could go up to 30 per cent of average weekly earnings-and we have done important things for pensioners. One for which I still do not think we get enough credit is the effective raising of the tax threshold for 1988-89 and onwards. That has now been increased to about $6,800 before a pensioner has to pay any tax. I think it is worth pointing out to pensioners that they are favoured in this respect. Low income workers, or any workers for that matter, have a tax threshold of $5,100, so pensioners are actually advantaged in this respect.

The other group which I am particularly concerned about is people who are on a modest superannuation payment and a part pension. These people often find that, when all is said and done, they have very little more net disposable income than people on a full pension, even though they have been paying into a superannuation fund all or part of their working lives. While their gross income may be considerably higher, by the time they are taxed, and when we take into account that they do not get fringe benefits or any sort of concession, in the end, effectively, they are not that much better off. The problem here is partly the criterion under which we award fringe benefits. We award them on other income-that is, income other than the pension-rather than total income. Usually only one partner who is in receipt of a superannuation income pays the full tax on that income, but that superannuation income cannot be split between partners for taxation purposes.

This Bill deals with the new provision to assess for social security purposes income from market-linked investments. When this was first mooted by the Government in the last Budget there was a huge outcry by the Opposition and by groups in the community. There were sensational headlines in the newspapers to the effect that once again the Government was hitting the poor old pensioners. As I have said before, the fact is that only 2 per cent of pensioners have been affected by this. Many of the other 98 per cent have other kinds of investment which are assessed--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not worried about the 2 per cent?

—I did not say that that 2 per cent does not matter; all I am saying is that only 2 per cent of people were benefiting from this provision; the other 98 per cent who had other kinds of investment income which was assessed were not affected by it. I think adding this provision for assessing income from market-linked investments makes the whole assessment system much fairer and much more equitable now that all investments will be treated in the same way.
