SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) mentioned, as a result of the Cass report and as a result of consternation in the community, the Government has established a retirement incomes task force which consists of 11 backbenchers from different States who will be going around the country talking to pensioner groups and individuals about their concerns. I said `talking', but actually its main role will be to listen to people's reactions to the Cass report, take them into account, and come up with some sort of report early next year on which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) will report. I am very pleased to be a member of this task force. I look forward to joining with my colleagues in talking to groups around the country over the next few months.

The last thing I would like to refer to is the question of grey power, as it is called. As I have said, there is reasonable consternation in the community about the whole area of treatment of retired people and the elderly, but there is also a huge degree of hysteria and irrationalism in this area. Certainly there is a great degree of inconsistency. For example, at the last Federal election, one of my opponents was a Joh Nationals candidate who was standing on a platform of a better deal for pensioners, at exactly the same time as one of his Party's candidates for the Senate-now Senator John Stone-was going around the country advocating about $11 billion in spending cuts. At the time Senator Stone was actually aspiring to be the Minister for Finance. So we had the National Party candidate for Hawker standing on a platform of a better deal for pensioners while his Party's aspiring Finance Minister was talking about $11 billion in spending cuts. Where that $11 billion worth of spending cuts was supposed to come from without touching the major areas of expenditure such as pensions, I do not know. These totally irrational and inconsistent aspects of the grey power campaign have to be exposed and dealt with by this Government, and that is certainly one of the things that our retirement incomes task force will be doing.
I commend the legislation to the House. I trust that over the next few months the task force will address many of the concerns of elderly people in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Due to the tight timetable relating to legislation and the fact that I have to carry the responsibility for the defence service home loans legislation-a very important piece of legislation which is now scheduled for midnight tomorrow-I will not detain the House greatly in the hope that that legislation will come on slightly before midnight tomorrow. It is vital to the whole equation relating to veterans and elderly citizens, as is the legislation before the House at the moment, which contains Budget related measures flowing from the previous Federal Budget, with particular reference to means testing. It is that aspect which I wish to focus on in the course of my comments.

SPEECH.PARA: Before so doing, I just mention to the honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Harvey) that we have followed with interest her comments on veterans and elderly citizens and we listened with particular interest to the reference to the 2 per cent cut back on Defence Force retirement benefits imposed by this Government in 1986 and yet to be rectified. It is an acid test of the Government's credibility whether it will rectify that matter. Our commitments and our expenditure priorities are far more learned than anything offered by this Government. For example, we would not be about spending $100m on additional aid to black African states in a continent with no direct reference-although there is certainly an indirect reference-or linkage to Australia. If one wants to look for $100m to fortify assistance to veterans and elderly citizens and protect their situation, one could start with the $100m of aid that the Government has provided in the last 18 months in a boosted package to the black African states. What sort of a priority is that in terms of our true national interest? I add in passing that the recent referendums cost $41m, as the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has pointed out. That resulted in four massive No votes to protect our Constitution. Honourable members will not see the next coalition government embarking on courses of action which are so arrogant and so out of touch as has been the Federal Labor Government throughout much of this bicentennial year.

I could list other matters but will not, because I want to focus in particular on the income assessment arrangements embraced by this legislation. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) told the House in introducing the legislation:

Growth on market-linked investments, which is currently assessed on realisation or maturity, will now be assessed on an ongoing basis. From 1 December 1988, pensioners and beneficiaries who, on or after 9 September 1988, invested or invest in institutionally managed market-linked investments which yield capital growth will have a rate of return calculated on their investments and counted as ongoing yearly income. There will be a statutory rate of return on all market-linked investments of 11 per cent or such other lower rate not below zero per cent as is specified by the Minister from time to time.

That is an extraordinary statement, because what happened-and it is very important to recount this-is that the Budget in effect provided a retrospective attack on elderly citizens and on our veterans who served in World War II, Korea, Malaya, and Vietnam and in other conflicts. It was a retrospective attack on the precious arrangements which they had made to protect their retirement income circumstance. This Government came forth with yet another Budget proposal, which followed a litany of Budget proposals in recent years which have cut back many of those programs. On this occasion there was a massive grassroots reaction right across Australia-even in Western Australia. Indeed, the shadow Minister for Social Security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), helped in leading that campaign. He attended meetings in Albury in my electorate, and I attended meetings in Sydney and elsewhere, to focus concern over this despicable retrospective attack on so many people associated with grey power.

It is educational for the Government to realise that is what it was taking on in terms of its Budget announcement. What happened? There was another meeting of Cabinet. It was held during a non-sitting week, as I recall, and Ministers had to flock back from all over Australia, as they were going about their portfolio duties. I acknowledge that the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), who is at the table, travels a great deal in non-sitting weeks to cover those important portfolio responsibilities. They all had to come back to Canberra for an unscheduled Cabinet meeting. It was one Cabinet meeting in which they actually had some business to discuss. We are learning of late that they are running out of things to place on the agenda as the Government runs into that tired, decaying mould that it seems to be approaching at this time.

There was a special Cabinet meeting to alter this Budget decision, to remove the retrospective elements embraced by the original announcement associated with this legislation. We in the coalition had a great win in the interests of focusing grassroots reaction to this attack by the Government. We have that confirmed by this legislation before the House, as the worst of those retrospective elements have been eliminated from the package. I will give credit where credit is due, because I know that the Minister at the table was probably batting in the fight for the removal of this retrospectivity. He would have recognised the damage that the original Budget decision did for so many in this portfolio. Certainly, we in the coalition proudly claim victory on this occasion, as the Government has wound back its Budget decision by altering the policy with regard to income assessment and, by so doing, very much improving the nature and impact of that proposal.

I highlight that aspect in particular to the House. There is in this country a live and viable democratic process. Even when governments have majorities in the lower House, as inevitably they do, and believe that they can force through proposals against the will of the people, they can come unstuck when they tread beyond a certain line. In this case the Government was caught redhanded. The Opposition went in to bat, and batted strongly. The Returned Services League of Australia, many veterans' associations and many organisations associated with grey power also went in to bat strongly. The outcome is that we have much better legislation before this Parliament as a consequence.

I support the amendments which are to be proposed by my colleague the shadow Minister for Social Security and I reflect his concern in respect of certain other parts of the legislation, particularly the impact of rent assistance arrangements on so many of the elderly.

I conclude by saying that it is essential that governments become conscious of the massive concern they create for many elderly people with changes that are proposed from time to time and the complexity of those changes in relation to taxation, veterans' affairs arrangements, social security arrangements and income assessment. The cry I hear time and again as I move around my electorate of Farrer, as I move around my portfolio constituency, is that people can no longer understand what is going on, except that it always seems to involve another attack on their net position and the assistance package by the government of the day, the Federal Labor Government.

I appeal to governments at all levels to be very conscious of the need to inject simplicity into the complex arrangements that they devise, particularly with regard to the various application forms, brochures and informational documentation prepared by governments and departments. For example, documentation on this income assessment should be written in such a way that the public can understand it and it is not frightening to them. I ask the Government to take this matter into account in the further consideration of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments contained in this legislation are important components of the Government's reforms in the area of social security and they aim at producing a system which is easier to administer and clearly targets those most in need. The first important set of amendments contained in the legislation is in the area of family assistance. Increases in the level of benefits, changes in the administration of the incomes test, the introduction of an assets test as well as other assorted amendments in this area are contained in this legislation, with the aim of targeting improved benefits to those most in need. I will return to these changes in a moment.

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage it might be appropriate to make a couple of observations about the way the debate has gone so far. Some Opposition speakers have talked about the problem of very high effective marginal tax rates that confront certain categories of pensioners and beneficiaries as they start to acquire private income. That is a very major problem, and dealing with that is something that really needs to be a significant government priority. However, it is important to recognise that there are significant dilemmas. To the extent that one tries to alleviate the position of pensioners and beneficiaries by easing the action of income tests, obviously there is a substantial revenue cost. To the extent that one does that, one limits the capacity to improve the basic adequacy of pensions, benefits and associated payments to those most in need. There is a genuine policy dilemma, and it is not an easy one to resolve. It is discussed in the Social Security Review paper on retirement incomes. There is no easy solution to it. The Social Security Review paper favoured utlimately going down the path of some kind of integration of the tax and social security incomes tests. Various proposals have been put forward to do that, the first being the guaranteed minimum income scheme arising from the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty. A more recent proposal is that of Dixon and Foster. These are discussed in the Social Security Review paper. It is impossible to pretend that it is a simple matter that admits of an easy resolution. Whatever is done in the area of income testing or in easing the income tax system on pensioners involves enormous revenue implications and a number of very difficult choices have to be made.

For the Opposition to pretend or imply that there is a simple solution is quite wrong and inappropriate. It typifies its approach to this type of debate. It is not interested in doing things which ensure the basic integrity of the income test. The recent kerfuffle about market-linked investments is an example of that. Obviously, just how tough the income test is to be is a policy decision the Government has to make. Whatever level of application it decides that the income test should have, whatever rate of withdrawal and whatever cut-off points are considered to be appropriate, the one thing that ought not to be a topic of serious policy arguments is the integrity of those tests. It must be guaranteed. When these matters come up, the Opposition automatically goes for the easy political point scoring exercise. In that sense it fails to make a helpful or significant contribution to policy debate in this area.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill contain changes in relation to the administration of unemployment benefits for the long term unemployed. Some aspects of the work test will be waived for unemployment beneficiaries in order to allow these people to undertake approved full time training courses for a maximum duration of up to eight weeks in any one year. This is consistent with the Government's policy of creating more training opportunities in order to encourage people back into the work force. Also contained in this Bill is the introduction of a payment of $100 to any person who returns to the work force after a period of unemployment of 12 months or more. This is designed to cover the many assorted costs of returning to the work force. These changes, along with the others contained in this Bill in regard to the treatment of unemployment beneficiaries, reflect this Government's commitment to dealing with the specific problems created by long term unemployment. The Bill also introduces a number of changes in the treatment of the widow's pension, as well as other amendments too numerous to elaborate on in one speech. Instead I will pay specific attention today to the package of changes in relation to the family allowance supplement (FAS).

With effect from 29 December 1988 family allowance multiple birth payment, double orphans' pension and child disability allowance will be integrated into the family allowance supplement pay day cycle. This will greatly simplify the current system, creating the one payment which will be of assistance to an estimated 80 per cent of Australian children. This Bill also raises the rate of payment of FAS. From December this year the amount of FAS payable for children under the age of 13 will rise by $2 a week and for children between the ages of 13 and 16 the payment will rise by $3 a week. The estimated cost of this measure in the remainder of the 1988-89 financial year is $71.4m, and in the full 1989-90 financial year will be $132.9m.

The Government has a longer term commitment to adequate child support payments. We have set the benchmarks at 15 per cent and 20 per cent of the combined married rate of pension. That is the target the Government has set itself. The achievement of that target obviously will involve very substantial revenue implications. When the wage tax trade-off is being considered next year it is important that proper attention be given to the need to build further on what the Government has already done to alleviate child poverty and to ensure that we have a package which consists of not only tax cuts but also significant improvements in the social wage provision. Child support payments are obviously a key part of that. These measures are part of this Government's often stated commitment to the elimination of child poverty by the year 1990.

The simple but shameful fact is that in a survey of eight major Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries conducted in the early 1980s, Australia had the second highest rate of children living in poverty-16.9 per cent of our children were living in poverty, second only to the United States, which had a rate of 17.1 per cent. Those figures go back to 1980, 1981 and 1982. Since then the Government has implemented a range of measures that have sought to redress that situation, particularly the family assistance package.

As a vital part of our commitment to the concept of social justice, this Government has set about redressing that situation. However, the scale of the task before us is enormous. In May this year the Australian Social Welfare Impact journal quoted results from two major studies in the area of child poverty and the estimated impact that the package of changes announced by the Government in 1987 would have on the situation. One study was conducted by Peter Saunders and Peter Whiteford from the Social Welfare Research Centre in New South Wales, and the second was a paper delivered by Helen Brownlee and Anthony King at a child poverty conference. Though the studies varied in their methodology they came to remarkably similar conclusions with regard to measurement of the poverty gap. The poverty gap is measured as the total amount by which the income of families with children falls short of the poverty line. These studies estimated that gap to be between $348m and $380m before the changes were announced in 1987. Both studies estimated that the Government's package of assistance to families would reduce that gap by just over 40 per cent. That must be considered a significant achievement.

What must also be recognised is the continuing magnitude of the task which we face in meeting our pledge to eliminate child poverty by 1990. It is a challenge we need to meet with firm polticial will. The success of FAS in alleviating child poverty is, I believe, a testament to the efficacy of carefully targeted Government expenditure as a policy instrument. I referred earlier to the dilemma and the conflict that exist in the degree to which we target payments of that sort and the scope to ease income tests and the combined operation of income tests and the tax system, and to the problem that poses in terms of limiting the availability of funds to improve the adequacy of basic payments.

Our opponents would have us believe that the only method of improving living standards is by reducing the level of personal taxation. Of course, what is implied but left unstated by the Opposition is that its policy on tax cuts would undoubtedly give the highest level of cuts to the highest income earners. The Opposition has stated that it would change the base broadening measures in the income tax system which have been so important in ensuring the integrity of that system. Measures such as capital gains tax, substantiation, fringe benefits, and so forth have been implemented by the present Government. The effect of the Opposition's proposals concerning the tax system would be grossly inequitable. I think that is fairly clear.

This Government remains committed to delivering tax cuts to lower and middle income earners but it is also committed to direct expenditure measures designed to achieve social policy goals. What we need, I believe, at the time of the wage tax trade-off next year is an appropriately balanced package which, as well as tax cuts, includes an array of improvements in the social wage provision that are designed to target those least well off and those who do not stand to benefit greatly from cuts in the income tax system. The fact the Opposition ignores is that directly targeted payments to low income earners provide a much more effective method of alleviating poverty for low income earners than do cuts in personal taxation rates.

To ensure the correct targeting of FAS payments in the future, this Bill introduces important changes in the administration of the income test for those applying for FAS. Currently, the test is based on income received by applicants in the preceding four-week period. This is both a difficult system to administer, and it can cause unnecessary difficulties and hardships for low income families whose income is subject to considerable fluctuations. As from 29 December this will be replaced by a test based on taxable income over the period of one financial year. This test will be indexed to increases in the consumer price index over the preceding 12-month period. In addition to this revised income test, the legislation introduces an assets test from 29 December this year. This will exclude from FAS any applicant who, with his or her spouse, has combined assets of more than $300,000. As is the case with the pensions assets test, property such as the family home is exempt from consideration under these measures. Proper targeting of welfare payments is a key component of an equitable system. These measures are designed to produce that equity by delivering the largest benefits to those most in need.

Earlier in my speech I quoted a figure which placed 16.9 per cent of Australian children as living in poverty earlier this decade. I would like to expand briefly upon this point, because that single figure does not give a full picture of the situation which exists. A broad figure measured across the entire Australian community can often hide significant areas of poverty. In a recent article in the Current Affairs Bulletin, Dr Judy Yates reproduced a table which showed that in 1981-82 40.8 per cent of single parent families were living in poverty after meeting the costs of their housing. Taking an even closer look we find that of those single parent families living in private rental accommodation, a staggering 61.7 per cent were forced to live in poverty after meeting their housing costs. It is a basic philosophy of Labor that no group in our community should be forced to endure such misery. No Australian child should be forced to start life with the crippling handicap of poverty imposed on them.

This Government has recognised the particular plight of single parent families, a group growing in numbers in our community. We have gone forward to develop a package which offers assistance targeted to meet the needs of this group, a package free of moral judgments on the worth of one type of family unit above another. The Government has already announced the jobs, education and training scheme, which is aimed at overcoming on a number of levels the difficulties single parents often face in entering the market-place. To complement this package the Government now announces the introduction of a sole parent's pension to replace the previous supporting parent's benefit and widow's pension class A. This removes an administrative anomaly which grew from an inappropriate moral judgment on the worth of different categories of beneficiaries. Such judgments are incompatible with the thrust of the Government's review of the social security system. This review of the social security system is the most comprehensive undertaken by any Australian Government. It is proving a demonstration of the political will possessed by this Government to deal with the problems of poverty. It is also a demonstration of the considerable political will of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and I believe that this House should commend him for his work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for debating these two Bills, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, is extremely limited, so I cannot spend much time talking about the remarks of the honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin). However, I cannot let one thing pass. At the end of his speech he was giving some figures in relation to child poverty. It is a matter of record that the number of children living in poverty rose substantially in the first term of the Hawke Government. In the last election the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that child poverty would be eliminated and that finally sparked the Government into some sort of action. The attack on living standards of families in this country, particularly one income families, has been very marked under the Hawke Government. I welcome anything it might be doing now to alleviate poverty, but the record shows that a great deal of that poverty is thanks to the Hawke-Keating Government, and particularly to its economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: If I had a little more time I would spend some of it congratulating the Government on a number of aspects of this social security legislation which deserve credit. This credit has been given by Opposition members. There are a couple of matters in which I have a particular interest but I will be able to refer to them only briefly. Because of the guillotine and the limitation on time of speakers, one simply cannot do justice to the very wide-ranging effects of these Bills. The areas provide for expenditure of approximately $20 billion and yet we are to have less than two hours in this Parliament to debate these major Bills. I would have liked to say quite a bit about pensioners and I certainly echo the words of the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer), who spoke a little earlier this morning about pensioners, particularly aged pensioners. In the time available I can only say that I do agree with him and with the statements of the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I confine my remarks on age pensioners to those very brief comments.

There are a couple of areas of the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) that I want to pick up and make a quick comment on. They relate specifically to the jobs, education and training (JET) scheme and the new start program. We are told that JET is to provide comprehensive advice, assistance, labour market training, education and child care for sole parents, and I certainly welcome that. This is a subject on which I have often spoken during my time in the House of Representatives. I remind the Minister of the number of times I have referred to an undertaking in an earlier Budget that sole parents and widow's pensioners would be given counselling to find employment. When the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training undertook this year an inquiry on access to training and employment by social security recipients, it was discovered that this word `counselling' did not have the meaning that one might have expected it to have. It was only a policing function. People were invited to come and be checked up on-whether they were working or whether their financial circumstances were such as would continue to qualify them for the pension. These were people who needed counselling and advice on the available government education and training programs. That counselling was not given in the past but I hope it will be given in the future.

I want to tell the Minister, however, that despite the report of that House of Representatives Committee, there are still major deficiencies in the matter of informing social security recipients as to their entitlements, and I can speak on that from first-hand knowledge. The report of that Committee included this recommendation:
Commonwealth Employment Service employment counselling should be upgraded to give priority to assisting long-term social security recipients to return to the workforce.

I know I am talking about the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and I understand that the Minister's speech was essentially about the Department of Social Security, but nevertheless it is the attitude that `this is the Department of Social Security's job and this is the CES's job' which means that we do not get the effectiveness of government programs that we are entitled to expect. The counselling, information and training that social security recipients are entitled to is not being passed on to a large number of them at present. As I said, I speak from first-hand information because I had an interest to see whether that report might have had some effect on the provision of counselling. I do not have any evidence that it has yet.

I want to congratulate the Government on the introduction of the new start program. I was very pleasantly surprised by this announcement in the Budget Speech. The social security review made some recommendations to this effect, but the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training also said:
There is a need for special payment to ensure people have an incentive to move from welfare benefits into employment, and to tide them over in their new situation.

People who have been out of employment for a long time, for whatever reason-whether it be on unemployment benefits or because they are sole parents rearing a family-are in a very poor position to basically physically equip themselves to attempt to get employment. The Committee's report recommended:
Consideration should be given to the provision of a return-to-work allowance, paid as an advance, for social security recipients who had been out of the workforce for a long period of time.

As a member of that inquiry, I can say that the range of suggested means by which that might be achieved was very wide and varied indeed and I did not envy anybody making the decision about how one would facilitate it. The Government's decision to give people a once-off payment of $100, after a long term of unemployment, to meet the reality of their situation, is to be welcomed.

In the very few minutes left to me I must take this opportunity to make some comment about family allowance. I quote what the Minister said in his second reading speech regarding changes to the assessment methods for the family assistance scheme:

The basis for income testing of FAS will be changed. Currently the income test, which operates on income received in the previous four weeks, encourages perceptions of the payment as a welfare measure. It is difficult to administer and creates anomalies for many low paid workers whose income fluctuates. The Bill will implement an income test based on the taxable income of the claimant and her or his spouse. . . Payments in 1989 will generally be based on taxable income for the year ended 30 June 1988.

On 2 November I asked the Minister a question in this House about the means testing of family allowance. The Minister did not initially understand the import of my question but picked it up on his way through his answer. I was actually referring to the fact that means testing on the basis of taxable income creates some anomalies. I mentioned in my question that whilst people who have incomes of less that $50,000 may think they are entitled to family allowance, a number do not get it. However, families which have a much higher income than them may be getting family allowance. This is because the payment of family allowance is linked to the income tax system and, except in cases of hardship, there is not a means by which one can adjust for the inequities this system creates. I only became aware of this problem because I was approached by a constituent about it. This was a case where the husband and wife had one child and both were full time in the work force. Their income was in excess of $52,000. When the wife dropped out of the work force in order to have a second child their income almost halved. They did not qualify for family allowance as they believed they would even though his income was only $28,000. Because of the timing of her dropping out of the work force, there was not the required 25 per cent reduction in their income for their 1987-88 taxation return. In other words, she dropped out of the work force late enough in the financial year for their income not to be reduced by the mandatory 25 per cent. I was not aware that people's income had to reduce by 25 per cent for one financial year before they qualified to receive family allowance in the subsequent financial year. Because she dropped out fairly late in the financial year they have to wait to qualify until the end of the next financial year, when their income tax return for 1988-89 would show that he earned only $28,000 during the year. For 18 months he will have supported a wife and two children but have received no family allowance. It is a real anomaly.

I contrast that with the situation of an age pensioner or someone who stands to lose an allowance. I know that this does not apply to the family allowance. Age pensioners are bombarded all year with letters from the Department of Social Security asking whether their income situation has changed or whether their assets have changed. The Department is looking for a change for the better so that it can take some pension off them. I contrast that with the family allowance benefit, which is meant to support families in genuine need. For it, the instant adjustment mechanism does not exist. I am not suggesting that the Government should be writing to families every three months saying, `Are you earning less and therefore can we give you some money?' People are quite capable of going to the Department of Social Security, particularly in the case of family allowance, and saying, `I think I am entitled to some family allowance whereas before I may not have been entitled to it'. There needs to be a shorter term adjustment mechanism. There are very real inequities at present.

As I pointed out in my question without notice to the Minister, some families with incomes below the means test level are not receiving any family allowance-for example, I mentioned the case of a family earning $28,000-but someone earning in excess of $50,000 would be getting it. This leads to the inequity of a family needing to have both parents working to earn an income of $52,000. Another family may have one income earner getting $52,000. That one income earner family with the same number of children is in a much better position than the family where two incomes are needed to receive the same amount of money. Because of the method of administration of this means test the lower income people, the average working people, are very substantially disadvantaged.

The Minister has had much to say in relation to income testing of the family allowance. I do not agree with him because I do not believe that this payment to a mother should be based on her husband's income. It should be based only on her income. Nevertheless, the Minister has justified this in terms of equity. However, the method of administration leads to straight-out cases of inequity. It is also arbitrary in that chance of the date of cessation of employment of the wife, particularly when she is dropping out of the work force in order to have another child, leads to all sorts of financial disincentives that I do not believe the Government would want to have built into what is supposed to be a family support payment. I certainly know that the Opposition would not want to have that built in.

Time precludes me from saying very much more. I welcome moves by the Government to alleviate child poverty. I say very briefly-particularly following some of the things that the honouable member for Sydney said that concerned me a little-that we have to look at this report on poverty traps we received this week. We must be careful that, when trying to help people in need, we are not actually putting people into need and building in situations in which there are very heavy pressures against people who are trying to help themselves to get out of need. Those measures in the Bill that assist people into the work force and into better working circumstances are to be welcomed. I just hope that the pressures of the poverty traps, which seem to be with us forever, do not diminish the opportunity for the success of those measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.20 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with the resolution agreed to yesterday. The debate may be resumed at a later hour.
—As a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that the Deputy Prime Minister and Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, will be absent from Question Time today due to flight delays.
—Sydney Airport?
—As distinct from the Opposition with ideas, there was a blow-out of a tyre of the plane and the Attorney-General cannot be here.
—I thought it was Sydney Airport.
—No, we cannot blame Sydney Airport for that. Any questions normally addressed to the Attorney-General should be directed to the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) put forward a proposition based on standing order 144 that a question was out of order because questions cannot refer to debates in the current session. I ruled that the question was in order. I draw the attention of the House to page 492 of House of Representatives Practice, which states:

INTERJECT.PARA: References in questions to debates in the current session, concluded or adjourned, are out of order . . . The rule does not preclude questions on the subject matter of such debates, which may be so broad as to cover, for example, the country's whole foreign policy, but rather precludes reference to the debate itself and to specific statements made in it.
This confirms that my ruling was correct and that there was no substance in the point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to further publicity given to the anti-Jewish and anti-Zionist statements of Imam Al Hilaly and, in particular, to the criticism of those statements by the head of the New South Wales Ethnic Affairs Commission, Dr Paolo Totaro. The issue has now been formally referred to the Commonwealth by the New South Wales Government. Is the Prime Minister so compromised because of the personal association between himself, the Treasurer and the then Premier of New South Wales with the Imam--
—Order! The honourable member for Mitchell will not cast aspersions on any member of this House. He will rephrase his question, leaving out that part which impugns another member.

—Is the Prime Minister so concerned, because of past associations between himself, the Treasurer and the then Premier of New South Wales with the Imam before the last New South Wales election, that he is now unable to prevent the Imam from pursuing his dangerous and inflammatory course of racial hatred?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in any way compromised by the fact, which seemed to agitate the small minds of those opposite when we were last sitting, that there exists a photograph-a remarkable thing!-in which I appear and in which my friend and colleague the Treasurer appears, as do other colleagues of mine in the Labor Party, with the gentleman in question. As I said across the table to the Leader of the Opposition, I have had my photograph taken with the Leader of the Opposition but I can assure him, members of this House and all members of the Australian public that that fact does not in any way indicate that I embrace any of the nonsense associated with his position.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a most remarkable situation: trial by photograph, assassination by the camera. One is at a function and one happens to have one's photograph taken. I make no apology for the fact that before the last Federal election, as part of the great surge of support for the Labor Party, the Moslem community in the city of Sydney indicated its support for this Government-as well it might-at a function which I attended. There was a great range of people at that function, a number of whom I have had significant arguments with in regard to aspects of the Middle East situation. The fact that I have had those strong arguments with them and that they are aware of the deep disagreement I have with them on particular aspects does not mean that I cease to attend functions where there will be people who have different points of view from mine. It is about time the Opposition got its mind onto serious issues of policy and stopped trying to pollute the Australian political debate by this particular form of character assassination.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question also relates in some sense to events in the Middle East, but by contrast with the previous question it is a serious one. I draw to the Prime Minister's attention the recent decision of the Palestine National Council to recognise implicitly, through its acceptance of United Nations Security Council resolutions 242 and 338, the existence of Israel, and also its decision to establish an independent Palestinian state. I ask the Prime Minister whether he can give the Australian Government's reaction to these-as it seems to many people-hopeful events, and whether he would use his influence to bring about some end to the conflict which has beset the Middle East for so many years.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for his question. He is indeed correct in the basis of his question: that the events and the decisions at the Algiers meeting are such that they should be applauded, with the qualifications, in some respect, that I will go to in a moment. I believe that it is the case that this Algiers meeting saw a significant movement by the Palestinians on some of the very contentious issues which have hindered the important search for a peaceful settlement of some of these tragic issues in the Middle East, and particularly, of course, the Israeli-Arab dispute.

ANSWER.PARA: In that respect, let me say on behalf of the Government that we particularly welcome the Palestine National Council's acceptance of United Nations Security Council resolutions 242 and 338. The National Council has accepted those two intrinsically important resolutions as a basis for the holding of an international conference on these issues. Of course, as anyone who is acquainted with the complexities of these issues knows, the acceptance of those two Security Council resolutions implies the recognition of the state of Israel-something that those of us who over the years have been concerned with this complex issue have indicated is a fundamental requirement for a sensible furtherance of discussion in this area. If there is to be the possibility of a sensible furtherance of discussion, with the possibility at the end of those discussions of a peaceful resolution of this dispute, then there is the requirement on the part of the Palestinians that they recognise the existence of the state of Israel.

So, as I say, the reference and the recognition by the Palestinians in their Algiers decision of resolutions 242 and 338 involve an implicit recognition of the state of Israel. We would hope that this would lead in the near future to an explicit and unequivocal acknowledgment on the part of the Palestinians of Israel's right to exist. But I do not quibble about that. It is a significant step forward. In the same sense, a very significant step forward in the Algiers decision is that aspect of the declaration which referred to the rejection of terrorism as an instrument for the achievement of the objectives of the Palestinians. That again is something which should be unequivocally welcomed. We do note that rejection of terrorism was to some extent qualified in terms of what they referred to as their rights to pursue their objective of the Palestinian state. We would hope that this important step that was taken would lead on in turn to an unequivocal rejection of the use of terror.

This Government has frequently noted its support for the right of self-determination of the Palestinian people, including their right, if they so choose, to independence and their own independent state. Having said that, we continue to believe that the question of a possible Palestinian state can only be resolved as part of an overall settlement of the Middle East dispute involving all the parties who are legitimately involved in and concerned with that dispute. Let me say in consequence of this that my Government continues to support the convening of an international conference on the Middle East as a means of resolving the Arab-Israeli dispute. Notwithstanding those appropriate qualifications to which I have referred, the Government believes that the meeting of the Palestine National Council in Algiers represents a positive step forward in the search for peace in the Middle East. One must say that to this stage the response of Israel has been negative. In some senses, of course, in Israel at present there are difficulties in the formulation of a response.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be a statement.
—I have not finished my answer yet.
—You are taking too long.
—I will finish very quickly, but I believe that the honourable member understands the importance of this issue.
—I understand the importance, but it should be a statement.

—I appreciate the point, and I will finish quickly. So far, the response by Israel has been negative. We recognise the difficulties at this point in time in the process of government formation that is there; nevertheless, it is the position of my Government-and I hope it would be the position of this House-that we believe Israel should make a positive response. It should at least recognise that a new and positive step has been taken. Israel can acknowledge properly, as we acknowledge, some of the qualifications that must be attached, but we hope that there will be a positive response on the part of Israel not only in terms of the broader interests of the region but in terms of the interests of Israel itself. The situation cannot continue in which agitation in the occupied territories is held down by force. I believe, and the Government believes, that a failure on the part of Israel to respond positively would not be acceptable to the world community. It is in the interests of the Middle East and, particularly, the people of Israel that they should match the positive step taken by the Palestinians by themselves taking a positive approach.

—Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs confirm that a sit-in at the Aboriginal Development Commission offices on 9 November 1988 led by Mr Ray Robinson was welcomed by a senior officer of the ADC, Mr Michael Stewart, who provided people with access to the ADC boardroom and subscriber trunk dialling telephones, and gave them 25 cakes, 100 sandwiches and drinks which cost $186.34? Did the sit-in include Mr Adam Perkins and Miss Hetti Perkins? Who paid the bill for $186.34 that was sent to the ADC? Will the Minister guarantee that it was not paid by the Australian taxpayers?
—I do not know the answer to the cakes and sandwiches question. This afternoon I will write to the ADC and obtain a formal response, and I will inform the honourable member in writing.

—Is the Treasurer aware of recent commentary suggesting that the Government should alter its fiscal policy? What are the reasons for the current stance of fiscal policy and will the Government change that policy stance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the question. There will be no change to fiscal policy. Fiscal policy is bearing down on demand and is providing scope for increased private sector investment, which is now running very strongly through the economy and, of course, underpinning its long term restructure. Indeed, fiscal policy is now as tight as it has been in 35 years. Last year's Budget surplus of 0.7 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) was the first in 35 years for which comparable records have been kept. This year's Budget surplus in prospect of 1.7 per cent of GDP even builds on that surplus. Yesterday's announcement of the Forward Estimates confirms the tightness of policy already in place; that is, the decisions already taken by the Government mean that as a percentage of GDP outlays will continue to fall progressively until 1991-92. In other words, the profligacy in Federal Government spending in the 1970s and early 1980s will have been wiped out and wound back to 1972-73 levels, and that is validated in the $11.7 billion of expenditure reductions which I referred to yesterday, nominated in the Forward Estimates. Yesterday, in commenting on the Forward Estimates, the shadow finance Minister said, `The Forward Estimates presented today serve to perpetuate and exaggerate the illusion of expenditure restraint under the Hawke-Keating Government'.

ANSWER.PARA: Just for the benefit of the shadow treasurer and the shadow finance Minister I table-one for each of them-chart 7 from the Forward Estimates, which shows the estimates of the outlays falling back to their early 1970 levels. It is interesting that the honourable member for Wentworth says that he is a person who understands the numbers and the technical arguments--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is.

—Is he? Yet, he says it serves to perpetuate and exaggerate the illusion of expenditure restraint. We have Commonwealth outlays down 5 to 6 percentage points of GDP, back to the early 1970s levels, and we still have a shadow finance spokesperson in the relevant portfolio saying that it is an illusion. He is saying that a 6 percentage points shift, $11.7 billion of nominated expenditure reductions by the Department of Finance, is an illusion. This is intellectualism within the Liberal Party.
—What about your asset sales?
—Order! The honourable member for Wentworth will cease interjecting.
—We are looking for a sane debate in this country, yet the shadow finance spokesman says--
—Why didn't you come into the debate yesterday?
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—The shadow finance spokesman says, `Well, a 5 to 6 percentage points reduction in Federal Government outlays is an illusion'. Worse than that, we have a competition in policy, this different view of fiscal policy in the Opposition. In the Sunday newspapers in an interview by Mr Peacock with former Senator Chipp, Mr Peacock, the shadow Treasurer says he does not believe the economy is as overheated as the Government wants people to believe it is. Then the shadow finance spokesman said last Wednesday that the Government has just not been prepared to admit that the economy was overheating. So on the one hand one says the economy is underheated and that the Government is exaggerating and on the other hand the shadow finance Minister says the economy is overheated.
—He didn't say that.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Lowe.

—Is it any surprise to anybody that there is not a policy response from the Opposition because it does not know what are the cause and effects. It does not have any agreement about what the state of policy ought to be.

ANSWER.PARA: Then at the Press Club, immediately after this year's Budget, the shadow treasurer said that the coalition would deliver a lower Budget surplus than the Government. In other words, the fiscal policy was too tight and ought to be relaxed. Then the shadow finance spokesman said in an interview on 2GB on 16 November that the public sector was still kicking growth along. Contrary to the shadow treasurer, the shadow finance Minister told Michelle Grattan of the Age of 19 September that he would keep the surplus intact. So he will keep the surplus intact and the shadow Treasurer says that fiscal policy should be relaxed and that it was too tight. One says that the economy is overheating and the other one says that it is underheating. Is it any wonder that the Opposition has no fiscal policy?
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Before members opposite come out with their manifesto about feelings, intuition, premonitions and values, what about some policy on specifics, about fiscal policy, the stance of fiscal policy, budgetary cuts, taxation and coming clean with the Australian electorate, instead of this shabby kind of press statement that went out yesterday talking about the illusion of expenditure cuts for a government that has reduced Federal government spending more than any government in the Western world.

—Order! I call attention to a rule which is one of the most stringent that we have for the guidance of business-standing order 84. I may say that an ordinary interjection here and there is not usually taken notice of by the Chair and has not usually been taken notice of by previous Chairs. A constant stream of interjections is decidedly disorderly. If it continues I will name without warning.
—Madam Speaker, on a point of order: will that same admonition apply to those who do not maintain answers which are relevant to the question asked?
—The Chair made the statement very explicit.
—So it will apply both to the relevance and to the individual?
—It will apply to interjections which become decidedly disorderly. I thought I had made that very clear.
—Madam Speaker, I am asking: will it also apply to relevance, as does another standing order--

—As I have already said, it will apply under standing order 84, which I ask all members of this House to take note of. The continued barrage of interjections that I am getting from my left is decidedly disorderly. If it continues I will name without warning. That is a very clear statement.
—Not to relevance?
—Madam Speaker, on the point of order and on your statement: there is only one reason why this sort of thing occurs on this side of the House. When you tolerate members going on for over 10 minutes--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for O'Connor. He is now quite outside the Standing Orders.
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. In response to one of the points of order, you mentioned the speakers on your left. I hope that you will apply the rule equally to speakers on your right.
—That is exactly what I said in the statement I made to the House.
—It was not what you said to the House.
—If you would listen instead of interjecting consistently you would hear the Chair.
—Madam Speaker, you mentioned interjections on your left alone.

—When I made the statement I asked the House to take note of my statement. I then made a further statement, in answer to the honourable member for O'Connor, that the interjections on my left had been decidedly disorderly.

—Madam Speaker, on the point of order: the conduct of this House takes place within the framework of Standing Orders. On the basis of the ruling you just gave you are giving precedence to one particular standing order, which could be regarded as an attempt to intimidate the Opposition. The point of order taken by my colleague the right honourable member for New England and Leader of the National Party of Australia suggested that the standing orders applying relevance to answers to questions should also be enforced with equal vigour. I ask you to give the House an assurance that you will give equal attention to that standing order as you will to the interjections.
—The Chair has put up with a very disorderly House over a fairly long time now. It does not intend to put up with it any longer.
—Hear, hear! Both sides.

—I suggest to those in the House on my right and my left that there are other standing orders in this House that should be adhered to. Standing order 84 and standing order 55 are two which they seem to totally neglect and ignore. Other standing orders are being used, misused or abused, depending on who is using them. The Chair will no longer tolerate it. That is the end of that.
—Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. Do I take it from that comment that we on this side of the House have your assurance that you will enforce with equal vigour and resolution--
—She always has.

—Those who are interjecting on my right are not assisting the Chair. They will cease immediately. The statement the Chair made is that standing order 84, under which continued interjections are disorderly, will be applied by the Chair. The Chair will no longer tolerate it.
—Do I take it from that comment, Madam Speaker, that we on this side of the House have your assurance that you will enforce with equal vigour and resolution--

—Those who are interjecting on my right are not assisting the Chair and will cease immediately. The statement that the Chair made is that standing order 84, which relates to continued interjections becoming disorderly, will be applied by the Chair. The Chair will no longer tolerate it.
—Madam Speaker, could I resume the question that I was asking of you before I was interrupted?
—Certainly.

—On behalf of the Opposition, can I have your assurance that you will enforce with equal vigour and resolution the standing orders relating to relevance of answers as you have so clearly indicated that you will enforce with vigour and resolution the standing order relating to persistent interjections? It is that equality of treatment and an assurance relating to it that we seek. It is necessary for members of the Opposition to be satisifed that the affairs of this House will be conducted fairly and in a balanced manner.
—In my opinion the Chair has always enforced the other standing orders with complete impartiality. I call the honourable member for McPherson.
—I take it, Madam Speaker, that you are not prepared to give me that assurance.
—You may take it that the Chair will do as it has always done and will apply the Standing Orders with impartiality.
—So you are not prepared to give me that assurance?
—The Chair will apply--

—The Chair will apply the Standing Orders as the Chair has been applying them. They will be applied with impartiality to both sides of the House. I point out to the House once again that there is no standing order on the length of answers. The House has never had the guts to give the Chair one. I suggest that once again the House goes back to its Procedure Committee and gives the Chair the right to cut down long answers. I totally agree with those within the House--
—The Government wouldn't allow it. It's for making sermons.
—I warn you that if you continue to interject while the Chair is on its feet, you are in trouble. That is the type of discourtesy that I am talking about.
—It is not, with respect, discourteous, Madam Speaker.
—Enough of your sermons!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I name the honourable member for Menzies.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the honourable member for Menzies be suspended from the service of the House.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Menzies is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The honourable member for Menzies thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shipton

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order in relation to your ruling on standing orders 84 and 55. Is your ruling an extension of the practice and an extension of the ruling of Deputy Speaker John Chanter who, in 1920, commented on the equivalent of this standing order? I call your attention to a rule which is one of the most stringent and that is standing order 84 for the guidance of business, upon which you have just ruled. Standing order 84 states that no member may interrupt another member while speaking, et cetera. You have interpreted that standing order in a stringent way. I ask you whether your ruling is more stringent than that of the 1920 ruling which said:

INTERJECT.PARA: I may say that an ordinary interjection here and there is not usually taken notice of by the Chair, but a constant stream of interjections is decidedly disorderly.
I also ask you what is your interpretation of a `constant stream of interjections'; are they from the same person, or from people on both sides--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a serious point of order.
—Order! I know it is serious.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Shipton

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. Madam Speaker, I will continue. Does the constant stream of interjections have to be from one person, people from one side of the House or from people from all sides of the House? I ask whether you would still apply the interpretation on page 469 of Pettifer's House of Representatives Practice of the discretion that the Chair has, and I quote:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Chair, although recognising all interjections as disorderly, has also been of the opinion that it should not interfere as long as they are short and do not interrupt the thread of the speech being delivered.

Is that still in your mind? My further point of order relates to standing order 84. I refer you to standing order 85. You have interpreted standing order 84 to apply to Question Time. I invite your attention to standing order 85, which says:
The Speaker . . . after having called the attention of the House . . . to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition . . .
Will you apply that standing order, which relates to irrelevance and tedious repetition, to answers by Ministers at Question Time?

TALK.START.PARA: —The standing order actually says `members in debate' but I take your point. I do not think you were here or were listening when I first read out Deputy Speaker Chanter's ruling. I agree that the ordinary interjection here and there is part and parcel of what takes place in Question Time and in this House. It would be ludicrous to expect everybody to sit dumb. As I said, I am perfectly prepared, as every previous Speaker has been prepared, for the odd interjection. I regret that we do not have any humorous ones anymore.
—What about mine?

—Yours we can do without. A constant stream of interjections is decidedly disorderly and I think any fair-minded person would say that in the last few weeks we have had a constant stream of interjections. That could be from an individual or it could be from a number of people one after another. I do not intend to apply standing order 84 or 55 any more stringently than other Speakers have. I do intend that the House will come to order.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. This is a serious matter. In the 10 years or so that I have been here I have not felt under immediate threat from the Speaker of being named without warning. I do not recall that having been raised in the time I have been here.
—I raised it about six weeks ago.

—I do not recall it under any previous Speaker. I ask you, Madam Speaker, whether looking back over the last few weeks there would have been anybody left on this side of the House without having been named, had this particular new procedure been in place?

—I would expect that, the Chair having spoken as it has, it would be the responsibility of this House to accept what the Chair has said. The House is becoming disorderly. Each single member has a responsibility to ensure that the House operates with maturity and with some commonsense. I would imagine that the Chair, having drawn attention to the matter, will allow interjections to continue but they will not become disorderly.
—On a further point of order, Madam Speaker: I ask whether you will look at standing order 85 as it relates to irrelevance and tedious repetition in relation to answers at Question Time.
—I certainly will.

—I raise a point of order on the same issue, Madam Speaker. In the Standing Orders there are provisions which deal with relevance in debate. Frequently, members are directed by the Chair to be relevant and told that, if they are not relevant, effectively they can be sat down. The members always then become relevant. May I ask the difference between relevance in debate, when the Chair seems to have no difficulty in determining whether a person is being relevant or not, and relevance in Question time? It is the same word: it cannot have a different meaning.

—At times it can. Some of the Bills that come before the House are broader than others. Some go on to say `and for related matters', in which case we have a wider debate. So the matter of relevance is not so urgent. Other Bills are very narrow and that constrains the debate.

—On a further point of order, Madam Speaker, I point out that if the question is a clear and specific one we can expect the Minister answering to be relevant, and that should occasion you no difficulty in ruling him to be relevant.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. Question Time is not a place for debate. This is a debate on a ruling.
—The Leader of the House will let me hear the finish of this point of order.
—In the interests of the way in which Question Time is going to be run, can I get an answer from you, Madam Speaker?
—The Chair has always ruled on relevance and will continue to rule on relevance when it is raised.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: White Mr P.N.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence will be aware of the following statement by the Acting Director of Air Force Safety:

QUESTION.PARA: The first six months of this year have been the worst introduction to the year that we have had in the last 20 years . . . What we have found . . . is that inexperience has been a major factor in aircraft accidents to date.

We now have senior Royal Australian Air Force officers complaining of further cuts in flying hours, which will make it impossible to maintain current experience levels, let alone improve them. In the face of these facts and given that the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has had evidence from the Government's most senior officers in the Defence Force about the continuing decline in capabilities of the Defence Force, how can the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel keep saying that there has been no loss in Defence Force capabilities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no loss in Defence Force capabilities. The quotation by the honourable member amounts to a partial quotation which has since been qualified by the individual concerned. Obviously, in training more pilots, with the loss rates that we have at the moment the training exercise is larger. Where a training requirement is associated with the introduction of a new aircraft, as we have with the F18, priorities will be assigned to that exercise over and above exercises elsewhere. That is a natural concomitant of those circumstances.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the honourable gentleman that the loss rates we have in our Air Force in no way compare to the much more significant problems being experienced by North Atlantic Treaty Organisation air forces. For example, in the case of the United States, where one moves beyond the six-year return of service obligation, as far as pilot retention rates are concerned critical areas of the United States Air Force are losing something like 50 per cent of their pilots per annum. Nothing like that loss rate is occurring in the Royal Australian Air Force.

Whilst outlays have been falling as a percentage of gross domestic product under this Government, whilst there have been real reductions in the way the Treasurer outlined earlier in Question Time today, there were real increases in the defence area in the last Budget. There were real increases in the amounts of money devoted to the defence forces. There is no doubt about the commitment of this Government to the defence of this country. The honourable member ought to bear that in mind when he puts forward his own defence policy-at last-as I am told he will do over the next couple of weeks. He is in the wonderful position of saying, on the one hand, `We are going to spend more money on operations and personnel' and, on the other hand, having to explain how he will pay for his promises to introduce air-to-air refuelling for the F111s, expanded amphibious capability, nuclear-powered ships and submarines, and an aircraft carrier which he does not describe as an aircraft carrier but as a `seagoing platform capable of operating fixed-wing aircraft'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. The point of order gets back to relevancy. I point out to you that the answer that has just been given has been given by the Leader of the House, whose job it is to run the business of the House on the part of the Government and who therefore should have close regard to Standing Orders. He is talking about Opposition policy in answer to a question which has been put to him concerning flying time and training. I bring you back to the point that I put to you: relevance has to have the same meaning, whether it is in debate or in Question Time. The Minister should confine himself to the question and not debate the question or engage in sermons, of which we get so many from the Government side in Question Time.
—I find the Minister to be in order.

—The honourable member asked me questions about the resources we were prepared to devote to the training requirements of the Air Force. Any question related to the allocation of resources in the defence budget involves a trade-off between one function and another. The fact that the Opposition even questions the relevance of my answer is an indication of the sort of ignorance that informs the Opposition's defence policy. The fact is that the honourable member does not comprehend and therefore is able to produce these absurd promises. On the one hand he says he will reduce the equipment vote in order to spend more money on operations. On the other hand, he comes in here and says, `We are going to buy nuclear-powered ships and submarines, amphibious capability, air-to-air refuelling for the F111s and an aircraft carrier'. The honourable member is totally ignorant on defence policy, as he is totally ignorant on Treasury policy. All that his question reveals is the poverty of his policy making processes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.
