SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do, Madam Speaker.
—Please proceed.
—On 9 November 1988 in the Legislative Council of South Australia, the Minister for Local Government, Barbara Wiese, made the following remark:

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that a Federal member of the Liberal Party has been involved with this-
that is, the Stirling-

Ratepayers Action Group. He certainly volunteered his services to sit on an executive committee of the Ratepayers Action Group at the time it was formed. I would be very distressed if that member, the member for Mayo, had participated in the decisions that have been taken by the action group to encourage people to break the law in this way.
I do not suppose that we should be terribly surprised by such action . . .

The point, Madam Speaker, is that in the first place I was never a member of the executive committee of that action group. I was a member of a steering committee designed to set up a ratepayers association. Secondly, I never supported a proposal that Stirling ratepayers should not pay their rates. Indeed, I cautioned that steering committee, before the ratepayers association was formed, not to go down that path.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to foster and support Australia's scientific capacity thereby critically eroding efforts to meet Australia's economic and social challenges.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, a watershed in the raging science debate will occur tonight when several hundred scientists hold a rally at the National Science and Technology Centre, which is to be officially opened. Could any one of us ever witness a more damning indictment of the Government's policy than this unprecedented public display by scientists? It is unheard of, utterly without precedent, for scientists to take to the streets in this way. It is very important in this whole debate to understand the character of scientists. They love their work, and often when one speaks with them they feel embarrassed at being paid to do something that they enjoy so much. They are the last people in the world to so dramatically demonstrate their anger at government. After all, it was only last year that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) was calling them disorganised wimps who could not lobby for their cause for love or money. Not any more!

SPEECH.PARA: So, what has happened to bring about tonight's rally? The answer is as simple as it is tragic. Science in Australia today is in a desperate state and scientists will not stand by and passively witness their country's economic and social fabric steadily decline. For this they deserve the support and gratitude of all Australians. Anyone concerned for the future of Australia will throw his support behind our scientific community.

At a time when our disastrous balance of payments situation demands increased productivity, greater competitiveness, structural adjustment, and all of the ingenuity that we can muster, the Government depletes our research and development capabilities. Self-interest, if nothing else, should force the Government to enhance, not destroy, our scientific capacity. The Government's mishandling of science and technology runs deep, and it extends even beyond the much publicised systematic destruction of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO). The negligence centres on, first, wrongful reductions in appropriations; secondly, an upsetting of the delicate balance that must be struck between basic research and short-term development; thirdly, a change in direction of research, much too far away from agriculture and mining; and, fourthly, totally inadequate ministerial arrangements. All of those policy failings are interrelated and together paint a picture of utter desolation.

The inexcapable truth is that morale in the science community has hit rock bottom and there is no sign whatsoever that this Government, first, acknowledges the problem or, secondly, will do anything to remedy it. This has resulted in a serious loss of scientists overseas. In case anyone should doubt the existence of the brain drain, let me quote the head of the Atmospheric Research Division of the CSIRO, Dr Brian Tucker. Incidentally, that division is charged with researching the greenhouse effect, supposedly the Government's No. 1 environmental priority-a problem of such high priority that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) cannot even obtain $1m from Cabinet for further research! I would agree that in global terms the greenhouse effect is the most worrying of all environmental problems. Dr Brian Tucker stated that in his division over the past six years government funding has been slashed by 40 per cent in real terms and staff numbers have been cut from 140 to 105. An article in the press reported him as follows:
``We've lost four of our best scientists to the US'', Dr Tucker said. ``Everybody talks about the brain drain but we really do experience it.''

Young scientists are also bitterly disillusioned by the insecurity of a career in science. A survey carried out at the Australian National University last August indicated that, of all the non-tenured research scientists at that university, 91 per cent believed that their career prospects in Australia were very poor. Furthermore, 61 per cent stated that they would be prepared to leave Australia to pursue careers overseas. Moreover, all tertiary institutions report a decline in interest in science as a career. Fewer graduates are going on to post-graduate study than ever before. This means that the chickens have not come home to roost as of today, but they certainly will in the near future as the pool of scientists, particularly specialised scientists, dries up. Is it any wonder at all that scientists and potential scientists have little or no chance of building careers? In the past year 80 per cent of professional appointments at the CSIRO have been short term, that is, one or two-year contracts only. As well, the capability and capacity of the CSIRO to take on young scientists has, to all intents and purposes, ceased. The capacity of the CSIRO to take on young scientists has not just diminished but finished.
Just what is the Government's response to the crisis in science? Believe it or not, the Government has established an interdepartmental committee (IDC).

TALK.START.PARA: —Another one.
—Another IDC. That defies belief. As if the problem is not bad enough, the Government has created another IDC as if to sweep everything under the carpet.

SPEECH.PARA: In the past three years three thorough reports have canvassed all the issues that will be the subject of discussion by this IDC, all of them dealing with the CSIRO and science generally. One wonders whether the Minister has read them. If so, why is there a need to set up yet another inquiry, yet another inter-departmental committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —He has failed to deliver.

—The Minister has failed to deliver. Let us turn our attention to the Minister, for whom some of us, if not most of us, have genuine affection. To all appearances he is sincere in his desire to assist science. If nice guys finish last, this Minister is not even in the race. It is not enough for the Government to trot him out as the human face whenever the heat gets turned up, as it will tonight with the rally of scientists, to explain away the problems caused by government inaction and neglect. We are sick and tired of the cloak of innocence that the Minister wraps around himself to hide the Government from the anger and disillusionment of the science community and a growing number of people in the community. It is not enough for the Minister to be bumbling and genial; he has to deliver. He has had 5 1/2 years. He has been part of the complete and utter destruction of Australia's scientific capacity. It is something of a mystery to me how the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business can continue in conscience to argue away, to excuse away and to apologise for his own Government's inaction.
—He should resign.

—He should resign. There was a stage when he made public hints about resigning as the ultimate declaration of support of solidarity with the scientific community, but nothing much came of that. If the Minister dares to call scientists wimps for failing to organise themselves into an effective lobby-those words will come back to haunt the Minister-he certainly is a wimp for not following through on the expectation of resigning in support of the cause of science.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody takes this Minister seriously any longer, least of all the science community itself. The Minister will tell us in reply to the Opposition's matter of public importance that it is all the fault of private industry, that the level of investment by private industry is woeful by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) standards and he will claim that the Government plays its part but is let down by the greedy, short-sighted, unimaginative capitalists out there. It is undeniably true that private sector investment in research and development is quite pathetic but it is also true that the Government's investment and lack of commitment in the area of science is just as pathetic. It is irrational to use this as a justification for cutting back on government expenditure in some sort of hope that private industry will be forced, will be dragged screaming, to increase its investment. Where is the logic in cutting back on government expenditure in the faint hope that private industry will pick it up?

There are some realities which the Minister and the Government have to accept in relation to the level of private industry investment. Firstly, the Australian market is small and often will not commercially justify investments on a large scale. This is particularly so for small to medium Australian companies. Also, too often research and development is done by the overseas parent companies and the research obviously is conducted in those foreign countries. The Minister has to take into account also the investment climate. He is delving into the realms of the ridiculous if he believes that the present climate is favourable or encouraging to private industry investment, where there is not an immediate return, with high interest rates and with a rigid, inflexible labour market. The Minister has to take account of the fact that businessmen must make commercial decisions and it is the overall policies of this Government which are serving as the greatest dampener to private investment.

The Minister should also take into account some of the culture of investment which is sadly lacking in the private industry. Undoubtedly those in private industry think that if they invest in research and development they may be sharing that knowledge and competitiveness with rivals in the market place. It is a very unsophisticated view but, nonetheless, instead of blaming others the Minister must face up to the Government's failings, and the failings exist for all to see. Within the Department of Finance which this Minister would have us believe is the real demon in the game, a short term view is taken.

The Government and its bureaucrats have to understand that investment in science is often long term and that basic science cannot always be measured in dollars and cents. There has to be that balance between the short term objectives of basic science and research and development, but the pendulum has swung too far towards short term development. It is this more than anything else which has unsettled the scientific community and led to a drying up of funds allowed by the Department of Finance.

Within the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce (DITAC) there is a similar ignorance of the true role of science, particularly in relation to CSIRO. Unfortunately, DITAC has a very narrow perspective. DITAC's policies are centred around manufacturing, and of course it concentrates on its own policy interests, so mining and agriculture, where we have a dominance in world markets, are suffering. We need to remain competitive in those areas. Quite frankly, unless the Government realises that by siphoning away what little funding there is from those areas in which we are efficient and which can be improved and where there are guaranteed markets for some of the Minister's more fanciful high-tech sunrise ideas, we will continue to suffer and the balance of payments will have no hope whatsoever.

The ministerial arrangements for CSIRO in particular are disgraceful. Take, for instance, the Forestry Division. It has an impact upon and reports to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. All those areas overlap in the Forestry Division. Quite frankly, CSIRO does not know to whom it is answerable. The Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce wants only that part of CSIRO that relates to manufacturing.

If the Minister gets out and speaks to officers in the CSIRO he will understand some of their basic concerns. It amazes me that the Minister would express surprise at the claim that CSIRO feels out on a limb and utterly neglected by government arrangements. No-one can doubt the grave deficiency in government policy: I challenge the Minister to deny that. As things stand now, CSIRO is on its knees. In a short while it will be nothing more than a second rate institution. Australia needs to sustain a base for long term strategic research. It can do this only through an investment in both capital and scientific personnel.

Let the guarantee of the Liberal-National parties stand unequivocal and unassailable: on return to government we will restore CSIRO and Australian science to the position of world pre-eminence it once enjoyed-a position that was lost soon after the Hawke Government came to power. Our nation has no other choice. Its future prosperity and the standard of living of ordinary Australians are dependent upon our scientific capacity.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that at long last we have the second matter of public importance in nearly six years proposed by members of the Opposition on the issue of Australia's scientific and technological capacity. They have been a long time getting around to it. Since March 1983, when I became Minister for Science and Technology, five shadow Ministers have put varying degrees of effort into the job. Unfortunately, none succeeded in stimulating public debate. Unlike the United States of America and Canada, our most recent election campaign failed to mention science. Since 1983 only 15 questions without notice have been asked by the Opposition on scientific subjects-10 in the first 18 months. There have been none at all in 1988. The previous matter of public importance on science was on 16 May 1985. The subject has simply not been on the political agenda. The Opposition totally lacks credibility here.

SPEECH.PARA: Politicians, bureaucrats and political journalists are uneasy about science issues because they do not understand them and are reluctant to confess ignorance. We do not find too many people in this building talking about superconductivity, although I exempt members of the subcommittee chaired by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), gene-shears, the Australia telescope, computer chip design, optical fibre and scientific instruments, all important new developments. Typically, we downgrade the importance of things we do not understand. If we have to choose between saying, `I do not understand this new development so there must be something wrong with me' and `This may seem very important to scientists, but in the real world who cares?', the second response is psychologically more appealing. Hence the striking contrast between the almost universal appeal of sport, where people share a common language and there is constant reinforcement of tribal values, and what is perceived as an area of limited, esoteric appeal. If the matter of public importance had been directed to the failure of the Australian community or the failure of Australian industry to foster and support Australia's scientific capacity--

TALK.START.PARA: —I predicted you would say that.
—I would have had no difficulty with it.
—No--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

—As the honourable member for Gippsland points out, there has been a decline in scientific vocations. That is absolutely correct. But I am sorry to say that it is a phenomenon that is not confined to Australia. It seems to be a universal phenomenon and quite a serious one. Relatively speaking, the Government's record is far better than that of industry. The problem can be expressed succinctly: Australia exports science and imports technology.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1968-69 Australia's gross expenditure on research and development amounted to 1.18 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP)-exactly the same figure it is now, 20 years later. There was a 20-year dip in between. Among the 24 nations of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) Australia ranked about the middle of the medium research and development performers in 1968-69. By 1988 we had fallen, in terms of proportion, to the middle of the small research and development performers. However, in absolute dollar figures, Australia still spends more on research and development than some nations with higher percentages but smaller GDPs, such as Denmark.

The reason for our 20-year dip was the appalling fall in private sector research and development spending in the 1970s. It fell here when figures in virtually every other OECD member country rose. Successive governments adopted the policy-or the bureaucrats did it for them-that government spending on research and development should aim to compensate for market failure until the private sector was prepared to take over the area; that is, by privatising research. There is something to be said about one aspect of the Friedmanite position. The proportionality between government and industry funding is still too heavily weighted towards government. Of the 24 OECD nations, Australia's budgetary expenditure on civilian research ranked sixth-far above Britain, Sweden, Japan and the United States as a percentage of GDP.

The area of greatest concern is that, at a time when other OECD nations have increased the quantum of funding, Australia is where it was two decades ago. The world has moved on; we have not. The good news is that the trend line in industry funding is rising and imaginative use of the industrial partnership and offsets programs will maintain or increase that trend. The bad news is that the private sector response has still been sluggish. It has mistakenly interpreted the reduction in government funding as an entirely negative signal. Even the take-up rate for the 150 per cent tax incentive was less than might have been expected.

Australia was not alone in virtually freezing budgetary appropriation for research and development. The United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand did the same. In all four nations the central role of market force economics was dominant. Canada, however, changed course when Prime Minister Mulroney went through a Damascus road conversion at the beginning of 1988 and announced that an additional $Can1.3 billion would be made available over the next five years for centres of excellence, convened a national conference on science and technology and set up a science committee of Cabinet which he chairs.

The achievement of the Hawke Government in restructuring the Australian economy has been enormous. Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, deserves great credit for initiating massive changes in the motor vehicle industry, steel, shipbuilding, chemicals, plastics, and textiles, clothing and footwear industries. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Treasurer (Mr Keating) have laid the foundation for a far stronger, more modern economy. Our economy is now globally oriented. We are now exporting more technologically based products than ever before-motor vehicles to Europe and Japan, specialised steels to the United States, optical fibres to Sweden, and even fetta cheese to Greece. We are no longer aiming to satisfy domestic demand only and sheltering behind tariff walls. Our rate of job creation is by far the highest proportionally in the OECD, with the highest participation rate in our history.

However, the trade figures are a continuing problem. A very high proportion of our deficit is in high technology goods, the sophisticated imports-computers, office equipment, cameras, watches, television sets, compact disc players, scientific instruments, aircraft, robots and production goods. In regard to the proportion of the value of imports over exports in brain based goods we are not doing well; we are tail end Charlies. It is a matter of great concern that so much of industry has been content to buy its research off the shelf overseas, often ignoring the excellent capacity offered by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and other research institutions in Australia.

We have had a bad record in rejecting or failing to understand the significance of local innovation. Our pioneering work on computers in the late 1950s was rejected by sound, sensible, practical men with their feet on the ground in Canberra who said that computing had no economic future. They, or their non-apostolic successors, also rejected our pioneering work on second generation transistors which they thought was an interesting laboratory phenomenon but which would never replace the valve. It happened again with Dr David Warren's `black box' flight recorder, with our space capability and with colour copying machines. Could the same thing happen now? Indeed it could.

Even at a time of acute Budget stringency, there are great achievements in Australian science. Wonderful achievements are being made such as CSIRO's gene-shears, work on superconducting, the `fast Fourier transform' chip, which I will mention in a minute, and the work on an influenza vaccine and on an extraordinary new diagnostic tool-the polymerize chain reaction. That illustrates a central problem which was not resolved by the contribution of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran). He said on the one hand that we ought to be re-enforcing our investment in areas where we are already doing well. I can see that in a sense that is quite an attractive view, but the problem for Australia is that there is an extraordinary degree of imbalance between the contribution made to exports by what is in world terms a declining share of world trade and our very poor performance in the fastest growing area of world trade.

One of the great turning points in economic history, as Paul Kennedy pointed out in his book The Rise and Fall of Great Powers, was the year 1957. That was the year in which for the first time total world exports of commodities were exceeded by the total world export value of manufactured goods. It never happened before, and since 1957 the gap has widened. The difficulty is that Australia has never secured a significant toehold in the fastest growing area of world trade. We still have a very respectable performance in the declining sector of world trade. I have never said that we have to eliminate one area at the expense of the other. That would be madness. We have to do both.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a practical effect.

—I am glad the honourable member raised that point. In 1982-83, the last year of the previous Government, the number of professional staff in CSIRO directly engaged in rural research was 713. What would the honourable member for Gippsland think about the 1987-88 figure? Would he think it would be more or less? Would he like to lay money on it? Do I hear an answer?
—More.

—The answer is more. The figure is 778. The proportion has gone from 29 per cent of the professional staff to 32 per cent. Does the honourable member for Gippsland see that as a catastrophic blow? Does he see that the whole area is collapsing, that the whole thing is on its knees? I do not think so. It is true that if we look at the total estimate of CSIRO staff, both professional and non-professional, we will see that there has been a change. I concede that. In 1982-83 the proportion was 40 per cent of the total. Would the honourable member for Gippsland care to hazard an informed estimate as to what the percentage is this year? I concede that it is not 40 per cent. What does he think it would be? Does he think it would be less than 30?
—What is this-a quiz show?

—I am just trying to test whether the honourable member has any idea what he is talking about. I think the answer is quite clear. He really does not have any idea of the quantity. The number has declined from 40 per cent of the total to 39 per cent of the total. As I said, the number of professionals has gone up but the total staff numbers in that area have deteriorated by one per cent. There is no doubt that CSIRO has gone through a period of extraordinary financial stringency. We all recognise that; it is having to do more things with less.

SPEECH.PARA: The other part that I thought was odd about the comments of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) was that he kept extolling the need to take the long view, the idea that we ought to be doing things. He was very critical of what he called the `sunrise industries', a term we have not used for quite some years-

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I know, absolutely right. We are looking at the areas such as the gene-shears and the fast Fourier transform device. This will take some years and will require not a minor contribution from industry but a massive contribution. More than anything else we need to encourage industry to develop that very long term view. When I was in the United States in August I was struck by something said by the Vice-President of DuPont.
—On no, not again!
—It is worth repeating.
—For the tenth time?

—It takes up the point that the honourable member made and perhaps puts it a bit more clearly than he is capable of doing. The Vice-President said that in his view the problem was that there were only six corporations in the US with a time horizon of 30 years. He thought that there were more than 40 in Japan. In Australia, the sad reality is that there are none. We are not yet developing the industrial infrastructure for the twenty-first century.

SPEECH.PARA: I have something here from CSIRO which I think a great achievement. It is the `fast Fourier transform' chip, which has 167,000 different components in it and is absolutely at the leading edge of technology. I think it could make a fundamental contribution to Australia's role in the world instrumentation industry. It is an area that is growing very fast and it is estimated that by 1995, worldwide, it will be a $300 billion industry and we have to have a good share of that. The CSIRO is doing that although it has been extraordinarily difficult for it. However, I think that the situation will be much better than it has been before. We have problems in credibility, adequacy, morale and recruitment. The group of officials, appointed by the Prime Minister in October to examine and make recommendations about our scientific potential, will report in December. This is the best news for science for a long time. It has nothing to do with the reports of the Australian Science and Technology Council; they were simply organisational.

The cutting back of expenditure to exhibit fiscal discipline and promote closer interaction with industry was a worthwhile objective but it depended on a very fast response time from industry which did not come or did not come in time. Because industry failed to invest in the way that Swedish, Dutch and Swiss corporations invested our core capacity has been weakened. If we are to be able to create and sustain a research base for the new industries for the twenty-first century, we have to do far more. Again, the burden cannot all be placed on the taxpayer. Industry must do more but I concede that we may have been giving contradictory signals. The stick theory has its limitations. It seemed to industry that we were saying, `We have to weaken CSIRO's capacity to strengthen its performance'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I found it somewhat interesting to listen to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) giving an erudite exposition of the position that he regularly gives, but he has failed to address the issue. All he has done is blame industry, blame the bureaucracy, blame the Liberal Party of Australia but not blame himself-there is nothing wrong with him, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business. He has tried to blind us with science. It is all right to refer to particular figures and it is all right to say that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) numbers in a particular division have gone up and then cloud the issue by referring to the numbers of professional staff as against those who are not professional. The growth has not been in professional staff, it has been elsewhere; so those numbers bear much closer scrutiny. I am surprised that the Minister comes in here and uses those types of figures in the way that he has.

SPEECH.PARA: An interesting point was alluded to by the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) when he first opened this debate, admittedly the first debate on science for a long time. It is ironic that he alluded to the fact that today, 23 November 1988, we are arguing about science, and this evening for the first time in Australia's history we will have a demonstration from more than 500 scientists.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not the first demonstration.

—It is all right to say that it is not a demonstration, but they are gathering to exhibit concern. Where are they doing it? They are doing it in one of the premier bicentennial gifts to this nation, funded primarily by the Japanese Government, and Japan has the fastest growing economy. I will quote some figures shortly about what is happening to science in Australia. What is going to happen tonight? We are having the opening of a national science centre, preceded by a national demonstration of concern about science. It will send a signal to the world that we are not serious about science. It will send a signal to this nation that we are not serious about science. All the Minister can do is say, `But it is industry's fault. It is the bureaucracy's fault. It is the Liberal Party's fault'. It is no-one's fault but the Government's. The Government was elected to lead and it is not leading.

SPEECH.PARA: The demonstration tonight will be a peaceful one. `Demonstration' may not be the correct word. For a long time most scientists have suffered in silence. Those who have articulated the problems and needs, not only of science but of the nation, have been largely ignored by their political masters. Now scientists are increasingly putting the pressure on government to take notice of the plight of science in this country, hence the gathering, the demonstration, which is unprecendented in Australia.

Honourable members should consider the following: Australia's position in research and development spending has dropped to 16 in a list of 22 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries by any measure. That is accepted. Australia ranks alongside economies such as New Zealand and Ireland and just higher than Iceland in commitment to research funding, government or private. Most industrialised nations are now spending more on research and development. The gap between Australia and its major econonmic competitors is becoming a chasm. The Minister has pointed to a 21.6 per cent drop in Government spending on science between 1983 and 1988. I maintain, as I have done in this chamber before, that it is higher than that. Let us have a closer look at some of those figures. I quote from the submission by the CSIRO to the IDC:

The world's strongest economy, Japan, has boosted its R& from 0.84% of GDP in 1955 to 3.19% in 1987, so becoming the first country in the world to top 3%. Australia's R& level as a proportion of GDP has only just regained that of 20 years ago.
We have been going backwards at an accelerated rate during the term of the Hawke Government. It concludes:
In Australia, we are mortgaging this future by reducing the level of longer term research as we pursue more immediate economic returns from our research.

As I have said many a time, science is all about preparing today for tomorrow. What this Government is doing with its science policies is sacrificing tomorrow in pursuit of short term gains that may or may not be there. It is all right to say that we have a high-tech need for communication equipment. We do-$10 billion by the 1990s. But let us not ignore those areas in Australia that have added greatly to our value as an exporting nation-minerals and agriculture. That is the point the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) was making. By walking away and reducing funding-proportionately funding in these areas has been reduced over the last five years-we have ignored the areas of environmental funding, soil degradation, water purity, the greenhouse effect and the ozone layer. They are the areas of significant interest to Australia and its future. They are the areas we ought to be concentrating on. The Government has moved the research budget away from those areas in pursuit of what might be important-I do not doubt that-but is it of fundamental importance? When we have competing priorities, where is the Government going to put the funds? It has to put them where the country most needs them and can best use them, so that we can get the long term benefit. What I am saying and what the Opposition is saying is that the funds have been misdirected away from where our true, long term interests lie.

When we have a closer look at what is happening to our economy we see that there are weaknesses. Only 20 per cent of our exports are manufactured. Our trade imbalance in high technology and manufactured goods continues to grow alarmingly. Trade ratios show an inverse relationship to the level of technology. Too many of our primary-based industry exports have little value added. Less than 5 per cent of our export income is generated from technology products involving a significant intellectual input, compared with 60 per cent for Japan. The result is that Australia's national debt per head of population is exceeded only by those of Mexico and Brazil, and today Australia ranks about eighteenth in per capita income terms. A century ago we had perhaps the highest living standard in the world.

Many times I have called for a recognition of science. Until now the other side of the Parliament has shown no interest in science. It is all right for the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business to stand up and say that we have shown no interest. We have certainly tried; but, other than the Minister, not one Government member has ever spoken in any meaningful way about science and where the funds ought to go. The Government has taken away from the Minister the responsibility for science. It has been spread to the seven winds of the bureaucracy. The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) now possibly has more input into science than the Minister for Science has. The same is true for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button). The Analytical Laboratories, which tests foods imported into this country, is now under the responsibility of the Minister for Administrative Services. Unbelievable!

Productivity levels, the levels of exports and imports, the current account deficit, all ultimately impact on the living standards of average Australians. The science community has finally got rid of its wimp tag. It has stood up and told us of the importance of the link between a strong support for science and the economy, that by ignoring science we are accelerating the economic decline of this country. Let me read the first paragraph of the submission by the CSIRO, which was leaked to us the day it was released, about what it believes is important to science:

CSIRO's research is essential to the success of the Government's strategies for improving the international competitiveness of all industry sectors. This support is important both to Australia's traditional industries and to the task of fostering new industries to broaden the country's export base. CSIRO provides the best practical mechanism to order priorities and focus research so that Australia can derive the greatest competitive advantage from its intellectual wealth.

The submission goes on to talk about CSIRO's appropriation funding declining significantly over the past five years. It also makes the point that the 1988 OECD report on science and technology policy disagrees with governments that believe their expenditure on research can be reduced by encouraging industry to support research in public institutions. As a nation we ignore that advice at our peril. What I fear is that this Parliament is ignoring that type of advice. For too long we have stood back and hoped that things would be all right. They will not be.

I say to the Minister in conclusion: the poet Bailey said that we live in deeds, not years. Longevity in this place, whilst admirable for the stamina it takes, is not the measure of achievement. If, after some 20 years in public life, we can show that Barry Jones has presided over the demise of science in this country it will be a tragedy for him because we know of his personal commitment. But more importantly, it will be a tragedy for our nation. We in this place will be gone before we suffer the consequences of the folly of the policies the Minister's Government is now pursuing. Unless the Government does more, this nation will be a lot poorer. Science is important. It is about preparing today for tomorrow. Woe betide any government of any political persuasion that chooses to ignore that fact.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing that has been demonstrated in this debate so far is that, even though the points of view of honourable members on both sides of the House are somewhat different, there is an obvious concern for the development of science and for the future of science in Australia. Much of the public concern expressed about the situation facing Australian science has focused on the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. CSIRO is Australia's premier scientific research organisation, carrying out about 15 per cent of all Australian research and development. A few years ago, before industry's research and development performance improved, CSIRO was undertaking about 20 per cent of the research and development in this country-as much as the whole of the private sector and about as much as the universities were carrying out in the natural sciences.

SPEECH.PARA: CSIRO has a justifiable and enviable reputation internationally for the quality of its scientific research. Since its establishment as the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research in 1926, it has made an enormous contribution to Australia's well-being, especially through the research support it has provided to the agricultural and mining industries, traditionally and still the mainstays of our export earnings.

The dramatic changes in the world economy this decade-its increasing competitiveness and its increasing emphasis on technology-based goods and services-have led all industrial nations to examine closely the structure of their research and development systems with the aim of streamlining them and making them more efficient and effective so that they gain the maximum industrial benefit from the research and development they perform. Given its dominant position in Australian research and development, it is not surprising that the Hawke Government paid early attention to the potential for CSIRO to make an even greater contribution to the nation and, in particular, to assist in the restructuring of Australian manufacturing industry by enhancing its international competitiveness through technological innovation.

Since coming to power, the Government has made profound changes to the organisation. In 1985 the Government instructed the Australian Science and Technology Council to examine CSIRO's role as the first part of a wide-ranging investigation of all Australian research and development. The most significant outcome of that inquiry was the decision by the Government to replace the CSIRO executive in 1986 with a larger board headed by a part time chairman to strengthen the external policy direction of the organisation. That has to be understood. The organisation is not inward-looking. It is now outward-looking. It is concerned with the planning of Australian science for the long term.

Under the direction of the board, CSIRO has now been completely restructured into six institutes that reflect the broad industry and community sectors, and research divisions that reflect specific industries within these sectors. These changes have strengthened relationships with the users or potential users of CSIRO research; concentrated research into fewer, larger programs; and enhanced the transfer of research results to industry and other users for the economic and social well-being of Australia. CSIRO is also strengthening its management systems, including the management and evaluation of research projects, both in terms of market potential and scientific and technological merit. Every member of this House, no matter how churlish some comments might be, would give full credit to the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) for the work he has done in providing the political leadership in this regard.

The intention behind these management changes is to maximise the flexibility and responsiveness of the research divisions, while still retaining a level of overall direction of CSIRO's research according to national priorities and objectives. The changes have already resulted in significant shifts in the distribution of CSIRO's resources. Research for the manufacturing and information industries has been substantially increased in accordance with the Government's policy of making these sectors more internationally competitive. Contrary to the concerns expressed by the rural sector, CSIRO's overall rural research has not fallen, although it is true that this is because industry funding from this sector has increased in recent years. That is to be commended. The joint relationship between the two sectors is precisely what this Government is aiming at in the restructuring of Australian industry-ensuring that, where possible, Australian industry takes up a larger share of the responsibility for research. That is something which I am sure honourable members on the other side of the House will applaud.

The effect of the changes to CSIRO is also apparent from a range of commercial indices. The number of provisional patents taken out by CSIRO has quadrupled from 42 in 1984-85 to 172 in 1987-88. The number of commercial opinions provided to CSIRO by Sirotech, the commercial company set up in 1984, has increased from 130 in the first year to over 350. The value of sponsored research undertaken by CSIRO for Australian companies has climbed from $4.3m in 1983-84 to $16.5m in 1987-88. CSIRO has also entered into some 16 equity investments, worth over $20m, during this period.

Farmer organisations sometimes argue that the research emphasis should remain on the primary sector, where Australia possesses natural comparative advantages. I have considerable sympathy for the rural sector's point of view in terms of its continuing need for research support and for the continuing great contribution it makes to this country's economy. Farmers appreciate, perhaps more than any other group in Australia, the value and necessity of research to their industrial success. We should be maintaining and even increasing the level of research support for the rural sector. In fact, the Government has substantially increased its contribution to the rural industry research funds which are based on industry levies matched dollar for dollar by the Federal Government. The farmer bodies are wrong to suggest that we should not be undertaking more research in the manufacturing sector. I am sure the honourable member for Bass would agree. Global economic trends demand that we improve the competitiveness of this sector in terms of its capacity both to capture export markets and to replace imports-a major source of our trade imbalance. I am sure we are nodding in agreement. For example, Australia has a trade imbalance in information technology of almost $4 billion per annum. If this trend continues it will reach $10 billion in five years' time-unless we can manufacture a far greater proportion of our requirements. That is one of the points that the Minister was making when he demonstrated that device that CSIRO has developed.

We can do it. Let me give the example of our medical and scientific instruments industry. Whilst it is small, it is growing rapidly, with most of its growth coming from exports. Its growth and its export intensity-the ratio of exports to domestic production-is about twice that of the manufacturing sector in general. Production has grown from $360m in 1980-81 to about $1 billion last financial year. In other words, it now compares favourably with some of our agricultural industries. It is in this direction that we should be focusing our attention-the benefits of the scientific research which has been undertaken, a targeted research, a more disciplined research. It exemplifies the way Australian manufacturing needs to go. It is technology-based and skill-based; it is integrated with the international market; and it shows a real entrepreneurial flair. It is, incidentally, an industry founded on CSIRO research-the invention of the atomic absorption spectrometer-and one to which the Organisation has since made an enormous contribution.

However, decades of sheltered existence have left Australian secondary industry ill-equipped to meet the challenges posed by the rapid deregulation of the Australian economy, and the consequent need for major restructuring. Whilst industry's research and development has increased in recent years, stimulated by the 150 per cent tax concession and other Government initiatives, its initial effort remains poor by international standards. Australia ranks about sixteenth out of 22 Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries in total research and development. It ranks about nineteenth in terms of the percentage of its research and development funding.

We have to give clearer, more affirmative signals to the CSIRO, to the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, to the Australian Institute of Marine Science, to the research community generally, and to industry itself, that we see our scientific capacity as being critical to our future. The Hawke Government has restructured our economy in many ways. I believe that we are entering into a period of vision in which we will face the future with greater understanding and greater confidence.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON TRANSPORT, COMMUNICATIONS AND INFRASTRUCTURE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, I present the Committee's third report on proposals for variation to the plan of layout of the city of Canberra and its environs.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This report is the third report prepared by the Joint Subcommittee on Variations to the Plan of Layout of the City of Canberra and its Environs and covers Variation 1988/4. Variation 1988/4 contains two proposals to vary the city plan: one to rectify the encroachment of a driveway onto Commonwealth land in Bruce; the other to provide for an access road for a residential development in Isaacs. Although the proposals were only gazetted on 14 October 1988, the Australian Capital Territory Administration asked that we look at these proposals quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Capital Development Commission (NCDC), following public consultation, received an objection to the variation. The Joint Subcommittee held a public hearing on the variation on last Tuesday, 15 November 1988. A number of issues were raised at the public hearing. In relation to the driveway encroachment in Bruce, it was pointed out to the Joint Subcommittee that the house on the block concerned was prominent and the siting and the design of it did not blend in with the topography. Special building conditions were imposed on houses in the Bruce South area. However, these conditions were not so well enforced in the later stages of the development and, therefore, this house is at the lower end of the acceptability range. Further, there were changes to the development plan which took in the hill reserve behind the Bruce South development. Residents were neither consulted nor informed of the changes to the nature and fire trail, nor were they consulted on the construction of a pedestrian access in the gully.

The Isaacs proposal provides for an access road to enable development of standard residential blocks by the Housing Industry Association. The briefing notes provided to the Joint Subcommittee on this proposal by the NCDC and the ACT Administration were misleading. The notes indicated that the access road was to be constructed when in fact it had already been built. The Committee is concerned that developers should not seek approval from the Joint Subcommittee for gazettals which are of a retrospective nature.

An administrative process which allows such a situation to occur is clearly inadequate and this causes us serious concern about how future private sector development will proceed. The current procedure, which enables private developers to pre-empt the parliamentary approval process, must be revised.

The Joint Subcommittee has approved the two proposals in Variation 1988/4, as the Bruce proposal is a minor road addition and the access road in Isaacs is the only logical means of subdividing the block. In so doing, the Committee expresses its concern that the NCDC did not ensure compliance with the building conditions in all instances in the Bruce South development and that there was no public consultation following changes to the development plan, which takes in the hill reserve.

The Committee is also concerned that the ACT Administration allowed construction of the access road in Isaacs to proceed when there was still uncertainty about its status. Seeking retrospective approval for a variation to the road plan of Canberra makes a mockery of the parliamentary review procedure. In future, any project for which there is even a slight possibility of the inclusion of a public road should be sent to the Joint Parliamentary Subcommittee for approval as early as possible in the planning process. Otherwise, the private sector land development process will simply become a means for avoiding public scrutiny of Canberra's development.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the legislation before the House on social security and the legislation governing the payment of pensions to veterans. The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill implement a number of decisions announced in the Budget in August this year. I wish to concentrate my contribution today in two areas-on the question of rent assistance and on the definition of `income' for the social security incomes test.

SPEECH.PARA: At present, pensioners receive up to $15 a week in rent assistance and those receiving sickness benefits or unemployment benefits receive up to $10 a week in rent assistance. In December 1989 people receiving sickness or unemployment benefits will also be able to receive $15 a week, an increase of $5 a week, bringing rent assistance paid to beneficiaries into line with rent assistance paid to pensioners. For the first time there will be parity between those receiving pensions and those receiving benefits. That makes sense and I commend it.

The second alteration to rent assistance is even more important. It provides for the payment of additional rent assistance to those families renting privately who have children. In June 1990 the Government will provide a supplement of $5 a week for families who rent privately and who have one or two children, and a supplement of $10 a week for those with three or more children. That is something I commend. A family in which the main breadwinner is unemployed and where there are three children today receives $15 a week in rent assistance in addition to the base rate of pension; in June 1990 that will be increased to $30 a week in rent assistance, an increase of 100 per cent. That is to be commended. Some people have suggested that the more assistance the Government provides to the unemployed or those in need, the greater the disincentive for those people to return to the work force. We should remember that these changes apply not only to unemployment and sickness benefits but also to the family allowance supplement (FAS) scheme. By increasing the amount of the FAS that is provided to people who rent privately in line with the rent assistance paid to those who receive pensions and benefits, we are ensuring that we are not building more poverty traps into the social security system. We are trying to ensure that those people receive every possible incentive to improve themselves and return to the work force without their losing some support in this area.

The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe), in his second reading speech, made an important comment, of which I wish to remind the House, on the definition of income. The Minister said that it is a cornerstone of our country's social security system that there be a fair means test. He made clear that the Government would undertake to act to counter any devices or schemes designed to circumvent the income test for pension and benefit eligibility. That is something I support. To assist me in my contribution and for the benefit of honourable members, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. This chart makes clear that at present under the income test people can still receive the full pension and earn up to $40 a week in non-pension income if they are single or $70 a week if they are married. Of course, similar limits are provided under the assets test. The important thing we must remember is that 73 per cent of pensioners receive the full base rate of pension because their income and assets are less than the relevant limits. Many people say, `What we need is a pension for everyone, no matter what their assets, no matter what their income, because people have paid taxes all their lives'. That might sound attractive at first glance, but let us consider who benefits if every person over 65 receives a pension. The 73 per cent of pensioners who already receive the top rate of pension would not get one cent extra if we provided everyone with the pension no matter what their assets or income. Those who would gain are those who have already provided for their retirement through superannuation, who have received large lump sums or who have large amounts invested. I believe it is fair that those people should be asked to provide for their own retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: One example that comes to mind is the Hon. Sir James Killen, former member of this House, now an eminent barrister appearing before a certain inquiry in Queensland. He retired from this House with a substantial pension and I am sure that, given his skill and legal expertise, he is also earning a considerable amount of money as a barrister in Queensland. Why should James Killen receive an age pension? I suggest to those in the grey power movement and other organisations who say that all people should get a pension because they have paid their taxes that James Killen has paid his taxes but he should not receive an age pension. That would be ridiculous. It would be ridiculous for someone in his financial circumstances or any retired politician to receive a pension because he has paid taxes during his life. I remind the House of that.

Of course, there are other cases. For example, constituents who came to my office early this week had retired with a substantial lump sum, which has been invested. Those people do not expect to receive a pension, because they had generous superannuation in their working lives. They knew that when they retired they would invest the lump sum and that the interest earnings on the lump sum would provide for their retirement. They do not expect to bludge on the community and get an age pension. Sometimes I become a bit concerned about people who have large sums of money, hundreds of thousands of dollars, and who believe it is their right to invest those sums in special, complex arrangements so that they can get a full pension on top of their interest earnings and other substantial investment income. I think that is wrong, and I am pleased that the Minister is tightening the loopholes. I am pleased he has agreed that these changes will not be retrospective and that, if people make investment decisions under certain rules, the rules will not be changed halfway through the life of the investment. That is something I commend.
In the few minutes remaining to me I wish to comment on the amendment moved by the shadow Minister for Social security, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), part of which states:
. . . the House condemns the Government for the confusion it has caused to pensioners.

Having sat through debates in this chamber when members of the Opposition sought to inflame fear in the community about the assets test, I wonder who is to blame for causing fear in the pensioner community? I recall that in the last Parliament one member of the Opposition suggested that under the assets test pensioners would have the gold in their teeth valued, that they should be worried about how many gold fillings they had. I leave it to the people of Australia to judge who has sought to create needless fear in our community.

I was interested to read the Opposition's new policy on social security, and I will quote from one report of Mr Connolly's launching of his Party's policy earlier this week. The Sydney Morning Herald stated:

Those retiring at 55 or over could take benefits as a lump sum. But the portion of the lump sum which received the benefit of tax concessions-mainly employer contributions-would be taken into account in assessing eligibility for the pension at 65 or later. This would be done through a deemed income provision-calculating the amount which the subsidised part of the lump sum would have earned if retained until 65 or later retirement.

There we have it, a return to the bad old days of deemed income, something which we saw in Australia in 1976. For those who do not remember, I remind the House that in 1976 we did not have something called the assets test; we had legislation that provided that, if someone had $100,000 in a cheque account that earned no income, the Department of Social Security could deem that investment to have a certain rate of return and, therefore, that would be income. That system was much tighter and tougher on pensioners than is the assets test that this Government has legislated to implement. The 1976 provisions for assuming deemed income on assets were much tougher than the assets test that now applies, yet the Opposition wishes to go back to the bad old days of 1976. I think that would be a backward step. It is right that under the current legislation the Government considers the actual income, whether a capital gain, dividend interest or some other form of income. Yet the Opposition wishes to go back to the bad old days of deemed earnings, whether or not people really earned the money. I commend the Minister, who is at the table, for his continuing reforms, especially in rent assistance and in tightening the definition of income. I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall take a few minutes to comment on the various contributions made in the cognate debate which covered the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill and which included a large number of particular measures. I think the honourable members who have contributed to the debate have focused around the issue of market-linked investments which has been a matter of some public controversy, but they have also referred very positively, particularly the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) on the opposite side of the House and members on this side of the House, to measures such as the jobs, education and training scheme for sole parents-JET-and also to the new start program which is designed to assist long term unemployed people to return to the work force.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of comments have also been made with respect to a significent set of reforms which are included in this legislative package concerning rent assistance. We have reached the point in terms of this proposed legislation where rent assistance will be effectively available across different classes of pensioners and beneficiaries at similar levels and in this proposed legislation the Government also introduces a family component into rent assistance in that the rate will now vary according to the presence of children. That is a significant reform because we know within the context of research that has been done on the issue of poverty that after housing costs poverty is particularly prevalent amongst low income families which are in private rental accommodation. While the process of rent reform has taken some time, within this Bill we have significant rent reform assistance indeed.

I will take the couple of minutes that remain to respond to the remarks made by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) and other honourable members, including the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), on the issue of market-linked investments. In government one does not have the luxury of avoiding choices. One has to recognise in government that resources are scarce and one has to ensure that if there is a policy, that that policy is operated fairly and consistently. The fact of the matter is that market-linked investments were a form of investment promoted by investment advisers for the purposes of circumventing the income test.

In a context in which we have pensions and benefits paid in Australia that are by no means generous by international standards, it is important that we provide assistance such as we are able to provide as fairly as possible. The Opposition, unfortunately, did jump on the bandwaggon and involve itself in an emotional campaign of opposing these changes that the Government has brought into effect to ensure that the income test would operate fairly. Indeed, the change was somewhat minimal in the sense, as the honourable member on the opposite side of the table has pointed out, that account has been taken of capital growth in respect of market-linked investments since at least 1980 and the difference essentially is that the Government has taken account in terms of this Bill on an accruals rather than on a realisation basis. So a great deal of the confusion in the community might have been avoided if people involved in that emotional campaign had made that point crystal clear.

The Government has been successful in terms of both economic and social policy because it has had the capacity to make these decisions. That is why we are able to talk about 8 per cent real increases in pensions; it is why the Government is able to talk about the achievement of the 25 per cent goal; it is why the Government has been able to ease income tests; and it is why the Government has been able to increase by 40 per cent real expenditure on non-health services for the aged. Under the stewardship of this Government the aged people in this country have been given a very great priority but we have had to make decisions to ensure that the 73 per cent of pensions on the full rate of pension are the people who have been given the greatest priority.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 8, page 7 omit proposed subsection (4c) substitute the following sub-sections:

I understand that the Government supports the amendment. The Opposition moved this amendment because it believes it is important to restrict the disclosure of information, the powers for which are contained in the Act which should effectively enable the Department of Social Security to allow information on individuals to be distributed-to use the words of the Bill-`in the public interest'. We believe this is a somewhat nebulous term and it should be more specifically defined in the Bill or in the regulations under the Bill. It is important that the Minister set guidelines as to what the public interest is, and it is also important that Parliament should have the capacity to see those guidelines and also to disallow them. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

I am more than happy to undertake that the guidelines I will issue will take a similarly strict view. The amendment of the Opposition would make these guidelines disallowable and ensure that they do not come into force until Parliament has an opportunity to consider them, and the Government accepts the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 11, page 14, line 20, omit ``(3) (b)'', substitute ``(4) (b)''.
(2) Clause 11, page 16, line 16, omit proposed paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:

(3) Clause 11, page 17, lines 21 to 31, omit proposed subsection (2), substitute the following subsection:

Amendments (1), (2) and (4) correct drafting errors. Amendment (3) relates to the widowed person's allowance which is payable for either 12 weeks after the death of the recipient's spouse, or when the pensioner was pregnant at the time of death of the spouse for the duration of the pregnancy. Amendment (5) relates to the employment entry payment of $100 payable when long term beneficiaries have obtained a job and amendment (5) makes it clear that the payment could be made prior to the actual commencement of employment provided that there was a firm agreement to commence employment; and that the claim for the payment must be lodged within 28 days of the commencement of employment. DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.
Amendment (by Mr Connolly) proposed:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for the confusion it has caused to pensioners and those planning their retirement incomes by its many changes to the income test during its period in office and for its failure to create a level playing field for pensioners in respect of their investments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government rejects the amendment for the reasons I indicated in the earlier debate. It is never an easy task to preserve a social security system that is effectively targeted on the basis of need to ensure that people who have access to income make use of that income to support themselves where that option is open to them. It involves making quite difficult choices. The Government makes no apology for trying to ensure that the income test we have, such as it is, operates as fairly as possible. I think it is unfortunate that it was not made clear in the debate, as it should have been, that capital growth has always been taken account of, certainly in the term of the previous Government as well as in the term of this Government, but on a realisation rather than an accruals basis. In the judgments that have been made about equity, quite frequently we have found it very difficult to get the support of the Opposition. I think that reflects that the constituency they are concerned about is the top 25 per cent of aged people, not the vast majority of aged people who are on a full pension.
