DEBATE.TITLE: COPYRIGHT AMENDMENT BILL 1988[COGNATE BILL:CIRCUIT LAYOUTS BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
The the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with order of the day No. 5. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 and the Circuit Layouts Bill 1988. The Copyright Bill makes important changes to the Copyright Act 1968 and the law on copyright. I make these comments on behalf of the Opposition and note in particular the very careful analysis of these proposals undertaken by my colleague the very excellent shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown).

SPEECH.PARA: The changes are to put a royalty on blank recording tape used for home audio taping; to protect performers from unauthorised recording or broacasting of their live performances; to enable educational institutions to video tape television programs; to streamline the existing licences to educational institutions to photocopy, and institutions assisting the handicapped to make talking books and other useful materials; to clarify protection for industrial articles; and to streamline the statutory licence for record manufacture. The Opposition supports both Bills but will move several amendments to the Copyright Amendment Bill.

I wish to make some remarks on the proposal to impose royalty on blank audio tapes. The Bill proposes a royalty to be paid on blank recording tapes or cassettes. The Liberal and National parties support this proposal. It has in fact been canvassed by our arts policy, which provides specifically that we support the introduction of royalty payments on blank tapes used for sound recording.

Home taping from the radio, records and other tapes, is widespread, and that is widely acknowledged. It is a breach of copyright but difficult to prevent. The result is that those whose creative endeavours are put into a work, such as composers, as well as publishing houses and recording companies, are having their work reproduced without any compensation. After extensive consultation this Bill sets out a scheme to accommodate the concerns of both consumers and copyright owners. Under the scheme consumers will be able to continue home taping of recordings, directly or off air, for private and domestic use without infringement of copyright. In return, owners of copyright in the recordings will receive a royalty levied on the blank recording tape.

The royalty on audio tapes with a playing time of longer than 30 minutes will be calculated by reference to the length of the playing time. The royalty will be determined by the Copyright Tribunal. The Attorney-General's Department expects the royalty to be between 20c and 50c per tape, and the industry association expects the royalty to be $1.

The royalty will be paid by the first sellers-in other words, the importers and manufacturers of blank tapes. Copyright owners will then be paid a share of the royalties if they are members of the single authorised collecting society to which the royalties will be paid. Copyright owners who will benefit from the scheme will include composers, lyricists, authors, music publishing companies and record producers. The recording companies have agreed that a substantial share of the royalty will be passed on to performers under their contracts. This would ordinarily amount to about one-third of the royalties collected by the society. The scheme does not apply to video taping of television programs and video tapes.

Fifteen per cent of the royalty will go to those in the Australian music industry most in need of assistance, and part will go to the Australian Contemporary Music Development Company, recently established by the Government to foster Australian contemporary music and young and up-and-coming Australian musicians. That reference to fostering Australian music is not a reference to the well known product in Melbourne-the Foster's brand. The royalty will be payable on all blank tapes ordinarily used for recording audio materials including digital audio tapes. Institutional users-for example, schools and institutions for the blind-will be able to purchase tapes free from the royalty. Individuals or organisations who buy tapes but do not intend to use them to record copyright material will be able to obtain a refund of the royalty on making a statutory declaration that the tape will not be used to record a copyright sound recording.

The royalty will be collected for the benefit of only owners of Australian audio copyright materials and owners of audio copyright materials in countries which have similar schemes providing comparable benefits to Australian owners. This will ensure that Australia adheres to the spirit of the relevant international copyright conventions without providing a windfall to foreign owners in countries which have not addressed the problem of home taping. The Opposition, however, has some concerns about the practical implications of the scheme described in the Bill. For this reason we propose an amendment to the motion for the second reading which has been circulated in the name of the honourable member for Menzies.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition also has some more detailed amendments which have been circulated. Due to the fact that the Government is applying the gag, I seek your assistance and direction on that, Mr Deputy Speaker, as time may not be provided to us to move those important amendments. In that case I would either seek leave to incorporate them in Hansard or at the appropriate time move that the amendments be circulated.
—This will have to be done at the committee stage.

—We will see whether time permits. However, we propose at least to ensure that the amendments are in the Hansard as a record. I foreshadow that the Opposition will take these matters further in the other place when the opportunity arises. These amendments define the prescribed organisations which will not have to pay the royalty and require the Attorney-General to table the annual report on the operation of the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter dealt with by the Bill is performers' protection. At the moment performers such as actors, singers, musicians, puppeteers, dancers and variety artists have little legal conrol over illegal recording of their performances. Technological developments have created effective means of unauthorised commercial use of performances, namely recording, broadcasting and diffusion by cable. The Copyright Law Review Committee has recommended that performers be given protection from this commercial exploitation of their live performances. The Government's solution is to give to the performers not copyright protection, that is property rights, but a civil right of action to sue for damages for any unauthorised recording or broadcast of their performances. The new provisions will provide performers with a greater bargaining power when negotiating contracts. That is consistent with the arts policy that I referred to previously and which we have released.

The Bill also provides for a series of criminal offences for illegal recording of performances, punishable by fine, and for copying recordings or trading in them, punishable by fine or imprisonment. There are many offences too numerous to set out here but the maximum fine is $250,000 and the maximum term of imprisonment is five years. We support this proposal.

The third matter dealt with is copying. The Bill establishes several statutory licensing schemes to provide a mechanism whereby the interests of copyright owners will be balanced against the interests of educators who need to copy educational material in the most efficient manner possible. The Bill deals with statutory licences for audiovisual copying by educational institutions. The Bill will establish a statutory licensing scheme which will allow educational institutions and institutions assisting handicapped persons to make copies of television programs in return for payment to copyright owners. Off-air copying of television programs by educational institutions is an infringement of copyright unless permission is obtained from copyright owners. To avoid breaching copyright, separate permission is required with respect to the script, sound recording, background music, film and broadcast. The scheme introduced by the Bill follows recommendations in the 1986 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on audiovisual copying by educational institutions. Under the licence proposed by the Bill, educational institutions will be able to make off-air copies of television programs for educational purposes, and copyright owners will be able to claim payment for the copying of their material through a single collecting society approved by the Attorney-General. The payment will be as agreed between the parties or, in the absence of agreement, as decided by the Copyright Tribunal. Institutions will be able to elect to pay for the right to copy either by an amount per student or according to actual material copied based on full record keeping.

The Bill also revises the existing educational photocopying scheme. The present scheme is cumbersome and costly because of its complex record keeping requirements. The revised scheme is based largely on voluntary agreements already entered into between Copyright Agencies Ltd-the authors' and publishers' collecting society-and a substantial number of educational institutions throughout Australia. Cooperation in this regard has largely been achieved by abandoning the record keeping requirements of the present scheme under which payments are required for actual copying. Instead, payment is being made on the basis of agreed sampling schemes whereby estimates can be made of the amount of copying and payment made on a per student basis. The amendments facilitate these voluntary agreements and ensure that they can operate effectively under the legislation. The revised photocopying scheme will adopt the flexibility of the television copying scheme. It applies to literary, academic, musical, and artistic works. There will be a collecting society representative of copyright owners. Schools may elect to pay for copying on a per student basis or, as at present, by full record keeping with records sent to the collecting society. This will avoid copyright owners having to carry out time consuming and costly record inspections at the thousands of schools spread around the country.

Criminal penalties in the Act relating to record keeping have been the subject of concern. They have substantially been omitted from the revised scheme. The revised scheme in practice will be much simpler to comply with. It will also substantially improve the means of remunerating copyright owners for the use of their copyright materials. The Bill also includes new provisions which will streamline copying by institutions assisting handicapped readers and intellectually handicapped persons. We therefore support this proposal.

The next matter dealt with is copyright designs interaction. The second reading speech says that the Bill will update the protection given to artistic works that are either registered as designs under the Designs Act 1906 or are used industrially without registration. For many reasons industrial designs are not appropriate to be protected by the Copyright Act. There is at present a lot of overlap which is leading to confusion. In 1973 the Designs Law Review Committee report on the law relating to designs recommended that these designs be protected under the Designs Act and not under the Copyright Act. The Bill amends the Copyright Act to this effect. However, we are very concerned at the way the Bill is drafted. Its results will be that some designs will not be protected either by copyright or by the Designs Act. For this reason we have proposed an amendment which is amendment (1) of the amendments which are circulated. Its effect is to delay the commencement ofthis part of the Copyright Act amendments until the Designs Act has been amended so that corresponding designs, as they are called, can be registered under the Designs Act. This is a sensible solution to the problem identified by the honourable member for Menzies. I hope that the Government will give it the proper and full consideration and the eventual support it deserves.

The Copyright Act presently contains a statutory licence for the manufacture of recordings of musical works. The relevant provisions specify conditions upon which the licence operates and a mechanism for changing the rate of royalty payable to music copyright owners. This mechanism requires the Attorney-General to determine that the current rate is inequitable. Then there is an inquiry and report by the Copyright Tribunal. The Government considers that the preliminary requirement for the Attorney-General to determine the current royalty rate to be inequitable is an undesirable and inappropriate role for government. Accordingly, the Copyright Amendment Bill will introduce a simplified scheme based solely on a Copyright Tribunal determination of the rate in the absence of agreement which will be consistent with other schemes in the Act, for example, the compulsory licence for broadcasting music. Such a scheme has industry support and will remove unnecessary government involvement in the industry. We support this change to the law.

The Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 is to protect computer chip layouts from unfair copying. The Australian computer chip industry is small but is important and growing. Australian chips, for example, make bionic ears and heart pacemakers work. They detect messages from space and from the ocean, and convert sunlight to power. Our specialised products have found valuable markets overseas. The Circuit Layouts Bill repeals inappropriate and uncertain Copyright Act and Designs Act protection, and provides protection for original chip layouts along the lines of the laws passed recently in the United States, Japan, Scandinavia and European Community countries. The Bill is consistent with the World Intellectual Property Organisations draft Treaty on the Protection of Intellectual Property in respect of integrated circuits. Enactment of the Circuit Layouts Bill is wanted by the industry and is needed to obtain permanent protection for Australian circuit layouts in the United States and European markets. The Bill provides modified copyright protection. It gives the creator of an original chip layout the exclusive rights to copy the layout, to make a chip in accordance with the layout and to make the first commercial exploitation of the layout of a chip made in accordance with it. The right arises automatically. It is a simple low cost form of protection involving no red tape and is welcomed by the industry. The Bill provides civil claims as the remedy for infringement. We therefore support this Bill. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that:
(1) upon the commencement of Part vc of the Bill, or as soon thereafter as may be practicable, the Government should refer the following matters to the Copyright Tribunal for inquiry and report:
(a) the extent to which audio tapes purchased in Australia are purchased with the intention of using them to record copyright material and non-copyright material respectively;
(b) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part vc of the Bill is the most practical means of implementing a blank tape royalty scheme;

(c) whether the blank tape royalty scheme set out in Part vc of the Bill is the most effective blank tape royalty scheme for providing compensation to Australian performers whose material is recorded domestically on audio tapes in breach of copyright;

(d) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzs (3) of the Bill for a statutory declaration entitling the purchaser of a blank audio tape to a refund of the royality paid on that tape is the most effective means of effecting a refund or waiver of the royalty when the tape is not used for recording copyright material; and

(e) whether the proposal in proposed subsection 135zzu (3) for the rules of the collecting society to make provision for the distribution of amounts collected by it is adequate to ensure that a reasonable proportion of the amounts collected is passed on or distributed to those whose own work has contributed to the making of the eligible sound recording or eligible work; and
(2) upon receipt of the report of the Copyright Tribunal on these matters, the Government should propose such amendments to the Copyright Act as may be necessary or desirable'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I start I will comment on the remarks about Fosters, made by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). I know that he is very worried because John Elliott is looking closely at his electorate. I think Mr Elliott has a house down at Portsea in the honourable member's electorate, so he should keep an eye on what he is doing down there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Circuit Layouts Bill 1988 is legislation that replaces the operation of the Designs Act and the Copyright Act for protecting computer chips. The development of integrated services has moved at an exponential rate. In the middle of 1970 I attended the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology or, as it was known then, Melbourne Tech. I went to night school and studied electronics. In those days I constructed valve operated equipment and we heard about a new device called a transistor. I can still remember my curiosity and the excitement when I started work on the first piece of transistorised office equipment. It had been imported from Germany and I looked with fascination at how these small transistors were replacing valves. Even then I could see the possibilities for transistors and printed circuits, as they were called at the time. These transistors and printed circuits were the forerunners of the integrated circuits that we take for granted today-one of the things that we rely on more and more to assist us in our daily lives.

I used to design and manufacture office equipment and I also designed and manufactured printed circuit boards. Many times I etched copper boards with ferric chloride, burning away the copper to make printed circuits. My circuits were very simple. They used only a few transistors and electronic components. They worked quite effectively but today what I used to put on a board of about two inches by three inches would all fit into a quarter of an inch chip. Today's integrated circuits are light years ahead of what I was making just 10 years ago. Let me give honourable members an example of what I mean. In yesterday's paper there was a story about Austek Microsystems, an Adelaide-based company. It said:

Austek Microsystems last week launched the digital signal processor industry's lowest-price Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) device on to world markets. The company's A41102 frequency domain processor (FDP) microchip, developed as part of the Australia Telescope project, is designed to process large amounts of information at high speed.
In the past, Fast Fourier Transforms have had to be performed on large, expensive mainframe computers.
The idea of producing a chip capable of performing Fast Fourier Transforms was conceived by Dr John O'Sullivan of the CSIRO's Division of Radiophysics.
Work began on the chip in 1985 and its design was completed by late 1986, when Austek signed a licence agreement with the CSIRO and began a joint manufacturing project.
It has wide applications in medicine, industry and defence.
The 8mm by 9mm chip contains 167,000 transistors and, operating at 40MHz, uses about one watt of power per second.

To give honourable members an idea of the dimensions of eight millimetres by nine millimetres-if they are as old as I am they will go back to inches, yards et cetera-it is about five-sixteenths of an inch and on that chip there are 167,000 transistors. The article went on to say:
The world market for digital signalling processing devices . . . is $700,000 a year at present and is expected to grow to $2 billion by 1992.
And 1992 is not that far off. It is expected to grow from $700,000 a year at present to $2 billion in four years. The article goes on:
The chips can be purchased in a 132-pin ceramic casing for $150 each.

That is 167,000 transistors for $150. I remember paying up to $8 for one commonly used, PNP transistor just a few years ago. It has been stated that if the price of cars had dropped as much as the price of transistors one could buy a Rolls Royce for approximately 25 cents.

Australia has some brilliant circuit designers, scientists and engineers. In my own electorate we have a firm called Signalling Technology. It has designed the program for the manufacture of a copyright chip of its own. It is manufactured overseas because no-one here in Australia can make such a chip. I trust that in the future Australia will have people with the skills to manufacture these and other integrated circuits. However, we have a small capacity in the design and manufacture of chips. Designing and manufacturing chips in Australia requires a huge capital outlay for the equipment. The particular chip that Signalling Technology makes decodes telecommunications signals and makes certain that a clear signal is received. It is the most advanced chip in the world and it is exported to the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Europe and Japan. Five years ago this company started with four people; it now employs 40. This is an outstanding record for a high tech company based in the Dunkley electorate-a company playing its part in Australia's future.

This Bill is important for chip designers; it is important for Australian industry. The chip industry is still in its infancy and has a huge potential. We are in a unique position in Australia to make certain that we share in this growth potential. I predict that in the next century chips will be an indispensible part of the quality of life of the people of this planet. We must make certain that our designers and our engineers have the protection that is needed so that in manufacturing and designing their chips they can ensure that the work that they put into it is justly rewarded. I commend this Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak only briefly on the Circuit Layouts Bill because, while there are many interesting aspects of it, there is one particular area which I wish to address. It is to do with the area of the visual arts-of paintings, drawings and sculptures. The copyright in a painting resides with the artist except where the copyright is specifically handed over. For instance, if you, Mr Deputy Speaker, were to commission a painting it could well be part of the contract that the copyright would go to you, but under normal circumstances the copyright for visual works of art resides with the artist. That is all right as far as it goes and it is subject to the usual copyright law pertaining to music, songs, musical performances on record or tape, books and poetry, but I believe it does not go far enough. I would just like to advance the proposition to the House that we should be looking at providing some sort of copyright on resale for the painters and the sculptors of this country. The copyright obtained by visual artists from prints of their work published in collections of books is very limited. The real money comes when we have somebody like Dobell or Nolan or when one of our struggling younger artists of today sells for $200 a painting which in 10 years time might sell for $10,000. In another five years it might sell for $50,000 and in another five or 10 years time on top of that it could well sell for a quarter of a million dollars. I believe there is a basic lack of fairness in the fact that the artist and the estate of the artist cannot benefit from the profit of those sales.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see in this country-undoubtedly I would like to see it progress right around the world-equity and fairness extended to our painters and sculptors. As I said, the person who buys the painting for $200 certainly gives the artist some benefit at the time. But we are all aware of artists who have struggled. Their wives and their families have struggled. They have had a very hard time. The artists we think of starving in a garret exist. It is very hard for them when they are young. I believe there is a fair case for consideration to be given to those people getting some benefit from there sale of their intellectual creation.

I do not want to burden the House with a great deal of detail on this matter. I suggest to the House that at some time in the future when this matter is being examined again we give some serious consideration to extending copyright to the resale of intellectual visual creations so that our artists will benefit just as the estate of John Lennon will continue to receive royalties until 50 years after his death. There would be a great deal of sympathetic response from the community of Australia if this were to be introduced. I commend the idea to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also am pleased that the Copyright Amendment Bill 1988 is before us. I think it has resolved very well an essential dilemma. It rewards creative efforts and, at the same time, it does a good deal to enable organisations running educational programs and programs for the print handicapped to get access to programs which are educational and entertaining at a cost which is within their reach.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of points which I would like to put on the record. Although the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is not in the House, he may do me the courtesy of sending me a written response. The technical and further education (TAFE) network has established the TAFE National Video Resource Centre (TNVRC). It provides to educational institutions in New Zealand and Australia at a minimal cost videotaped copies of programs which are suitable to support TAFE courses. As part of the normal operations, or at the request of a provider, that network negotiates with the copyright owner or agent for video copying rights of suitable titles. It then endeavours to obtain rights for all TAFE providers in Australia at no cost or at a substantially reduced fee compared with the normal commercial rate. After completing an agreement for rights a master copy is obtained and copies are produced and held in stock so that orders can be processed promptly, usually the same day. The catalogue, which lists in excess of 2,500 titles, is distributed on microfiche to over 800 users twice yearly. A comprehensive computer program is used for the TNVRC records system, including control of the many complex copyright agreements, production of the catalogue and maintenance of stock records.

This operation began in a very small way in 1978. Ten years later it now distributes more than 6,000 programs each year. It has an annual turnover in excess of $450,000. Yearly savings to the TAFE system from discounted copyright fees are at least $400,000. In many instances colleges can now buy a copy of a program from the TNVRC for the equivalent of one hire fee, thus saving any future hire and freight costs as well as having the program readily available. The combination of the multiple videotape copying equipment and the computer system enables the service to operate very efficiently with three staff. The important point is that under that excellent service educational programs are provided after negotiation with the maker of the program or the holder of the copyright. It is therefore of great benefit or our educational institutions, which are always finding that their funds have been cut and which are being asked to be more efficient.

The provisions in this Bill concerning off-air recording of television broadcasts may not help that service to do all that it now wants to do. In particular, there is an endeavour to provide copies of educational programs to schools which are disadvantaged by remoteness, lack of staff or facilities. At least one TAFE audiovisual department of which I know was intending to record the material off-air and from the master copy produce subsequent copies for distribution. Of course, it intended to pay a royalty for each copy which was distributed. It would negotiate the royalty.

The Bill allows only copying of broadcasts, not the production of subsequent copies from a master. If copying from a master can be arranged under the Bill then the services I have referred to could go ahead. As I understand it-and I ask the Attorney-General to perhaps write to me about this-that is not possible. If it is not possible, I ask him whether he would consider an amendment in the Senate to make it possible. It is an important service to children, in particular, in remote areas or areas which are particularly short of facilities.

As with photocopying, the scheme will be feasible only if the charges for copies are within the financial constraints of the educational system. A reasonable fee needs to be set for the TNVRC master. Small schools must be able to afford and purchase a copy of the program. I hope that the Attorney-General will look at that. That particular information came from the Moorabbin College of TAFE, which is in my electorate, but I know it applies to TAFE colleges elsewhere.

In conclusion, I make the observation that the amendments which the Opposition are advancing are aimed at improving a number of deficiencies in an otherwise commendable Bill. In particular, there are administrative problems about the question of making a statutory declaration to say that one does not intend to use a tape for the purposes covered by the Bill but for strictly private purposes. I think that is a difficult way to administer it to avoid the royalty on the tape. One wonders whether one needs to avoid the royalty on the tape as most tapes these days are used to record material that is the subject of copyright. The administrative problems relating to photocopying could prove to be considerable. I would ask the Attorney-General to consider changes to that when he monitors the operation of the legislation. I suspect that educational institutions will find the copyright administration quite burdensome. It will therefore interfere with their capacity to do the job that they want to do by actually taping material of this kind.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 31 August, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The next Bill to be debated this afternoon under the gag is the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill 1988. The debate is being gagged because, quite frankly, the Government would have trouble organising a Sunday picnic. It is a sad indictment of this Government that it cannot control the parliamentary agenda and that business is conducted in this House in such a way that significant issues such as occupational health and safety, which affect tens of thousands, if not hundreds of thousands, of workers in this country cannot be fully debated. It is an indication both of the priority the Government gives this issue and of the embarrassment the Government must feel when anybody refers to the issue of occupational health and safety.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long line of Opposition members who would take the opportunity to speak today on this Bill but for the fact that the Government has gagged debate on it. There is a list of speakers who have a real interest and a genuine concern about this significant issue. The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), the chairman of the Opposition's industrial relations committee, will be speaking in this debate. I think it is fair to say that that committee is one of the best party committees operating in the Federal Parliament. Other members of the committee are also finding their speaking time cut short by this Government's inability to organise the agenda so that honourable members can speak on these significant issues.

We wanted to have the opportunity in debate to canvass a wider range of issues, including the more general issue of regulation and red tape. I will move a second reading amendment at the conclusion of my remarks so as to highlight a significant aspect which the question of occupational health and safety impinges upon. This debate would have given us an opportunity to canvass, in particular, the policy recently released by the Opposition, which talks about an effective deregulation policy as being one of the essential features of our economic policy to reduce government intervention in the lives of private citizens and to cut down business costs. That policy represents a first. It sees a commitment to have responsibility for a comprehensive deregulation program at senior ministerial level. It will see existing regulations systematically reviewed and unnecessary regulations repealed. A deregulation agenda will be set and an annual report required so that under no circumstances can this issue slip away from us. It is a significant issue and it is time it was faced. The policy also sees a commitment to introduce sunset clauses to regulations, a major step in the right direction. However, as I say, the opportunity to discuss those important matters in detail has been denied by the Government's inability to give us adequate time.

The Government's handling of the occupational health and safety issue has been a litany of broken promises, nothing but waste and ministerial incompetence. They have been the hallmarks of Labor's attitude to occupational health and safety. The whole policy area is a shambles. Wherever one looks one sees a complete shambles. It is an absolute indictment of this Government's ability to administer anything. If there is any doubt about the importance of the issue, we should go back to November 1983, five years ago. This Government has been in office for nearly six years. Let us see what the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis), said at the time:
One of the most important and far reaching policy proposals to which the Labor Government is committed is our national strategy on occupational health and safety.

Those were his words. Other members have called them historic. As I said, the honourable member for Corangamite will contribute to the debate today. He said some very strong things about the importance of this legislation and the Government's initiatives. He described the Commission back in 1985. He said it was a milestone. It is a milestone no longer. It is a millstone around the Government's neck in its abject failure to get on with the job. The Minister, when talking in 1984 about the significance of occupational health and safety, said:
The need to develop our national occupational health and safety strategy is an essential component of the non-wage aspects of the prices and incomes accord.

That is a high priority for any Labor member when the Minister says, `Look, we have done a deal with the ACTU. It is a high priority for us'. I shall be very interested to hear the contribution of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) this afternoon. It should be a contribution in which he eats his words, because in 1985 he said that this proposal would see a reduction in costs. This is the economic rationalist coming out of the woodwork on the other side. He holds the carrot out in front and says that this will reduce costs. I invite him to come into the chamber and give honourable members a few case studies to illustrate that Labor has in fact produced some real benefits for somebody. It will be absolutely staggering if there are any examples whatsoever. The whole thing has been a disaster.

These problems are not just trotted out by the Opposition in some sort of rhetorical point scoring. In 1987, in recognition of the problems, the Government appointed Mr Bernie McKay to review the whole operation. Mr McKay has undertaken a fairly wide analysis of what has been going on with the Government's policy. As generous as he might be with the use of his words, what he says is no compliment to this Government. Mr McKay refers to the overall lack of progress. He says that progress has been unsatisfactory. Let us look at his exact words on page 11 of his report:
Progress has not been adequate in the following areas-

It is a long list: a heightening of public awareness of occupational health and safety matters-not been adequate. The development of strategies and priorities-not been adequate. Coordination of occupational health and safety, particularly amongst the States and with other Commonwealth departments-not adequate. These were the critical priorities of the Government, as stated back in 1983, and here we are, at the end of 1987, early in 1988-`not adequate'. The development of standards-not up to scratch, Mr Minister. The development of the Institute-not adequate. The development of information and education programs-the Minister did not score on that either. Research activities-he says, `The lack of adequate progress in the first three of the above is of particular concern'. And so it should be. It is an indictment of this Government if ever there was.

It is no wonder that we have seen press reports saying that the Commission was in a state of total crisis. No one has known what to do. We had the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, both getting stuck into the Commission. We had the absurdity of the manual handling draft code. There were over 500 objections to it. The whole country came down on top of the Commission. It was just crazy. They were talking about implementing a national code or scheme which would prohibit people lifting weights, weights the average of which would in fact be less than what the ordinary shopper would carry out of Safeways on a Saturday morning.

Finally, the Minister sends a note down to the Commission saying that he is concerned about the expansive scope and directions of its activities. He is the Minister responsible and even he is getting stuck into what is happening with this Commission. He generally wanted to know what it was doing.

I think a lot of people have wanted to know what it was doing. Even in the last week or so there has been the situation arising out of the Senate's Estimates committee. There is an officer who lives in Canberra and the Government, at taxpayer's expense, is flying him back and forth from Canberra to Sydney. It is time someone took a deep breath and had a close look at what has been going on with this Commission. We have a bureaucracy four times as large as was intended. The staff morale in the place has been basically at zero for the whole time since its inception. We have a top heavy administration in terms of the staffing arrangement of it and high levels of absenteeism. All of these things have been features, unfortunately, of this Commission. In this report Mr McKay steps carefully around the problems, but he makes it absolutely crystal clear that there has been an inadequate level of progress-to use his words-during the Commission's early years.

In respect of this Bill, I would say that the recommendation of the McKay report does at least suggest some effort to deal with the problems. In particular, there is to be less emphasis on tripartism, a greater role for the States, separation of the functions of the chairman and the chief executive officer, and a greater focus on the Commission's priority issues and determinants of the Commission's work programs and organisational operations. I see that these recommendations have the support of the Confederation of Australian Industry, the ACTU and State governments. I think also that the appointment of Dr Emmett as acting chairman has generally been welcomed and that does provide the opportunity for the Commission to establish some sort of credibility. But after 5 1/2 years it says very little for the Government that the best assessment of the Commission is that it has an opportunity to start again and make a clean start.

We will, therefore, not be opposing the Bill. We believe that there is a big need for a real shake-up in the administration of the Commission. The adoption of some of the recommendations of the McKay report in this legislative package is not unreasonable. It therefore has our support.

In concluding, I want to put the issue in a broader context. I do so noting that it is necessary for me to curtail my remarks so that some of my colleagues can at least make some contribution. But I want to put it in the broader context of the accord and where the Government is going with its so-called wages policy. The line has been that the Government says to the community at large, `Look, you go along with cuts in real wages. You make your sacrifice and in return-in compensation, if you like-we and the ACTU leadership will obtain some real non-wage benefits for you. So in return for the cuts in real wages, do not worry; we have something else in the bag that we will hand out to you, some extra benefits'. The benefits to be found in that social contract are a long list of things which the Government thinks are adequate recompense for its policies which have led to a decline in real wages. By `decline' I mean $56 a week, because that is the figure that represents how much worse off people are since this Government has been in office.

One of the cornerstones of this accord is that near the top of the list of those non-wage benefits is the statement that the Government will take steps to ensure a safer workplace for the workers of this country. That is the offer. It is an offer which has not been met by any capacity on the part of the Government to deliver what it said it would deliver. The reality is that there is nothing there. It is just a mirage. It is just talk. It is all about the ACTU leadership talking of what it might offer. However, when we scratch the surface and look for the result, we see that there is nothing. I simply say to the Government that it is about time it looked at its overall policies because, in return for the $56 a week cut there are no real benefits for employees. There is a mirage based upon a deal that provides no benefits for employees.

I commend the Bill to the House. It has our support but, if it is an indication of the Government's capacity to honour its promises in an area central to its deal with the ACTU, this Government stands condemned. It is a real indictment of ministerial incompetence, a failure to apply the Government's own priorities to an area that the Government has stated is of critical importance to the conduct of our economy and the circumstances of workers in this country. I move:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not opposing the provisions of the Bill which seeks inter alia to streamline the administration of the Commission, the House notes the Government's failure to implement effective procedures to reduce the burden of excessive regulations on industry'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this Government came to office there was little or no activity in the occupational health and safety field and all the cries of the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) about `not enough' deliberately ignore the lack of significant occupational health and safety actions by the Federal Government prior to 1983. This was despite the fact that in Australia there was an unacceptably high incidence of work related death and injury, which is not being tolerated in other Western countries. Each year in Australia about 550 men and women die as the result of work related accident or disease. That figure is high, an incidence of 77 per million. If we look at the 1984 International Labour Organisation yearbook of labour statistics, we find that there are 22 per million such deaths in Sweden, 24 in the United Kingdom, 20 in Japan and 37 in the United States compared with 77 in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This record must be changed. It is caused by a range of factors, not the least of which is the fact that there was no motivation by management of employees or by Government of management or employees, and little enthusiasm by employees for safety measures. Thus, there was hearing impairment on a wide scale. There was enthusiasm within the work force for toughness and recklessness rather than safety measures, and people actually refused to take the required precautions in, say, the sawmilling industry, the mining industry or a range of other industries.

Perhaps one of the most dangerous areas of activity in Australia is farming. That is rather surprising, because there are opportunities to ensure safety on farms, yet it is in that area that many accidents occur. Even today there are very real problems on farms. Therefore, the work that is being undertaken is important and in that light I compliment the Government in particular for its support of an application in the south-east region of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory to educate people involved in rural pursuits. There is education through shows, education through surveys and the publication of results and education through motivation of people so that they can adopt the necessary attitude to develop on-farm safety.

I have seen accidents involving tractors. People have taken chances that perhaps they should not have taken while driving on slopes. I have seen accidents involving fertiliser distribution by air. Just recently a death occurred in the Bombala-Delegate area. I have seen cutters and combs flying from shearing handpieces, and they could easily cause injury, particularly eye injury. I have seen accidents where people have not been properly protected in handling livestock. On one occasion a goat leapt to a height of six feet and collected me on the head. My head is still in good order; nevertheless that was a dangerous situation and a bad accident could have occurred. One sees accidents involving the handling of cattle, horses and sheep.

In that light, it is particularly pleasing that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) have announced the formation of a special ministerial advisory group on farm safety following the Farmsafe 88 conference last July. That conference considered rural health and safety and was initiated by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. It arose from concern about the high incidence of injury, such as back injury, hearing loss, accidental injury relating to machinery use or animal handling, injury caused by chemcial toxicity, another important area of concern, and skin cancer. A constant theme of Farmsafe 88 was the need for a greater focus on skills training for practising farmers and farm workers and on broader community education on the hazards of farm work. It is good to see that Dr Peter McCullagh and his team in this region have honed in on that aspect and their displays, education programs and work with schools, organisations and show societies to make clear the need for farm safety has been of great benefit in this region. In other words, they have looked at the need for broader community education on the hazards of farm work.

I point out that 17 per cent of all deaths in the employed labour force occur on farms, despite the fact that the rural work force constitutes only 4 per cent of the total labour force. Additionally, the injury rate of farm workers is appreciably higher than the industry average. Farm workers have historically been trained on the job, but Farmsafe 88 suggested that there are better ways to train. The ministerial advisory group that was announced will be chaired and serviced by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission-Worksafe Australia-in coordination with the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. The organisations that have combined in this great effort are the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Workers Union, the Rural Training Council of Australia, the Country Women's Association of Australia, the Victorian Department of Agriculture and Rural Affairs, the Western Australian Department of Labour, Works and Services, and Dr Lyn Clark of the Agricultural Health Unit at Moree District Hospital. These organisations have been invited to join the advisory group, which will be asked to report back by the end of March next year on three important issues; first, the priority occupational health and safety areas in rural safety in the light of the Farmsafe 88 recommendations. It will report on the effective implementation of those recommendations and the way in which they should be evaluated. That should occur one year after the presentation of the Farmsafe 88 report.

The recommendations emphasise the importance of improving farm safety and work skills through education rather than legislation. They also call for consultation with rural workers to ensure that the programs suit regional issues and take account of existing local organisations, people and family units. In other words, it recommends use of knowledge on the ground-the people and the links on the grounds-to get the message across. The recommendations also call for the provision of standards and codes of practice on farm safety and the reassessment of present legislation, whether State or Federal, in consultation with the user groups affected, so that we achieve more national uniformity in our approach. The recommendations also calls for the recognition of the key role played by rural women in encouraging farm safety and the initiation of research and evaluation into rural occupation health and safety issues and safety programs. So the role that is being played by the industry bodies in encouraging the implementation of the recommendations will be absolutely vital.

Six areas have been identified for the implementation of the preventive strategies that have been developed by the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. They are six very important areas-occupational health, occupational back pain, noise induced hearing loss, chemicals in the workplace, occupational skin disorders, mechanical equipment injury and occupational cancer. They deal with the concerns brought forward by Farmsafe 88.

This Bill has the full support of a wide range of organisations, the organisations I have mentioned as well as the Confederation of Australian Industry, the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the representatives of all governments-State and Territory-on the National Commission. A number of items were dealt with which separate the functions of the chairperson of the National Commission from those of the chief executive officer, provide greater flexibility in the composition of committees involved and facilitate and consolidate the significant improvements in the national commission's operation. The legislation reflects in a practical way the Government's continuing commitment to improving the safety and quality of working life in Australia.

There is nothing that I enjoy more than being involved in the presentation of safety awards at a saw mill, being involved in the Government's new training schemes where safety is an important ingredient. In shearing shed work now people are being trained to be rouseabouts, through proper training schemes. I believe we will gain a great benefit from that, particularly in the area of farm and farm worker safety. It is with great pleasure that I support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to debate this National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill but before I move to the main body of my speech may I remark on the comments of the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow). Although I am sympathetic and supportive of the committees that he spoke about investigating farm safety both for farmers and employees, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was not mentioned in those endeavours. In fact, this bureaucratic organisation was allowing other groups to investigate farm safety, which is commendable. It is interesting, however, that the honourable member for Eden-Monaro in his remarks did not indicate the role of the Commission in coordinating these activities and giving grass roots support for the way in which the committees would operate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's centralised bureaucratic approach is confirmed with the introduction of the higher education White Paper which gives the Minister for Employment, Education and Training total control of higher education from Canberra. In the case of the National Occupational, Health and Safety Commission, this Canberra dominated bureaucratic approach has been followed to the letter. If the results of the Commission are any example to follow, higher education in Australia is in for a rough time over the next triennium.

In May 1985 I raised the issue of yet another quango being established to duplicate the activities of State governments. At that time I suggested that the new quango would mushroom and demand increasing amounts of funding and provide dubious benefits for workers and employers. Earlier this year the McKay inquiry confirmed my bleak and pessimistic predictions that the Commission would not be effective in solving the health and safety problems of Australian workers. The McKay report identified 34 ways in which the Commission could be improved. The first major criticism was that the structure, operation and organisation of the commission were in disarray. Secondly, the Commission had little impact in raising public awareness of health and safety issues throughout Australia. Thirdly, the very reason the Commission was set up-to coordinate the States and the Commonwealth in developing an overall strategy about health and safety issues-was seen to be a failure. The report recommended that the Commission had failed to develop standards, information and education programs and research activities that were part of its original charter.

It is a damning indictment on the Commission and the Government that such a statutory body should be criticised so harshly in its third year of operation. The Canberra Times, in an article of 11 October 1987 by Mr Jack Waterford, probed in greater detail the failings of the Commission. It said:

Three years after its establishment, it is said not only to have failed to meet its objectives of developing a national strategy for improving occupational health and safety, but to have become a floundering bureaucracy four times as large as it was ever intended, with appalling staff morale, high rates of absenteeism, sick leave and staff turnover, and with a very poor reputation out in the workplace.

The Canberra Times article goes on to quote a letter from members of staff which portrays the inadequacies of the Commission in precise and damning detail. The letter seems to be in accord with the findings of the McKay report. I quote from the letter:

A sense of hopelessness pervades the whole organisation . . . representatives of unions, employers and Governments, who participate in Worksafe's tripartite committees and working parties are seriously concerned with the Commission's poor record and reputation, its cumbersome administrative and committee procedures, its inefficiency and waste of financial and human resources, its lack of directions and strong leadership, its duplication of some state activities, and its failure to meet its statutory obligations.

That is some comment from the employees of that organisation! Currently the Commission has an annual budget of $18.4m for 1988-89. The average salary per employee across the Commission for 1987-88 was $32,729, which is high by Public Service standards. These figures provide an indication of the malaise facing the Commission. It evidences a highly paid bureaucracy at its worst with an emphasis on administration but a lack of capacity to deal with the real problem of developing a health and safety strategy for the whole of Australia. There is no doubt the research functions and coordinating role of the Commission are left wanting.

A Senate Estimates committee raised the issue of the Chairman's travel costs and arrangements. Mr T. Emmett, the Chairman, commuted to Sydney from Canberra for three or four days each week for a period of 21 months although that officer had been given a compulsory transfer. This gross expenditure, along with the problems of relocating the office from Canberra to Sydney over many months, added to the general bureaucratic confusion surrounding the Commission's activities. The Opposition accepts the Minister's suggestion that there should be a change in the role of the Chairman and Chief Executive which is compatible with commercial and organisational experience in other statutory bodies and in the private sector.

In an endeavour to get some runs on the board the Commission issued a draft code of handling in 1987. Reports suggest that some members of the Commission were unhappy that the draft code was released with undue haste. The consequent widespread criticism of the code confirmed their suspicions. On an earlier occasion I raised the impractical nature of this draft code and its impact on business throughout Australia. In August 1987 the Business Council of Australia stated its unequivocal opposition to the Commission's proposals on staff manual handling. The Business Council used evidence put forward by the Government's own Business Regulation Review Unit which indicated that it would cost industry at least $9 billion in capital costs for maximum value of $230m to implement such a proposal. The impractical nature of the draft code was made evident in that the code suggested that manual handling of 16-kilogram weights be restricted and that any item weighing more than 34 kilograms be banned from being lifted by any person, male or female. By this bureaucratic guideline Australian shearers would be prohibited from shearing Australia's 164,000,000 sheep. Maybe the Commission would allow shearers to shear lambs but not heavy full-wooled merinos weighing more than 34 kilograms. Since most sheep weigh between 50 and 70 kilograms, what would the Commission's research staff suggest in their manual code of handling for the sheep industry? Would the Commission also suggest that hard-working Australians be prohibited from lifting one dozen cans of Fosters because of its statutory weight limitations?

Let me turn now to the genuine concerns the Opposition has for workers' safety in the Australian workplace. There is no doubt that back injuries sustained by Australian workers in manual trades are a chronic and costly problem. Personally, I am very sympathetic to those members of the work force who have a bad back. On the other hand, it is a measure of serious concern that this ailment is used to exploit the various workers compensation schemes around Australia to the workers' advantage and the employers' disadvantage. Education and encouragement of sensible workplace practices will help alleviate this difficult problem facing the Australian work force. Likewise, sensible exercise programs incorporating spinal mobilisation could benefit the often mysterious bad back syndrome which plagues our manual work force.

Employers and employees have become aware of the deleterious impact of noise upon their hearing. The use of ear muffs in noisy environments such as airports, factories and forests and in the use of heavy machinery has helped to alleviate long term impairment of hearing. In the modern industrial world the use of chemicals in the workplace has provided greater hazards to workers in terms of their short term health and longer term lifestyle. Again, education and sensible work practices are important to ensure protection.

Occupational cancer has been identified as a major problem in the asbestos and coalmining industries. It is essential to bring about an increased awareness of the cancer-causing hazards in industry today and improve working conditions. Mechanical industries have been a problem since the Industrial Revolution and continue to be a major source of worker disability because of attitudinal problems by management and workers. Only when there is a genuine effort by both parties to ensure that safety is implemented in the workplace on a day by day, hour by hour basis can the rate of industrial accidents be reduced.

The Robens inquiry in England in 1972 confirmed this approach in bringing about a change of attitude and a degree of self-regulation in the workplace. The Robens report suggested that there should be a more unified and integrated system surrounding safety and health matters throughout England but that statutory change for change's sake would not bring about the desired result. The 1974 British Act requires every employer to ensure, so far as is reasonably practicable, the health, safety and welfare at work of all employees. All employers of five or more people must prepare a written statement of their policy, organisation and arrangements for ensuring health and safety at work and must inform their employees of the policy and of the arrangements for carrying it out. Health and safety regulations require serious accidents and dangerous occurrences to be reported to the Health and Safety Commission. In the United Kingdom this approach has helped to bring about a more positive attitude in the workplace to the health and safety of employees. No amount of legislative coercion will change human behaviour. Individual awareness in this difficult area must be encouraged further in Australia.

The extreme example of a statutory attempt to enforce safety and health require- ments upon employers was the Victorian Labor Government's legislation. This made it mandatory for union representation on the shop floor, with the power to provide an immediate cessation of work if the union official considered that a breach of the safety regulations had occurred. Fortunately, the more draconian sections of the Act were watered down and commonsense prevailed, so that industrial muscle could not be utilised under the umbrella of health and safety.

Whilst the objectives of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission are laudable, the functions of the Commission are duplicated in every State and the evidence indicates that the Commission's management performance is in very poor shape. The Opposition will look closely at the Commission and bring to bear a philosophic approach which will ensure a greater degree of health and safety education, a change of attitude and a reduction of yet another Canberra-based bureaucracy directing the lives of hardworking Australians in their daily tasks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised at the comments that have been made by members of the Opposition because most of their criticisms relate to a situation which the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill sets out to correct. It is true that some criticisms were made of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in its first couple of years, but the purpose of this Bill is to correct each of those mistakes. The previous Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), instituted the McKay review in November 1987 to review the effectiveness of the Commission. That review led to 34 recommendations, each of which either has been implemented or is now the subject of action. So the Opposition's criticisms are really out of date and redundant. It seems as though members of the Opposition are trying to find things on which to criticise the Government just for the sake of being oppositional rather than being constructive.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is important because it corrects some minor mistakes that were made in the early years of the Commission. It comes in in a situation of desperate need for effective action in the occupational health and safety area in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still?

—Still, indeed. I am very glad to see that the Opposition is supporting this Bill. It opposed the establishment of the Commission in the early days. It is a step forward for the Opposition now to be supporting these amendments because it suggests that, at long last, it has recognised that there is a high cost to industry from occupational disease and injury. In fact, it was estimated that in 1985-86 workers compensation payments cost the private sector about $3 billion and that at least another $3 billion per year was wasted through loss of production and other associated costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1985-86, over 300,000 new claims were made against Australia's workers' compensation systems. That is a deplorable situation. In fact, in that year about 500 people died as a result of occupation-related accidents or diseases. The most recent figures which are available to compare the Australian experience with that of other countries suggest that we have a much higher rate of deaths per million workers in Australia than do other countries. It is difficult to be sure that these figures are comparable but as orders of magnitude they are the best that are available at present. They show that there were 77 deaths per million workers in Australia in the mid-1980s. In the same period in the USA there were 41 deaths per million workers; in the UK, 24 deaths; in Sweden, 22 deaths; and in the Netherlands, 13. So in Australia the numbers of fatal injuries or disease-related deaths affected by work were two or three times the level in other countries. That is an absolutely appalling situation.

There are some industries in which those injuries occur more commonly than others. The coalmining industry is the most serious. In coal mining the rate of injury per 1,000 workers was 276 in 1985-86; in transport equipment manufacturing, 124; in construction, 121; and in food, beverage and tobacco processing, 106. They are the industries in which injuries are most common, but there are some occupation-related injuries or diseases in every industry. I well know from my own experience in the electorate of Fraser that the overuse syndrome has been a major problem. There are, therefore, enormous potential benefits to the whole of both the public and the private sectors from effective occupational health and safety standards and a reduction in occupational disease and injury. That is the purpose of the amendments to the Bill we are now debating.

One of the criticisms that was made a couple of years ago was that the Commission had not achieved very much up to that point. I would like to concentrate most of what I want to say on the level of achievement that has occurred, and there have been great achievements. It seems to me that one of the best qualities of the work of the Commission is that it is very systematic. Before this debate I took the time to go and visit the Commission. I spent a day talking with people, reviewing what they do, inspecting their laboratories and so on. I was very impressed by the high level of commitment but particularly by the systematic approach to the issues they are studying. One example of that is their identification of six major areas of occupational health and safety hazards. The six areas that they have identified as being the most dangerous in Australia are chemicals, occupational skin disorders, cancers, back injury, mechanical equipment safety, and noise-induced hearing loss. That has the ring of truth about it. I am quite sure that honourable members and others listening will reflect on their own experience of occupational disease or injury. Much of the incidence that we are aware of comes within one of those categories.

The Commission has taken major steps to approach each of those problems. I would like to list some of the achievements to date. It has set up standards and codes of practice in a number of very important areas. One of the first that it introduced was a code of practice on occupational overuse syndrome-what used to be called repetition strain injury (RSI). That code is a major element of a prevention and management strategy designed to counter the incidence of occupational overuse syndrome.

When I was first elected four years ago, one of the problems that more constituents came to me about than any other was RSI. Since that time a whole series of changes has been introduced within both the public and private sectors so as to reduce the danger of occupational overuse syndrome and to help treat and rehabilitate those who have had that disease. There have been major achievements. The number of people who are still suffering from occupational overuse syndrome is now much lower than it was three years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has nothing to do with the Commission.

—It has a lot to do with the Commission, because that Commission set up standards which have now been implemented in large parts of both the public and private sectors which have changed work practices, improved the quality of furniture and trained people better. The effect has been a sharp reduction in that occupational disease-a major achievement from the Commission's work.

SPEECH.PARA: Another code of practice which it has set up is for the safe removal of asbestos. It is a very topical piece of work to have achieved, because there is enormous concern in the community at present. Again, in my own electorate many people are frightened that asbestos insulation might have been installed in their houses. The Government has introduced a survey of every house in the Australian Capital Territory to assess how much asbestos was used as an insulation material and is going to organise its removal on a subsidised basis.

Another of the codes of practice established by the Commission is for the use of timber preservatives. Timber preservatives such as copper chrome arsenic, creosote and organic solvent based preservatives present potentially major health hazards to workers in timber preservation and outdoor industries. The code provides guidelines for the safe handling of timber preservatives and for preservative treated wood.

Finally, in this area of the Commission's achievements, it has established a national data set for compensation based statistics. One of the major problems is that we simply do not know enough about the extent of these problems. There has not so far been a standardised statistical collection about occupational injury or disease in Australia. Therefore, we are to some extent guessing the cost to industry from occupational disease and injury. One of the most important points in presenting persuasive material to the Opposition in order to try to get its support for these activities is to demonstrate authoritatively how extensive the problem is. That is one reason why this statistical collection has been introduced. But it is, of course, very important for the Commission to have thorough detailed statistics so that it knows on which areas it ought to concentrate.

The Commission has also introduced a whole range of other guidance notes. It has developed national prevention strategies for occupational back pain or occupational skin disorders. It has begun a chemical notification and assessment scheme. Cabinet approved the details of that in August this year. There are now draft standards and codes of practice in a large number of areas which have been released for public comment. One of the very effective aspects of the Commission's work is that it consults so widely. It has also put in place national preventative strategies in a whole series of other areas.

That does not end the effective work that it has been doing. It has concentrated a lot of its attention on professional education. A national institute was established and it now has undergraduate training programs, postgraduate education courses and short courses for operators in the field. That kind of training program is an essential part of ensuring that we gradually improve the safety and healthfulness of the environment in which people have to work. It also has a major research program which is starting to produce very useful results. It has instituted a research award scheme to encourage people in universities and in the private sector to do their own research.

I have touched only on some of the major achievements of the Commission. It has been very effective in the last few years. This Bill will increase that effectiveness and provide a sound legislative framework for the Commission to continue to operate in. I strongly support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking in this House yesterday on the Australian Sports Commission Bill, I concluded that the difficulties for sports administration in Australia over recent years had to be laid at the feet of this Labor Government for the badly conceived and hastily introduced management structure. I find myself tonight in almost identical circumstances in debating the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill 1988. Although the Opposition will not oppose the provisions of the Bill, my colleague the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) has foreshadowed an amendment which seeks to highlight the failings of the principal Act in not having remedied the excessive and often conflicting nature of the regulations presently imposed on Australian industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Peter Morris) will recognise the clemency being shown by the Opposition in pointing to this single, albeit vitally important, failure of the present legislation, for there is the most disturbing evidence that between the passage of the principal Act in May 1985 and the present time, Worksafe Australia-as the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission is commonly known-has not met its objectives and has been publicly referred to as a costly, bureaucratic failure.

The Bill before this House tonight aims to rectify some of those deficiencies, thereby putting the Commission onto a more soundly based management structure, and one which is more appropriately placed to address the Commission's objectives. Whether the legislation goes far enough to allow that to be achieved is something I will refer to a little later. As I mentioned in my opening remarks, I see a disturbing similarity between the necessity for this Bill and that for the Australian Sports Commission. Both comprise amending legislation, and apparently are necessary to remedy badly conceived management structures introduced by this Labor Government in 1985. The pressures on the Government at that time to achieve its many platform and electioneering promises are very understandable, but just as the fast track technique has produced its increasingly apparent problems in our immediate environment, its application in the areas of sports and occupational health management must cause a serious questioning of its use in other than projects where its suitability has a proven application. Its proponents point to the substantial cost savings it offers, but when one is looking at sports or occupational health administration, costs savings are not necessarily the hub around which management should be structured. The unsuitability of fast tracking is all too apparent in these instances, and more will be brought to the notice of this House as the passage of time reveals the inappropriateness of much of what has been structured and changed by this Government.

With hindsight the Minister for Industrial Relations should admit that the Government made a fundamental error in modelling the 1985 occupational health and safety legislation on the United Kingdom model, which was in turn taken directly from the recommendations of the United Kingdom Robens report of 1972. He will not, of course, since the political circumstances of 1985 were such that he preferred to describe his legislation as historic, pioneering and having its genesis in the much vaunted accord. Nevertheless, his legislation was taken directly from the United Kingdom model, and this was done for the simple reason that superficially, there were many similarities between occupational health and safety in the United Kingdom in the early 1970s and Australia a decade later. The British factory Acts had been created haphazardly over a century or more, and resulted in a highly industry specific, fragmented and piecemeal approach which had led to overregulation, administration complexity and inconsistencies, while still leaving a large proportion of the work force unprotected. Australia was in a similar situation in the early 1980s with over 130 Federal and State Acts and ordinances in force.

Very shortly after Worksafe Australia was officially introduced in 1986, unsatisfactory aspects of the organisation became apparent. These were accentuated by the relocation of the Commission to Sydney, and, dare I suggest it, the manner in which that relocation was managed.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the dinner break, the problems of the Commission were accentuated by the relocation to Sydney. I believe that far too much was expected of the Commission at that time and that this, when placed on an inappropriate organisation, reduced much of the Commission's effective capacity and its ability to address its priority objectives properly. Media criticism and informed criticism, mounting through 1986 and into 1987, finally forced the Government to acknowledge that serious problems existed. It approached the problems by appointing a former Secretary of the Commonwealth Department of Health, Mr Bernie McKay, to conduct a review of the Commission's activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The McKay report findings were released on 3 March this year and were critical of most aspects of the Commission's operations. The report recommended 34 ways in which the Commission could be improved, its most significant criticisms being an overall lack of progress in its first two years of operation, requiring immediate structural and organisational changes; inadequate progress in heightening public awareness of occupational health and safety matters and developing strategies and priorities; inadequate development of standards, information and education programs and research activities; communication problems between Worksafe Australia and the Minister and his Department; a rigid adherence to tripartite principles at all levels of activity; and the negative impact of a Public Service model organisation on its activities.

On 31 August this year the Minister introduced the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Bill 1988 into Parliament to reflect some, but not all, of the recommendations of the McKay report.
