The appropriateness of the Government's selectivity in implementing these recommendations will be determined only by the further passage of time, but the failure to act on two particular recommendations is a matter of great concern to me and the Opposition in general. These are recommendations Nos 7 and 21 which state, firstly, that expertise rather than tripartism should be the principal criterion by which membership of committees and working parties is derived and, secondly, that all existing committees and working parties be critically reviewed with a view to their abolition and retained only where no alternative arrangement is possible.

I believe that there is a well-based concern that the tripartite arrangement is not the most effective way to conduct the work of the committees and working parties, more so when that is coupled with membership from peak organisations. Having in mind the critical importance of the educative role of Worksafe Australia, it is not unreasonable to question the efficiency of such long lines of communication from the Commission to the people to whom occupational health and safety is really directed-the factory floor. It is an area of immense importance. It is an area where self-satisfaction cannot be lightly taken. I am sorry that previous Government speakers have suggested that things seem to be going so well. The McKay report highlights in a very clear and dramatic fashion some of those areas where real concern needs to be expressed. The Government has demonstrated once again that its earlier legislation was introduced in far too hasty a manner. This amending legislation will do something to deal with the problems, but certainly there is a great area of concern which the Opposition will be closely monitoring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill implements a number of necessary changes, as has been mentioned earlier in this debate, to the structure and operation of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission which assists government, employer and employee cooperation in matters of occupational health and safety. The Commission, which is better known as Worksafe Australia, is responsible for the development and implementation of national occupational health and safety policies and strategies. The Australian Labor Party Government takes occupational health and safety seriously. I do not doubt for a moment that some people on the other side of the House do as well, but the fact remains that it was not until a Labor Government came into this place that we saw some real action occurring in this area. The then Minister for Industrial Relations, the present Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) pointed out in his second reading speech that the interim Commission was appointed and that subsequently this Commission was set up in 1985. The review which was referred to by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) was conducted in 1987 by Mr Bernie McKay. It reinforced the need for the Commission to focus its resources on a number of key strategies. The review also recommended the separation of the functions of the chairperson and the chief executive officer, a recommendation which the Government has accepted and which hopefully will be passed into law, through this Bill which we are debating. The separation of these functions will enable more of a public relations role to be played by one of those officers.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also provides the Commission with a new function in relation to the evaluation of occupational hazards in workplaces, and enables the Commission to constitute committees comprising persons other than its members. So that in itself overcomes some of the problems raised by the honourable member for Warringah. Obviously, there are difficulties occasionally, with the tripartite nature of the Commission, but there is no need for that Commission to be bound unto its members; it can take expert advice as it requires.

When our Government came to office in 1983 Australia had an unacceptably high incidence of work related death and injury. I am sure that these statistics have been mentioned already in this debate tonight but they are so important they bear repetition. Each year 550 men and women die in a work force of seven million; this incident rate of 77 per million needs to be compared with an annual fatality rate per million workers of 22 in Sweden, 24 in the United Kingdom, 20 in Japan, and 37 in the United States. At that stage obviously we were doing something very wrong. Almost nothing was being done despite these figures in Australia at that time. As I said before, it was not until we came into government that something started being done in this area.

It is estimated that more than $6 billion a year is wasted in Australia through loss of production and associated costs arising from occupational injury and ill health. I have no doubt that it has been said before in the debate but it needs repeating that the occupational health and safety question is one which costs not only in dollars but also in human resources and grief, and no cost can be put on that.

The Labor Party believes that the Federal Government has a vital and crucial role to play in coordinating industrial health and safety activities and in ensuring that uniform standards are adopted around the nation even though regulation is not necessarily the answer. The Commission has an advisory role, not a coercive role. The statutory National Commission was set up in 1985, and it is a 17-member tripartite body comprising representatives of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, employers and trade unions. This Bill will increase membership of that Commission to 18 in order to accommodate the proposal to separate the functions of the chairperson from those of the chief executive officer. It is obviously important that both people are active members of the Commission and are on the Commission when it makes decisions.

The Commission has two operational arms: the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety, and the National Office which services the Commission. The Commission's training and education strategy has two major objectives, the first of which is to contribute to ensuring that all people whose decisions and actions affect the Australian workplace are equipped with the appropriate knowledge and expertise in occupational health and safety. It sounds very trite but we want the people who are making the decisions to know what is going on. The second objective is to coordinate the national development of high quality, cost effective training and education programs in occupational health and safety which meet the needs of the workplace and the community. As the honourable member for Warringah mentioned, the education of employers and employees is absolutely crucial to the success of any national occupational health and safety program. The people on the floor, so to speak, should have a heightened awareness of hazardous situations and they should learn how to eradicate those situations wherever possible.

As members of Parliament, as workers before we came here and even as workers here, we all understand that accidents occur every day and that many of them are preventable. Prevention is the key to overcoming this problem, as is awareness. In the old Parliament House I once had an avoidable accident when I foolishly stood on a chair while trying to use a facsimile machine. That is what happens when one is short and I am sure that you, Madam Speaker, are aware of these problems. We cannot always see or reach the equipment. At the time of my accident I was an employee. I was wearing high heels, which did not help, and I fell off the chair and broke my finger. My arm was put in a sling; I was unable to pursue my duties. I did a lot of other things, but I certainly could not do the duties that I was supposed to be doing at the time. I think that those sorts of things point to the idiocy of the placement of some of the equipment in our offices especially in the old building-not here as we have a bit more space-where machines were put in places which were very difficult to reach. Accidents can occur through foolishness, haste and misplacement of machinery. I certainly will not make that mistake again and I will encourage my staff not to do so.

In our occupation we also see repetitive strain injury because many of the staff of members of parliament and Public Service employees, such as Telecom Australia and Australia Post employees, have suffered from repetitive strain injury. It is a very serious injury which is costing Australia a great deal of money. It is not something that is in the mind but people must remember that it is very much stress related. It is also physiological. I have had a lot to do with it and I know that the people who have been subjected to that injury are now much more conscious of the requirement for ergonomic furniture. Also, employers are often much more conscious of the need for ergonomic furniture, appropriate rest breaks and not pressuring staff. All of that sort of thing seems so simple and yet does not happen. I am sure that the role of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, in its educational aspects, will overcome some of these difficulties and I also know that the Commonwealth employees' compensation legislation, which we passed not so long ago, will assist in this area by supervising particular departments to ensure that they actually carry out their role of, firstly, awareness and prevention and, secondly, appropriate rehabilitation, which is very important as well.

The research and scientific division of the Commission undertakes research, high level consultancy services and teaching across a wide range of disciplines. These include epidemiology and surveillance, occupational medicine, statistics, occupational hygiene and safety engineering, toxicology, occupational psychology, ergonomics and environmental health. The major activities of the research program have included a major national study of traumatic work-related fatalities; longitudinal studies of noise induced hearing loss and pulmonary function in coal mines; evaluation of the utility for work injury surveillance of data collected in hospital accident and emergency departments; a study of asbestos fibres and lung tissue; and a number of studies into heat and cold stress in the workplace.

Whilst I am on the question of asbestos I would like to point out to the House that in Western Australia there have been many injuries caused by the attachment of the asbestos fibre in the lung and there are a great number of people who suffer from mesothelioma or asbestosis which is in itself an extremely debilitating and unpleasant cancer which, of course, is terminal.

The high level consultancy services which are obviously sought after by many people in industry have included a service for Qantas Airways Ltd, and for the Australian Government, a study of the occupational hygiene aspects of the dust extraction program for manganese minerals at Groote Eylandt, a study of potroom asthma, which is occupational asthma in the aluminium industry, a noise survey of mechanical workshops at naval armament depots at Kingswood and Silverwater and another asbestos survey at the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne. Again, people do not realise that children are exposed to asbestos fibre if their fathers or mothers come home with the asbestos fibre in their clothing. We must not turn a blind eye to these sorts of things. We must be aware as a nation that where there is an allegation of a dangerous practice or a hazardous undertaking, it is in the nation's interest to take that allegation seriously in the first instance rather than find that we have paid for it with human life and economic cost in the latter instance.

Sometimes, asbestosis or mesothelioma take 30 years to actually become the disease that kills people but in that 30 years we have allowed a lot more people to work in mines and buildings that have been insulated with asbestos. I think we have to be extremely careful not to allow those sorts of things to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission was established in 1985 on the basis of a report by an earlier interim commission of inquiry. I remind the House that at the time the Opposition opposed the creation of what seemed certain to be another quango. The Opposition then warned of the dangers of the Commission becoming another vehicle leading to the encouragement of greater regulation which, in turn, increased the costs of employing people without any real improvements in health or safety.

SPEECH.PARA: We pointed to a series of problems in the administrative structure of the Commission with its separate national office of Occupational Health and Safety and its National Institute for Occupational Health and Safety. Many of those problems which it was suggested might emerge have indeed appeared. However, the administrative problems which have emerged in the Commission have at times been so great that little in the way of proposals for a national strategy for occupational health and safety, which might have led to greater regulation, have emerged from the Commission. It is because of the results of a fairly recent review of these matters that the legislation we see today has been brought before the House.

Specifically, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill seeks to separate the position of the Chairman and the Chief Executive Officer of the Commission. The Opposition does not oppose these amendments or the Government's attempt to further the health and safety in the workplace in Australia. However, we question whether the Government's general approach, which is typical of its actions in many other important areas, is the best way of dealing with acknowledged problems. No-one is opposed to occupational health and safety. It is very much in the nature of a motherhood issue.

It is in the best interests of employers as well as employees, who have a very direct interest in their safety, for injuries and health problems caused at or by work to be minimised. It is not just a matter of the large economic costs of injury but also the very real suffering of those people who have the misfortune of being injured at work. We must realise that injuries at work will never be completely eliminated. Some people work in more dangerous occupations than others and are compensated for that by receiving higher wages and direct compensation if injury occurs. I have heard previous speakers mention figures from Japan suggesting that we have a higher per capita rate of deaths as a result of accidents in the workplace than countries such as Japan, the United States and Sweden.

The nature of the workplace in Australia is quite different and a large part of our national wealth is gathered in very dangerous industries, including the extractive mining industry and the construction industry which is very large and reflects the needs of a vast land mass and a developing economy. Other problems will result from accidents where no degree of blame can be attributed to anyone. Given this, we must seek the situation where the maximum possible level of knowledge and incentives to eliminate health or safety hazards is achieved. I would argue that the approach to occupational health and safety pursued by this Government, as well as by the trade union movement and the State Labor governments, actually fails to further the objectives which I have no doubt they genuinely wish to achieve. In my opinion, in the long run it will hinder the development of immediate and relevant knowledge and remove strong incentives on employees and employers to provide for safety in the workplace.

While the problems of occupational health and safety are national in character, in the end they must be solved in each separate workplace in the most efficient way possible. They are not new problems. Most places in which people work are probably safer today than at any time in the past. Safety issues have, to some extent, given way to more general health issues such as smoking in offices, the best type of furniture for staff to sit on and measures to counteract the problem of repetitive strain injury and so on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Progress is being made.

—Progress is being made but it is not necessarily as a result of the creation of the quango we are discussing here tonight. I would like to see this body-if it has not started already-look at the presence of legionella bacteria in Commonwealth buildings. We should look first at our own Commonwealth buildings and structures and workplace practices before we start interfering with the private sector. Let us get the Commonwealth's house in order, as it were, before we start regulating and interfering in the way we do. We are not clean as a Commonwealth. There is more than prima facie evidence-it is a matter of certainty-that legionella bacteria is to be found in old buildings where air-conditioning installations have been in place and operating for some time. Rather than concentrating on smoking in the workplace perhaps we could have a look at this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason employers are concerned about health and safety is obvious. Accidents can still be avoided by greater knowledge about possible dangers. Such knowledge requires work and effort. That is acknowledged. Unless an incentive exists to make the effort then, no matter what the Government does, there will be no great improvement in occupational health or safety. Employers whose negligence or actions cause injury or health problems to their employees should be fully liable for the costs of the employee. There should be significant incentives for those who employ people to ensure that their firms are as safe and healthy as possible.

No fault compensation, which has been legislated for in the United States, means that even the most meticulous employer will indirectly pay for the mistakes of other firms. Given that the greater safety might involve some monetary costs, the idea of no fault compensation removes most of the offsetting benefits in terms of lower additional costs in maintaining each employee safely in employment.

The common law system of providing for compensation after accidents provides real incentives to avoid those problems I have just referred to that are disincentives. In addition to those incentives we can find little more than education and an efficient and affordable legal system to resolve disputes and plans as swiftly as possible. Many of the criticisms of the common law approach to workers compensation and related issues are in fact criticisms of our legal system and its inability to cope with the litigation arising from the rapid growth in government legislation at all levels. The money spent on the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission could be better directed towards the Government's fundamental responsibilities in providing a legal system which can cope with the law it passes.

The alternative promoted by this Government and other Labor governments in the States has involved extensive regulation of the detailed operation of the workplace. This is particularly true of proposals of the trade union movement which are being adopted by Labor governments across the country. I will be interested to see how the national strategy of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission differs from these highly regulatory trends in the law relating to occupational health and safety. The truth is that overregulation in the health and safety area parallels regulation in many other areas of industry which has been imposed by governments in recent times.

One particular area for concern is the penchant for inspectors with wide powers to interfere in the operation of a business. Those inspectors are being appointed by all levels of government to perform a certain range of functions. People responsible for health and safety are usually appointed at the State level. Some proposed and existing legislation gives them investigative powers as wide as those of the police but without the same procedural restraints.

Similarly, the activities of trade union appointed safety officers on work sites have been completely counterproductive. I could do no better in support of that claim than to refer to the building industry, of which I am reasonably familiar. Although no-one wants to see people injured on building sites, the type of occupational health and safety legislation promoted by the unions and their captive parliamentary wing-the Labor Party-gives an open invitation to building industry unions to have snap strikes whenever they choose at no immediate cost to their members. The cost of spurious health and safety disputes to Australian industry and to the building industry in particular are incalculable. Certainly nothing has come out of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission to address these very real and significant problems. Because of the guillotine I propose to leave my remarks there. I regret that very much because there is a great deal that I could have contributed to this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been emphasised, estimates of the cost of occupational accidents in Australia amount to approximately $6 billion per annum. That is a wastage which this nation, like any other nation, cannot possibly condone or afford. Of course, the actual economic costs is only one element of it. The cost to the human condition of those people who are injured or incapacitated is much more than that. Whether it be in the short or long term it does not matter. There is a cost also to the families and children of these people. The human costs are those that go beyond the economic costs. I hope that all honourable members who have taken part in this debate recognise that fact. I emphasise once again that point by quoting the 1986-87 annual report of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission:

SPEECH.PARA: Each year, in Australia more than 500 workers leave home and do not return. Current statistics indicate that in Australia there are some 550 work-related fatalities and approximately 300,000 work-related injuries or disease annually which result in an absence from work. Estimates indicate that the national cost of these fatalities and injuries, directly, and in workers compensation, lost time, retraining, and replacement and repair of equipment, is more than $12 billion each year.

Much of this is avoidable if we take the appropriate measures. I wish to make some comments about work which is actually being done with a view to reducing that figure. I would like to make some comments about a contribution that is being made by the Ballarat College of Advanced Education to the improvement of occupational health and safety in Australia. It was fitting that this college should develop a course of this kind because it was there that so many people were prepared to enter the mining industry as mining engineers in the nineteenth century. In the early days mining was one of the most dangerous of occupations. It is estimated that in the heyday of mining one person a day was killed in the Victorian mines. In those days people did not recognise the importance of occupational health and safety. Unfortunately, sometimes people tend to say, `What a nuisance it is that people are making noises about occupational health and safety'. This ignores the human cost. The deaths that occurred in the Victorian mines in those days led the unions to establish safety mechanisms in the mines at Creswick and Ballarat.

In 1984 the Ballarat College of Advanced Education (CAE) developed Australia's first tertiary course in occupational health and safety. Under the leadership of Dr Dennis Else, the six full time staff recognise that there is an enormous task involved in preventing occupational injuries and diseases. They aim to provide training for health and safety practitioners, managers and inspectors. The college provided the first tertiary health and safety course in 1979 and has extended it from a graduate diploma to a masters degree. It is the best equipped unit in the country and has received recognition from industry and government at all levels.

The unit works according to three themes which have direct application to the workplace. Firstly, it is seen as necessary to identify health and safety problems, to seek their solutions and to have them applied in the workplace. That sounds very simple but it is not, and that is part of the problem. Secondly, if this is to happen, a change of attitude towards health and safety is required. Industry at all levels needs a change of attitude. From management to the shop floor, knowledge of health and safety issues is necessary. This must also extend to the application of health and safety knowledge to plant management and work practices. As part of this thrust, the third theme is developing an understanding of the economic advantages that can accrue to a plant through sound health and safety practices. That is one of the most significant motifs and has generated a lot of interest. It leads to better industrial relations, improved productivity and quality control. The numbers of days lost through injury and compensation claims are reduced. In other words, health and safety awareness and its application are sound business and are more than cost-effective.

I refer to the case of a progressive firm in my home city of Ballarat that has embraced occupational health and safety in what would otherwise be a very dangerous and expensive industry. Bendix-Mintex Pty Ltd is a manufacturer of friction products, mainly brake linings. Its business record is second to none. In recent years it has become the major manufacturer of brake linings in Australia. It has developed a successful record of export marketing, exporting its products to over 40 countries. But the firm recognises that it is dealing with a dangerous material, namely, asbestos. The company has taken a lead throughout the world in airborne material containment control by its design and installation of computerised ventilation equipment. As part of the Government's policy of encouraging excellence in Australian industry, occupational health and safety must be seen to be a most significant component. This firm has been working towards that goal with the Ballarat College of Advanced Education. I would like to congratulate the now retired Managing-Director of Bendix-Mintex, Bill Gribble, for his foresight, openness and common sense. I know that the new management is equally as committed as Bill was.

The message has to be: `Safe business is good business. Think safe; think smart'. These could be worthwhile slogans for any industry to adopt today. It is interesting to note that the Netherlands now requires new equipment and manufacturing plant to be provided with state of the art health and safety controls. It is to be hoped that the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission will work to ensure that the latest material in technical developments in the area of occupational health and safety is available, is distributed widely and is a conscious matter within the firms. Occupational health and safety awareness and its application must become part of our working culture. Management and employees, including the self-employed, must think safety and must have the knowledge to make their workplace safe and healthy. I congratulate the Ballarat CAE and its health and safety unit for the valuable work that is being done in this area. It ought to be noted that the council of the Ballarat CAE has recently required an evaluation of all courses offered within the college for health and safety requirements. I also wish to thank my friend Bob Hall for providing me with much useful material on this subject.

I support this Bill. I do not believe that any amendments are necessary. The Bill is simple and ought to be accepted. We are talking about an extremely important matter. It is to be hoped that the Bill will be passed with no opposition so that the Commission can work far more efficiently.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been made clear in this debate, the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission Amendment Bill provides for a number of measures aimed at improving the operations of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission, otherwise known as Worksafe Australia. The Commission was first set up on a provisional basis in 1984 and was established as a statutory body by Act of parliament in December 1985. The Commission's role, in a short statement, is to facilitate government, employer and employee cooperation towards achieving a more uniform approach to occupational health and safety. It is responsible for the development and implementation of national occupational health and safety standards and strategies in cooperation with the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for a greater focus in the area of work-related death and injury is clear. It stems from the fact that Australia has had an unacceptably high incidence of work-related death and injury as compared with other Western nations, even allowing for the nature of our industries discussed by my colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). As the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) pointed out, each year approximately 550 men and women die as a result of work-related accidents and disease. That gives an incidence rate of 77 per million in a work force of about 7 million. That compares with an annual work-related fatality rate of 22 per million workers in Sweden-these are 1984 figures-24 per million in the United Kingdom, 20 per million in Japan and 37 per million in the United States. To the 550 deaths to which I referred must be added some thousand persons each day who suffer a compensable injury or disease. And apart from the effects of injury and death, the lack of uniformity as between the States in their regulatory regimes in this context-the situation has been described as creating a legislative minefield for industry and unions-leads to inefficiencies and higher costs for industry. Hence the need for action-the importance of the issue-is not in question.

As to the `qango' that has been set up, it is clear that in the first few years of its operations the Commission ran into some pretty heavy weather. In September of last year Mr Bernie McKay was appointed to conduct a review, as pointed out by previous speakers, and his report was released in March of this year. The measures in the present Bill largely stem from Mr McKay's recommendations. He concluded that there had been an overall lack of progress in the first two years of Worksafe's operation and an inadequate development of the standards, information and education programs and research activities that were contemplated as its objectives, with insufficient development of the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety. I note in parentheses that the Commission has two arms-the National Occupational Health and Safety Office, the operational arm, and the National Institute of Occupational Health and Safety, the scientific and technical research arm. So we have two bureaucracies rather than just one!

The McKay report made recommendations that suggest a real effort to deal with the problems of the Commission: specifically, less emphasis on tripartism, a greater role for the States, separation of the functions of the Chairman and the Chief Executive Officer, and a greater focus on the Commission's priority issues as determinants of the Commission's work program and organisational operation. Those recommendations have in fact been supported by the Confederation of Australian Industry, the ACTU and the State governments. One might also note the appointment of Professor Ted Emmett, a distinguished Australian who, at the time of his appointment, was Professor of Occupational Medicine at the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health and Director of the Centre for Occupational Environmental Health at that university. His appointment as Director of the Institute and acting chairman of the Commission should enable it to establish greater credibility in the whole area.

As the shadow Minister has indicated, the Opposition does not oppose this Bill-as I can assure the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren). But the Opposition remains wary of the necessity for a large bureaucratic body-as I just said, two bureaucracies-costing the taxpayer in the order of $20m but to date seeming to achieve very little. In the light of the high incidence of occupational death in industry in this country-I previously referred to the figures; in respect of deaths, more than twice the incidence in comparable Western countries-the need for definitive action to combat that incidence is imperative. However, for my part I suggest that only so much can be achieved by direct regulation and through the efforts of a body such as this National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. In practical terms, part of the answer, and perhaps the most important part-my colleague from Curtin (Mr Rocher) was suggesting something similar in reducing the excessive incidence of occupational injury and death in this country is better and more responsible industrial relations in the workplace, at the individual enterprise level-the breaking down of the `them and us' syndrome, the achieving of a real sense of common purpose and mutual interest between employee and employer.

It is perhaps significant that in the very week that this Bill was previously listed for debate the House passed this Government's Industrial Relations Bill. While that measure made some marginal changes, and the current focus on award restructuring will contribute further to a measure of freeing up, by and large the too rigid and too centralised industrial relations system in this country remains in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —It enshrined the adversarial industrial relations system.

—It enshrined that, which is adverse to the problem we are trying to address. So here is the Government desperately trying, on the one hand, to make a large bureaucratic body, costing the taxpayer in the order of $20m, work with some effectiveness, while on the other hand it backs away from the sort of action in the industrial relations arena which would truly encourage direct dealing, more constructive cooperation between employers and employees, which I have no doubt would reduce the present unacceptable level of occupational injury and death. Of course, if that were pursued, there would at the same time be increased productivity and higher real wages for the employees, greater profitability for the enterprise-and I might add, a stronger and more internationally competitive Australian economy. So I think we ought to get the focus a little away from the introduction and development of quangos such as this National Occupational Health and Safety Commission and more into dealing realistically with the conditions in which this high incidence of accident and injury obtains.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duncan) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: OZONE PROTECTION BILL 1988[COGNATE BILLS:OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1988OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-MANUFACTURE) BILL 1988]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate order of the day No. 7 concurrently with orders of the day Nos 8 and 9. That being the case, the Chair will allow that course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Ozone Protection Bill 1988, the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill 1988 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill 1988. These Bills give effect to Australia's obligations under the Vienna Convention and under the recently signed Montreal Protocol on the protection of the ozone layer. On this side of the House, as surely is the case on the other side of the House, we regard this as an extremely important matter, not just for Australia but for the whole world.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills move faster than the international minimum standards which are determined in the Vienna Convention and in the Montreal Protocol. They provide for about a 50 per cent reduction in the use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons within a period of five years. Everyone in this House would agree that there is very great international concern now about the depletion of the ozone layer. Ozone is a trace gas in the stratosphere which helps to filter ultraviolet radiation from the sun. It is well known that without that filter then ultraviolet radiation can be lethal to unicellular organisms and surface cells of higher plants and of animals.

CFCs are seen as one of the major causes of the destruction of parts of the ozone layer and in particular, of course, of ozone molecules. This effect on the ozone layer of CFCs was first recognised in 1974 by Rowland and Molina at the University of California. Their research and subsequent research done into this issue is widely accepted now throughout the scientific community. It is worth all of us reflecting on some of the consequences which will occur if the ozone layer becomes increasingly depleted, as there is concern that it is already happening.

One of the first consequences will be an increase in skin cancer, and for us as Australians that is obviously a particular concern because Australia has the highest incidence of melanoma in the world. Malignant melanoma now affects about one person in 250 around the world and some scientists estimate that by the year 2000 it will affect one in every 135 persons. Others predict that there will be a 60 per cent increase in the incidence of skin cancer by the year 2000. Of course, there are a lot of reasons for this happening. Some of them are social, and there are other scientific reasons not related to the ozone layer which may be the cause of a potential increase in skin cancer. But there is no doubt that the concern that the depletion of the ozone layer will contribute to an increase in skin cancer is a concern that we must all take very seriously.

In 1987, the National Health and Medical Research Council with the Australian Environmental Council made an estimate that if there were a one per cent decline in the ozone layer, that would lead to an increase in the occurrence of skin cancer of between 4 per cent and 6 per cent. I think that just underlines how seriously we need to take the consequences of the depletion of the ozone layer. However, they are not the only consequences. There is some evidence that an increase in the effective ultraviolet radiation, coming, of course, as a result of the depletion of the ozone layer, may suppress the human immune system. So that again is something we all have a responsibility to be concerned about.

A third consequence of the depletion of the effect of the ozone layer and the increase of ultraviolet radiation is that it could do significant harm to aquatic systems and to biological organisms. For example, many scientists believe that it would reduce yields from crops, and I know that that would be of considerable concern to our rural community. It would increase the susceptibility of crops to pests and disease. That too is of major concern to a country such as Australia that depends so heavily on its agricultural industries. It is interesting to note also that scientists believe that the increase in ultraviolet radiation could harm the larval stages of fish and thereby have significant implications for the fishing industry around the world.

A fourth consequence of that occurrence is that it is believed-of course, there is only preliminary evidence for this-there could be a significant detrimental effect on the incidence of urban smog. That aspect is not widely known yet. There is no firm evidence that that will be a consequence of the depletion of the ozone level, but it is a matter of some preliminary scientific evidence. Fifthly-and perhaps this is the most well known of the consequences of the depletion of the ozone layer after the incidence of skin cancer-it is believed that the depletion of the ozone layer may affect the global temperature and contribute to creating what is know as the greenhouse effect. CFCs are believed to help trap heat in the atmosphere, and naturally enough the consequence is a warming of the surface of the globe. That creates the greenhouse effect.

The greenhouse effect means changes to rainfall patterns, and that could have significant consequences not just for agriculture but also for the way we live. Secondly, the greenhouse effect, if there would really be a warming of the globe as is widely believed, would lead to a melting of the polar ice caps and a rise in sea level. I note that the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) on one very well-known occasion put out a most informative press release on the greenhouse effect. It is an issue very close to his heart, and I am glad to see that he is here. I had not noticed that he was present until I began making these points. The honourable member for Bass made the point that, if predictions about the greenhouse effect turn out to be correct, the electorate of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) could be flooded. Perhaps that would be one of the positive consequences of the greenhouse effect, but I jest because, for the people who live in the Prime Minister's electorate and, doubtless, who never see him, that would be a very undesirable consequence.

I make the concession, as I believe anyone should in this debate, that these consequences are by no means proven beyond reasonable doubt. There is a lot of doubt, there is debate in the scientific community, and different views, I have noted, have come from different sections of the meteorological community, for example, which dispute first of all, that there is a greenhouse effect. Some dispute that the depletion of the ozone layer is an issue with which we should be overwhelmingly concerned. I am not sure that we can responsibly simply sit by and accept that there is a debate within the scientific community and conclude that we should do nothing. By introducing this sort of legislation, following, as the Government is doing, the lead of the Liberal Party, and, in particular, the Liberal Party in many States, we are doing the safe thing by addressing what is certainly a fact-that if the use of CFCs continues to increase, that will cause some of the effects I have cited this evening. If we do nothing to reduce the use of CFCs those five consequences will become a reality. If the use of CFCs stabilises, we might accept that there is just a debate within the scientific community and that we do not know what the consequences might be. I believe it is wise to take the responsible course and not gamble with people's health, the future of our aquatic systems and our biological organisms, the issue of urban smog and the greenhouse effect.

Many people, in addition to these direct concerns of the consequences inter alia of the effects of the use of CFCs, are concerned about the growth of what is described as the ozone hole. It is believed that this ozone hole began to grow in about 1979. We do not know for sure, but that seems to be the consensus amongst the scientific community. There is a range of theories as to why the ozone hole may be growing, but let me make the point before I discuss some of those theories that the growth in the ozone hole should be an issue close to the heart of every Australian. Certainly, it should be close to the heart of every Tasmanian, because the ozone hole exists over Antarctica, and Australia is just about the nearest country to Antarctica. Therefore, we have a natural self-interest in being concerned about this occurrence. As I said, there are a number of theories about why the ozone hole may be growing. The first of those theories is that the ozone hole is caused by a change in the direction of air flow in the polar region and that, once that air flow direction changes back again, the ozone hole may begin to fill up. Secondly, some people argue that it is caused by solar cycles and that we are going through a particularly unusual solar cycle at present; when that solar cycle is finished, one of its consequences, that is, the opening up of the ozone hole, may pass by and the ozone layer may cover the earth in its entirety. However, the third theory, the one that I know we can actually do something about, is that the ozone hole is caused by chemical reactions.

I appreciate, as every honourable member in this House should appreciate, that there are no final conclusions on the causes of the opening of the ozone hole, but there is overwhelming evidence that the use of CFCs in particular is exacerbating the ozone hole, whatever its cause. If we were simply to take the view-which, I am glad to say, we as a Parliament will not do-that that did not matter, that the scientific evidence is unclear so we should not do anything, I believe that would be grossly irresponsible, because there is one thing we can do: we can take action on the chemical front. We cannot do anything about solar cycles and we cannot change the direction of air flow in the polar region, but we can stop the emission of damaging chemicals such as CFCs into the ozone layer.

For those reasons we on this side of the House warmly welcome the Government's action in introducing these Bills in the past few days. I compliment the Government on following the lead of the Liberal Party throughout Australia in this issue, but it must be underlined that the Liberal Party has repeatedly taken the lead around Australia on the issue of the future of the ozone layer. At the 1988 Federal Liberal Party Council in Melbourne the Liberal Party passed a resolution on the elimination of the use of CFCs because of the overwhelming concern within the Party of the effect of CFCs on the ozone level. My recollection is that that resolution was passed unanimously.

In South Australia the Liberals with the Democrats have had a Bill passed in the Legislative Council to control the use of CFCs, again to address the issue of the future of the ozone layer. I am disappointed to hear that the Labor Party in South Australia will oppose that Bill in the House of Assembly. That is disappointing, because the Labor Party is starting to take the issue seriously in this Parliament. There is not the same degree of commitment in the Parliament of South Australia. In Western Australia Barry Blaikie, one of the shadow Ministers, initiated action in the Parliament against the use of CFCs. I congratulate Barry Blaikie, a Liberal member, for his commitment in that State. Probably standing above all these people is Peter Hodgman, the Minister for the Environment in Tasmania, who has led the way in Australia. He has definitely led the way in Australia in introducing legislation on this very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is grandstanding all the time.

—His legislation, which I hope the honourable member who is interjecting does not oppose, comes into force on 31 December this year, one year before the Federal Government's legislation comes into effect. Perhaps as a final point on the very strong commitment of the Liberal Party and how the Liberal Party has led the way on this issue, I point out that action against the continual use of CFCs is an integral part of the Liberal Party's federal environment policy which was successfully launched by my colleague Senator Chris Puplick recently in Canberra.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important not to set industry up as a bogey man and say that it has acted in a grossly irresponsible manner in the promotion of the use of CFCs. That would be unfair because, in particular, I think the aerosol industry has done a good job and its excellent record in reducing the use of CFCs needs to be recognised. From 1974 to 1985 the use of CFCs in aerosols has declined from 13,000 tonnes to 4,000 tonnes. That may not be enough, but it is worth recognising that the industry has done a very good job in reducing the use of CFCs and it would not do this Parliament any discredit to congratulate the aerosol industry on the voluntary reduction in the use of CFCs that has taken place. Some of that reduction in the use of CFCs in the aerosol industry is without any doubt brought about because of concern for the consequences of the use of CFC driven aerosols.

There is no question also that non-aerosol use of CFCs has increased in the same period of 1974 to 1985 from 3,000 tonnes in 1974 to 8,000 tonnes in 1985. This Bill will address that. It will lead to a substantial reduction in the use of CFCs and that is something that members on this side of the House warmly welcome. I do not want to take up too much of the time of this debate because I know a lot of my colleagues feel very strongly about this issue and wish to speak as well and the Government has guillotined the debate so that Parliament is not able to express a broadly based view on this issue. Only a small handful of people lucky enough to be high on the speakers list will be able to do so.

Briefly, I wish to raise several specific points about the Bill. First, I am glad that the Government has had the intelligence to make some exemptions for the pharmaceutical industry because there is a debate about the use of CFCs as a propellant for asthmatics. Some people in this Parliament in another place, the Australian Democrats, believe that CFCs should not be used as a propellant even in the treatment of asthmatics. As I will point out in a minute, I think that is extraordinarily irresponsible, even callous on the part of the Australian Democrats whose spokesperson comes from my own State, someone called Senator Coulter. For the treatment of asthma and certain other medical conditions there are still no practical alternatives for CFCs and the reason is that CFCs are effectively non-toxic. Hydrocarbons are the usual alternatives for CFCs but the trouble with hydrocarbons is that they are toxic.

Senator Coulter, to whom I referred earlier, advocates the use of carbon dioxide as a propellant in the treatment of asthmatics but he does not seem to have taken into account that there is a difficulty with using carbon dioxide, namely, that as the air temperature increases, so does the pressure of that carbon dioxide propelled unit and if the pressure increases, the treatment to the asthmatic becomes very irregular and could be damaging if the temperature was high enough. Senator Coulter may not be very concerned about that but I know members of the House of Representatives are. We do not think, as some people in the Australian Democrats think, that there should be a trade-off between the disease of asthma and the disease of cancer. Honourable members on this side of the House do not believe that cancer is a more serious threat to health than asthma and so cancer should be addressed and asthma forgotten; let us not use CFCs so that asthmatics cannot be properly treated. That is the view of the Australian Democrats. We think that in any humane and responsible society we should try to treat both asthmatics and people who have the potential to develop cancer, let alone those who are already suffering from it, in the best way we can.

We would also say in that context that it is important that the Government consults with the States as the States introduce their own legislation in this very important area. It would be regrettable if a State government did not take into consideration the need in certain circumstances to exempt from legislation the use of CFCs in the pharmaceutical industry. I know that in the case of Tasmania that exemption has been made, and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) will confirm that. I hope in other States that same exemption will be made and no-one will listen to the ravings of some of the people in the Australian Democrats.

The second point I raise is the issue of the effect of clause 4 of this Bill. I am sorry that no Minister responsible for this measure is in the House and that the Labor Party does not take the issue a little more seriously. Although the Minister is not present, perhaps his advisers are listening. Members of the Opposition would like from the Government a full explanation, particularly for any future legal action that may occur, of the possibility of this proposed legislation striking down certain State laws which go further than the Federal laws. Clearly, under section 109 of the Constitution, where there is a conflict between State and Federal legislation, the Federal legislation strikes down the State legislation. I am not saying that I think this would happen in this case but it would be helpful if the Minister, when he winds up the debate, gives us the assurance that that conflict will not occur. With that assurance we can be fairly confident that that kind of conflict will not create some legal confusion in the years ahead between the Commonwealth and the States.

In conclusion on this very important issue, I am sorry that we do not have more time for the debate and that more honourable members cannot contribute to this matter which is a major concern to all Australians. I noticed an opinion poll the other day that showed well over 90 per cent of Australians were concerned, particularly about the greenhouse effect, and that reflects also their concern about the depletion of the ozone layer. It is a pity that the Government has introduced the guillotine. However, honourable members on this side of the House are glad to support the Bills the Government has introduced and are glad that the Federal Labor Party has followed the fine lead given it by the Liberal Government in Tasmania, by Liberals in Western Australia, by Liberals in South Australia and by the Federal Council of the Liberal Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Nationals.
—The National Party too has played an important part in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ozone Protection Bill is a very important measure and perhaps it was a reflection on the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) of his continuing displays of lack of maturity that he had to be so partisan in this debate. He mentioned a number of State governments but he failed to mention the inaction of the Liberal Government in New South Wales. When one reflects upon people's attitudes to this question, often other factors come into play. It may be that because we have so many aerosol manufacturers in New South Wales there is some tardiness on behalf of that State Government. That is not to say that other governments have not displayed the same insensitivity.

SPEECH.PARA: On the international stage when we look at the developments that have led to the Montreal Protocol we find that in Europe there has been great debate where the European Community is the signatory on behalf of its member states, and that the member states of that community had great debate. Unfortunately, that was based upon the industrial aspects of the manufacture of chlorofluorocarbons and other such gases. It is unfortunate that when we have debates such as this matters of that moment are brought into play.

As has been outlined so far in the debate, we are dealing with something that is based on hypothesis. It is not something that can be readily proven; it is not something that can be readily understood. The important thing is that we have a major environmental matter that has captured the imagination and interest of people. I think it is important to say that, despite the comments of the honourable member for Mayo, these pieces of legislation have the full support of this House. The Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) in his second reading speech said:
Protection of the ozone layer is one of the Government's highest environmental priorities.
The honourable member for Mayo, in speaking on behalf of the Opposition and on behalf of the Opposition shadow Minister, Senator Puplick, echoed those words.

As I have said, this subject enables people to focus their attention on the broader environmental matters that have been forgotten in recent times. We have come a long way since the time when simple matters of air and water pollution were seen as not being important. We have matured in our attitude and, through various pieces of legislation, we see these aspects as being very important. Certainly, the environmental debate in this country has moved on to narrower fields, where we have looked at the protection of particular natural assets. In protecting those natural assets there has been a great deal of debate, unfortunately characterised by partisanship, by State governments getting into long drawn-out battles with the Commonwealth Government. That is unfortunate because it has tended to confuse people about the importance of environmental matters. With this type of legislation, we have a chance of bringing people back together, concentrating and focusing their attention on things that are important to all of us.

The effect of the ozone layer in the stratosphere has been well outlined in previous speeches. It is very important for the filtering of ultraviolet rays and therefore protecting humans from ultraviolet rays, which can cause cancers, and also protecting other flora and fauna from the harmful effects of ultraviolet light. Clearly, as has been set down by the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, the legislation attacks the amount of chlorofluorocarbons and halons that are used. At the moment, chlorofluorocarbons are used predominantly as propellants in aerosols and refrigerants in foam and halons are used predominantly in fire extinguishers.

Since the theory was put forward about the depletion of the ozone layer responsible bodies have been looking at alternatives to chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, as they are more commonly known. The action of the aerosol manufacturers in voluntarily setting out to place these bans is to be admired. It is interesting to see that they have now embarked upon a campaign-I suppose the bottom line of any company's decision is a profit motive-and are marketing their aerosols as containing no chlorofluorocarbons. They have created a symbol with a tick which states, `Friendly to our environment'. These little devices are also important because they remind members of the community when they are out shopping, looking at articles on the shelves, that this is a feature. I have had correspondence from the Broadmeadows Community Health Centre in my electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good health centre too.
—Broadmeadows is a good health centre and it is doing a lot of vital work in that area.
—And represented by a good member too.

—I thank the honourable member. That health centre wrote to me suggesting that, on those aerosols containing CFCs, there should be a warning that CFCs were harmful to the environment. I think that sort of thing would be helpful not for any punitive reason but in educating the community and making it aware of the issues.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of propellants in aerosols is the easiest of the uses for us to address. Should we go back to the common pump spray for fly sprays and things like that, which people perhaps think is a museum piece, or should we use other gases such as hydrocarbons? Those considerations are important, but we must look at the other uses of these gases as coolants in refrigerators and air-conditioners. We know that, as the CFCs finally percolate the 20 or 50 kilometres above us into the stratosphere, they will remain there for many years. Some say that they will remain in the stratosphere for over 100 years. So it is not just a problem of now. Even if we addressed this problem and had a total ban on CFCs today, we would still be confronted with a problem.

A lot of these gases are lying in machinery that will become obsolete. One issue that this legislation does not touch upon-I understand that the Minister has had discussions with the industry groups he consulted before placing the legislation before the Parliament-is the recycling of these gases. Because of the way in which the gases are stored in the coils of machinery it is unfortunate that they are not readily recyclable, it is something we should look at. If the gases are to continue to be used, even within the strategy of reducing their use, they should be able to be extracted, not just for recycling but also so that they can be more readily and properly disposed of. One of the dangers is that these gases can leak from machinery thrown onto the municipal tips. The coils are damaged and the gases are released into the air, just as if they were in an aerosol pack. It is important that these issues, some of which are outside the scope of the legislation, continue to be addressed.

Exemptions are allowable in this legislation, which is a controversial point with some people in their approach to the question of the control of chlorofluorocarbons. We on this side of the House believe that there are necessary issues that should be allowed for. Therefore, there is a procedure in the Bill that will allow for exemptions for essential uses-medical, veterinary, defence, industrial safety or public safety purposes-and that is important. The honourable member for Mayo outlined the use of CFCs in asthmatic inhalers. He said, quite correctly that those gases deliver consistently over the life of the aerosol package a dose that can be appropriately measured and delivered. Unfortunately, at this time we do not have an alternative to the gas but it is something we must continue to work at. Fortunately, the uses that will come under this exemption represent only some 3 per cent of the CFCs used in the Australian context. The other important thing to look at is the rate of manufacture in Australia of CFCs, which represents just under 2 per cent of international production levels.

The point that I wish to make is that this matter requires international effort. It is not something that we shall be able to combat in isolation. It is unfortunate that the reduction of levels of ozone in the stratosphere on a seasonal basis that creates the so-called ozone hole over Antarctica has the greatest potential of causing effect not only to Tasmania but to some parts of mainland Australia, depending on the prevailing meteorological conditions.

It is important that whilst we bear the brunt of the effect, the international community should look at this question with as much zealousness as we can. One of the effects that can occur due to the increase in ultraviolet rays reaching the earth is a disruption to plankton, which is an important food source for aquatic animals in the Antarctic region. Later, that will be of even greater consequence than the effect on humans.

This legislation is important. It should not be belittled. We should not look at it on a partisan political basis. I hope that we do see cooperation from the State governments with the Commonwealth Government on this issue, because it is important. There can be no other issue of such fundamental importance as matters concerning the environment, be they the question of ozone depletion, the greenhouse effect-CFCs have some involvement in this effect, having regard to their levels in the atmosphere-or other worldwide environmental matters. It is important that we continue to show the community at large that there are matters on which we in this place can sit down and tackle the issues with as much effort as we can muster and come to full agreement. I am glad that in this chamber we will have total support for these pieces of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to describe speaking in the debate on this legislation as a pleasure because it is such a worrying matter, but it is certainly a matter that calls for very serious consideration by this House. One gains the impression tonight that considerable concern is being expressed by members on both sides of the House, as it ought to be, regarding this serious problem. We are trying to legislate away possibly irrevocable damage done by humans to their environment. The coalition tonight is expressing its support for a significant extension of industry regulation. The subject of the legislation is the depletion of the ozone layer around the earth, which has been described in great detail by a number of speakers. Its objective is to eliminate the emission of certain man-made substances, in particular, chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, commenting on this issue, a Sydney University academic, Dr Chaples, warned that democratic governments have great difficulty planning for issues that last longer than the interval between elections. Sadly, when we look at the history of how various governments comprised of parties from either side of the House have performed, that is true. Dr Chaples is, of course, right. This legislation is an instance of closing the gate, not after the horse has bolted, but just in time to catch the horse's tail. A horse caught like that takes a lot of effort to get back into the stable, as I am sure everybody would agree. It takes a lot of what somebody described as horse sense-the definition of horse sense being stable thinking.

The reality is that even if the legislation before us imposed a total global ban, it would take around 200 years for the upper atmosphere fully to repair itself from the effects of CFCs. The reality is that scientists first warned parliaments around the world in 1974 about the link between CFCs and ozone depletion. While some countries banned CFCs from aerosol cans, little action was taken to deal effectively with the problem. Indeed, were it not for a gaping hole over the Antarctic, I doubt whether this kind of legislation, with even its moderate schedule of regulation and control, would be before this Parliament tonight.

Other honourable members have outlined the scientific facts about the damage that CFCs have caused and are causing. They have referred to the projected tens of thousands of skin cancers and cataracts. They have referred to the impact of higher levels of ultraviolet light on agricultural production. They have referred to the probable new slot on weather broadcasts at the turn of the century which will give readings on ultra- violet B light alerts. I do not intend to repeat those details or repeat the specifics of the legislation before us.

I want to emphasise the broader questions before us in this legislation. I made two opening statements at the start of my remarks. I said first that we are here today trying to legislate away damage done by humans to the environment over which they were appointed stewards by their creator. Dr Stephen Schneider of the National Centre for Atmospheric Research in the United States has argued that humans are altering the earth's surface and changing the atmosphere at such a rate that we have become a competitor with natural forces that maintain our climate. What is new, he says, is the potential irreversibility of the changes that are now taking place. That is a very significant statement.

The story of the ozone depletion problem is the story of man-made substances produced for life-style purposes in ignorance of their likely impact on the environment. It is the story of corporate and political unwillingness to heed scientific advice. It is the story of political responsiveness only where there is evidence of imminent catastrophe. It is a familiar story in the area of environmental policy. If nothing else, it should be a lesson in humility and conservatism. We should take it as a lesson on how fragile the environment is and how reckless human pursuit of affluence and ease is. It should remind us that we know less than we think about the logic of life. Just as we have begun to understand climatic patterns which have gone on for countless years, we discover that we have been subverting them and possibly can do little but hope that a ban such as this will allow time for natural recuperation.

My second statement related to the unusual enthusiasm by my own Party and the coalition to extend regulation of industry in this legislation. Coalition support for this legislation reflects the realities and pragmatism of what must be a common effort by Australians and citizens around the world to bring to a halt and then reverse the destruction of the living earth. The evidence before this Parliament on soil degradation, the greenhouse effect and ozone depletion tells us that wisdom and prudence must replace ideology in the area of environmental policy-making.

I referred earlier to the concept of human stewardship of the environment. I indicated my belief that it is a God-given obligation. That we have denied our responsibilities as stewards and pursued instead, and blindly, mere exploitation and consumption of creation, is both obvious and shameful. This legislation is late in coming but urgently appropriate. Hopefully, it is a chance for Parliament to signal its intention to take seriously our part in the stewardship of creation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely pleased to be able to speak on the Ozone Protection Bill, the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill, and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill. This legislation has taken some time to be drafted, but I believe it is a significant step in recognising what could become a very serious problem-the destruction of the ozone layer which surrounds and protects the earth. It is a very complex problem. Daily we hear wild claims of what could happen. We hear other views to the effect that we should not be concerned. I would like to express some ideas which have not been expressed; some of my own ideas. I am pleased to see the attitude taken by the chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) producers. They have taken positive steps. They have agreed to cut production. Many countries have ratified, or will soon ratify, the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. Eighty per cent of the world's consumption of CFCs will be covered under that Protocol. The United States environmental agency has called for a total world ban on the use of chemicals believed to be destroying the earth's ozone shield. Even Prince Charles has banned the use of aerosols in his household because of the controversy. These people are pointing in a direction which we as individuals can follow.

SPEECH.PARA: The aerosol producers have cut CFC usage by 70 per cent since 1974, bringing production down from 12,000 tonnes per year to 4,000 tonnes. Four out of every five aerosol cans in Australia do not contain any CFCs now. The West produces about 75,000 tonnes of CFC-11 and CFC-12 each year, with the Soviet Union producing another 60,000 tonnes. World production of other probable ozone depleters amounts to approximately another 200,000 tonnes. This is an overall total of one million tonnes with an annual value in the range of $2 billion. The market is dominated by about two dozen companies in the United States, Europe and Japan. But there are literally thousands of downstream companies that use CFCs. CFCs are produced by huge chemical companies such as Du Pont, ICI, Hoechst Australia Ltd and, I believe, Monsanto Australia Ltd. The Chemical Manufacturers Association which throughout the 1970s argued the chlorofluorocarbons were innocent of all ozone-depleting charges is now spending $2m a year on research and development of CFC substitutes. Even Du Pont declared last last year that although it will be many years before an adequate scientific understanding can be achieved, it would nevertheless be prudent to limit worldwide emissions of CFCs.

I am a believer in the principle that the polluter pays. You may recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that recently I moved in this House that a levy be placed on all polluters and pollutants to fund research into the greenhouse effect. I suggest that those companies which have made billions of dollars from the manufacture and sale of CFCs over the past decade put their hands in their corporate pockets and provide money for research into what they have been doing to the ozone layer. Why should we, the taxpayers, fund research into a problem that the chemical companies, the chemical industry, have known about for years? I believe that in the United States the chemical companies provide money for research. These companies, such as Hoechst, produce nice advertisements. One such advertisement shows children learning how to pronounce their names. If chemical companies have a social conscience I expect them to announce generous grants to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation for research in the near future.

I would like to bring to the notice of the House some of the effects which could occur by the depletion of the ozone layer. There will be an increased incidence of skin cancers. Laboratory studies and epidemiological evidence show a strong link between exposure to UV-B-ultraviolet rays-radiation and an increased incidence in basal and melanoma skin cancers. While the current incidence of melanoma skin cancer is small compared to non-melanoma cases, the fatality rate is much higher.

While I am on that subject, I draw the House's attention to a paper, called The Erythemal Ultraviolet Radiation Distribution over Australia-the Calculations, Detailed Results and Input Data. It was written by G. W. Paltridge and I. J. Barton who worked for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in 1978. A table in this paper gives the erythemal ultraviolet radiation values-or doses-in Melbourne and in Brisbane. The dose in Melbourne is around 1,400 units. In Brisbane it is around 2,400 units. That is an increase of approximately 70 per cent. With the present depletion of the ozone layer we who live in Melbourne would not be exposed to as many ultraviolet rays as we would if we lived in Brisbane. Therefore, the concern that has been raised by many people is not really valid.

There will be an increase in cataracts. Radiation has been found to play a significant role in the formation of cataracts. There will be damage to aquatic organisms. While studies to date have been limited in scope, it appears that increased exposure to UV-B radiation will adversely affect aquatic organisms and potentially disrupt the aquatic food chain. For example, studies have suggested that phytoplankton remains close to the water's surface to facilitate photosynthesis. As a result, it is susceptible to damage. There will be accelerated weathering of outdoor plastics. There will be an increased formation of ground level ozone. This could have an effect on various crops.

I also draw the attention of the House to some of the ozone depleting potentials and the lifetimes of some of the compounds that are commonly used in CFCs. CFC-11 and CFC-12 are quite popular. They are the bulk of all CFCs used in air-conditioning, et cetera. CFC-11 has an atmospheric lifetime of 60 years. CFC-12 has an atmospheric lifetime of 120 years. CFC-13 has an atmospheric lifetime of 100 years. CFC-115 has an atmospheric lifetime of 490 years. Luckily, this CFC is not used very much, but it is used in low temperature refrigeration.

I would also like to bring to the attention of the House the latest information regarding the 1988 Antarctic ozone hole. I stress that I have only a draft report; it is not a final report. However, it has some very interesting information in it. The Antarctic hole of 1988 is not as deep as in previous years. It is the smallest springtime ozone minimum observed over Antarctica at least since 1982. Ozone levels reached a minimum around mid-September. Rather than continuing to decline as in previous years, the minimum stayed relatively constant at 175 to 180 Dobson units (DU). The Antarctic ozone hole of 1988 is not as deep as in previous years. It is the smallest springtime ozone minimum observed over Antarctica, at least since 1982. Ozone levels reached a minimum around mid-September, then, rather than continuing to decline as in previous years, the minimum stayed relatively constant at 175 to 180 Dobson units.

There are areas of unusually high ozone levels, in excess of 500 DU, around the normal Antarctic ozone ridge-approximately 60 degrees south. These values are also higher than in previous years. The ridge of high ozone is concentrated on the Australian side of the Antarctic vortex. Integrated total ozone levels over the entire Southern Hemisphere during September and October are the highest recorded since 1979 when satellite observations began. The vortex is more mobile this year and more elliptical in shape. The ozone hole has been pushed off the pole towards South America, but still remains within the confines defined by the Antarctic continent. The evidence suggests that the vortex is not as stable this year and preliminary analysis of stratospheric temperatures indicates that it is significantly warmer. That is a very important point.

A smaller ozone hole was predicted this year by the Ozone Trends Panel, based on the observed two-year cycle in its previous intensity and the phase of the solar cycle. However the increase in ozone levels over Antarctica this year significantly exceed previous expectations. This year's findings on the Antarctic ozone hole will cause rethinking about its mechanisms of formation. It will rekindle the debate between chemists and dynamicists about the balance of the formation mechanisms, chlorine versus atmospheric transport, and will hopefully further increase our understanding of this important phenomenon.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) has suggested the Antarctic ozone hole of 1988 will slow down the long term decline of ozone observed in the Southern Hemisphere. Even if the current Montreal Protocol were observed or ratified by all nations, the Antarctic ozone hole would remain forever because, under the current protocol, stratospheric chlorine levels will still double from their current levels. The hole will remain until these chlorine levels are reduced to what they were in the early 1970s. This will require virtually a complete phase out of CFCs, and careful consideration of acceptable emission levels of Ch3CCl3 will have to be made. However, the hole could disappear if the Antarctic stratosphere were to warm significantly. Perhaps there could be a spin-off from the greenhouse effect. If it warms up we will get rid of the ozone hole.

What this all means is that we really do no know what is going on. Last year it was doom and gloom; this year it is good news. What is happening? No-one knows. This is why we must put more money into research and we must allow our scientists and chemists to work out exactly what is going on. I am glad to see that this Bill has bipartisan support. It is something we do not see very often but it is excellent and I am very pleased that the Opposition is supporting this Bill. There is a lot more I could say, but I have run over my time.
