I thought it was most important that I bring to the notice of this House the changes that have occurred in the ozone hole over Antarctica this spring. I urge the House to support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Ozone Protection Bill, as we have already heard from previous speakers, is to give effect to the provisions of the Montreal Protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer. The passing of this legislation, with bipartisan support, will ensure that Australia can then ratify the protocol. Protection of the ozone layer is one of the highest environmental priorities. The proposals contained in this Bill should enable Australia to achieve targeted reductions in half the proposed time that the Montreal agreement recommends. Protection of the ozone layer is an environmental issue of world importance which requires urgent action. The implications for Australia arising from ozone depletion are especially important in terms of a possible increase in the already high incidence of skin cancers, possible damage to primary industries and our interest in the preservation of the Antarctic environment.

SPEECH.PARA: What then is ozone? We now know that ozone is a gas composed of three oxygen atoms. It surrounds the earth like a veil, protecting the planet and its inhabitants from the direct rays of the sun. Ozone is the umbrella against the ultraviolet. If ozone were not present in the atmosphere lethal levels of ultraviolet radiation from the sun would reach the earth's surface. Ozone is found in heights of up to 60 kilometres. It is at its most dense 20 to 25 kilometres up but even here only one molecule in 100,000 is ozone. It is interesting to note that if all the ozone were collected at the surface of the earth, it would form a layer only about three millimetres deep. Ozone is vital and because there is so little of it even the smallest changes in ozone concentrations could have dramatic consequences for life on earth. The production of ozone occurs naturally high in the atmosphere from oxygen and is broken down by natural forces with the result that gas is constantly created and destroyed. The speed with which this occurs determines the amount of ozone in the atmosphere. These speeds can be influenced greatly by chemicals in the atmosphere which act as catalysts speeding them up without themselves being destroyed.

In recent years it has been realised that certain pollutants being released into the atmosphere have the potential to reduce the equilibrium level of ozone. The most dangerous of these ozone depleting compounds, as we have heard so often tonight in this debate, are chlorofluorocarbons or CFCs which are used as propellants in aerosols, in refrigeration techniques, as foam blowing agents in the plastics industry and as solvents in electronics. CFCs are extremely stable and long lived in the lower atmosphere, but when they reach the upper atmosphere they are broken down and release active chlorine which acts as a catalyst in the reaction which naturally breaks down ozone thus reducing the equilibrium level. This reduced level of ozone in the stratosphere allows a greater amount of ultraviolet to the lower atmosphere, which can result in serious changes particularly to our farming community and people who work outside with an increased risk of problems such as skin cancers forming and harm to our aquatic systems and biological organisms.

Ozone affects the earth's heat balance in a number of ways so climate can also be affected by changes in ozone levels. These reductions in the level of stratospheric ozone can have serious consequences for global agricultural production, although much more research is required before any definite conclusions can be reached on this issue or its accompanying issue of the greenhouse effect. Last January, the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research aircraft sampled atmospheric levels of CFCs near Darwin as an ongoing program to measure CFC levels throughout the troposphere. In a companion effort a high flying American plane flew into the stratosphere some 20 kilometres high to take direct readings of ozone levels. The latest results of scientific work suggest that ozone levels will fall by a few per cent during the first half of the next century, although increases in CFC emissions could cause more than a 10 per cent fall in ozone. Measurements of the total amount of ozone in the atmosphere show levels have not changed appreciably as yet, though small changes do seem to be occurring at particular heights. There have, however, been dramatic changes over the Antarctic. Measurements of ozone levels above the South Pole in spring reveal that levels have fallen by 40 per cent since the mid-1970s. These changes occur only during the spring and no-one understands why they are occurring or whether they may be the forerunner to wider changes.

The provisions of this Bill have been the subject of extensive liaison between the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and industries which manufacture, import and use CFCs and halons. The processes that have taken place in the development of this legislation are an example of what can be achieved through a process of consultation, discussion and tolerance. As a result of this liaison between manufacturers, government and departments, a series of action plans have been produced. The provisions of the Bill reflect the recommendations of these plans.

Liaison has also been maintained through an interdepartmental working group on ozone and the industry group, the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers. State governments and consumer and conservation groups have also been consulted. Manufacturers using ozone damaging chemicals are alarmed that lack of coordination between the States may force costly and premature changes to industry, which has already agreed to switch to more environmentally safe alternatives within the next decade. Legislation to control the use of CFCs is now regarded as a matter of urgency by all States, and legislation has either been drafted or is being drafted. There is, however, a legitimate concern among manufacturers of CFCs that unless State legislation is timed to complement this Bill before Parliament this evening industry could well be faced with extra costs to modify products for sale in different States. The result could well be a hotchpotch of legislation with loopholes allowing products to be sold in one State but not in another. It is essential that there is uniformity in all legislation controlling the use and sale of CFCs.

This Bill provides for a system of licences and tradeable quotas for the production, import and export of schedule substances. It controls the applications of schedule substances so as to limit, as far as practicable, the emissions of some substances to the air. Licences will be granted to persons who produced, imported or exported scheduled substances during 1986. Quotas will be granted to the same persons according to their market share in 1986. Once they have their quota they will be free to buy and sell their share of quota on the open market. Total quota on issue will be adjusted according to the provisions of the protocol.

The second category of restrictions gives effect to a determination to take all reasonable steps to exceed the minimum requirements laid down in the protocol. These controls on applications include the prohibition of the manufacture or import of aerosol sprays containing scheduled substances such as those for a limited range of medical, veterinary, defence, industrial safety or public safety purposes. Applications where CFC powered aerosols are the only practicable way to meet legal requirements are also prohibited. The calibration of warning, measuring or scientific equipment will be exempted. There will also be prohibitions from 31 January 1989 of the manufacture or import of do it yourself kits for recharging automotive air-conditioning systems. Also prohibited from 1 July 1989 will be the manufacture or import of disposable containers, five kilograms or less, of scheduled substances for recharging air-conditioners and refrigeration systems.

The point should be made that CFCs are still essential for some uses, particularly for asthmatics and for other pharmaceutical purposes. It is for this reason that the stance of the Australian Democrats in the Senate on this Bill is quite ridiculous. As the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Holding) indicates, Australia has been at the forefront of international action on this issue. We lead the rest of the world by recognising that this is but the beginning. International action is urgently required to minimise ozone depletion and future greenhouse heating. It has taken decades for human activity to produce any effect upon the structure of the atmosphere, so it is imperative that a start be made now to reverse what will be a long term process.

There are many gaps in the knowledge of the earth's climate, of atmospheric changes and the possible effects of those changes. All this makes it imperative for considerable basic research. It is therefore unfortunate that on the very day that this Bill will pass through this House with bipartisan support the only protest meeting in our history by the scientific community is being held in Canberra expressing concern at the disastrous commitment of this Government to science and research. I conclude by thanking the shadow Minister for Science and Energy, my colleague the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), for allowing me to speak in his place tonight because he is at that particular protest meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue being debated tonight can be highlighted by imagining how one can stop a speeding locomotive when it is nearing a station. One imagines that unless the brakes are applied rapidly the engine will juggernaut through the station, smashing lives and smashing the station down. In many ways the way in which our industry has moved over the past 300 years from the days of the Industrial Revolution to the present has been like a locomotive-very productive, fast and efficient and enabling us to lift our standard of living enormously but, on the other hand, moving seemingly inexorably towards a collision with some of the fundamentals of our natural environment. We are now starting to screw back some of the advances that we took as beneficial, as positive and as naturally the way to go to develop our productive capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been only in the last 15 years or so that we have started to realise the threat that faces us if we do not combine internationally to do something about the abuses of our planet. This is a issue crucial to the future of our world. It is not just an Australian issue. The Ozone Protection Bill 1988 responds to an international agreement in which Australia certainly had a leadership role. But the steps that are being taken go only a small way towards being able to respond effectively to the immense problems we face as a nation and as a world.

Perhaps a graphic example of the kinds of stored up problems that we may face can be given by referring to the River Derwent in Tasmania. The other day the media told us about vast slicks of sludge that have been cast up on the foreshore of the river, some five kilometres of matter which has apparently detached itself from the bottom of the river to emerge as foul and fettered reaches of material measuring about a metre deep, with the consistency of a soft tarry substance and a foul smell, and containing wood products that may have been discharged from the upstream paper manufacturer.

I am not seeking to blacken the name of that particular manufacturer. No point would be served by doing that. The simple reality is that until recently we thought we could discharge effluent without cost to future generations. We thought that we could proceed to belch smoke into the atmosphere, produce carbon dioxide in massive amounts, use new chemicals such as chlorofluorocarbons and that our environment was large enough to absorb all that we could throw at it. Unfortunately the evidence that is starting to come shows that that is not the case.

The tragedy is that the advanced nations of this world, those which have massive productive capacities, are starting to go into what is commonly called a post-industrial phase. They may have the capacity to respond, as Australia has done, by phasing out utilisation of some of these products and approaching this issue on a rational and coherent basis. How do we respond to the Third World that has yet to pick itself off the ground and get its standard of living and manufacturing base close to the level that we take for granted in Australia? How do we respond to the people in South America who seek a better living standard but who see the way forward as replicating the methods that we used-that is, tearing down our forests, establishing heavy manufacturing, belching smoke, utilising resources and getting away with it? These people see what we have done, believe that we have been successful, and naturally seek to follow our methods. We have an overwhelming international responsibility now to take not only a didactic role but also a constructive, positive role that will help those whom we will be asking to exercise restraint in the international interest. Their restraint will be at some cost to their development expectations. They will have to face the reality that they may not be able to aspire to the same living standards that we now take for granted. Those are enormous demands to make of impoverished Third World nations, which have yet to attain the income levels and living standards that we aspire to and seek to maintain.

These are fundamental issues whose surface we are only beginning to scratch. I am pleased that this initiative has bipartisan support. It deserves bipartisan support. I suppose `bipartisan' suggests that there are two parties involved. However, on this issue all four parties that are represented in the Parliament support this initiative. It is not something we can simply deal with on a knee-jerk, simplistic basis. The honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) gave a detailed and comprehensive explanation of some of the complex scientific aspects of this issue which we do not know about. It is an issue which inevitably we will have to deal with. It particularly affects my State of Tasmania, which is the State closest to the ozone-depleted Antarctic. I refer to an article published in the Age and written by Graeme O'Neill, which states:

On 11 December last year, a tongue of ozone-depleted air licked across southern Australia, causing Tasmania and southern Victoria to be bathed in levels of ultraviolet radiation normally seen only at the height of summer.

The article suggests that significant health consequences might flow from that occurrence. Significant economic and resource impacts may also flow from it, particularly in regard to the plankton resource of the Antarctic. The real questions are: Can we slam the brakes on in time in this runaway train? Do we have the political will to take steps that will hurt ourselves and our potential living standards, which we expect to rise continually in the future? Have we the capacity to reach into the hearts and minds of those in the Third World, to cooperate with them in programs that will assist them and will mean that they will not move down the path of further environmental degradation in this very environmentally degraded world?

Few challenges could be more important to the future of Australia or of all mankind than the challenge faced by this Parliament of grappling with the problem of environmental discharges of CFCs, carbon dioxide, and industrial effluents. These issues affect all of us. If we approach them simply on the basis of responding to the necessity to appease a public that increasingly is becoming aware of these issues and do not grapple with the realities, the hard issues, then not only will we be buying time at the expense of the future but also future generations will have every reason to be critical of us and to say, as did a generation of Englishmen who condemned those who waited while appeasement was negotiated between the Government of Britain and that of Hitler, that they talked and appeased when action was necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have stated, the purpose of this legislation is to give effect to the obligations which will arise from Australia's ratification of the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. The protection of the ozone layer is one of the most important, if not the most important, environmental priorities in the world today. The international control regime proposed under the Vienna Convention and the Montreal Protocol attempts to freeze the use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and halons at their 1986 level and thereafter to achieve reductions of 20 per cent from 1993 and a further 30 per cent from 1998.

SPEECH.PARA: Why is this so? Down here on earth, among the hairsprays, hamburger containers and air-conditioners, CFCs are exceptionally safe and that is why they are to be found everywhere. They are difficult to replace. They consist of chains or rings of carbon atoms attached to atoms of fluorine and chlorine. They hold together tightly, remaining harmlessly unreactive until they float upwards some 20 kilometres to the stratosphere. There they break down and attack ozone molecules in the ozone layer, which plays a vital role in filtering out the ultraviolet radiation of the sun. What appears to have happened is that a massive hole in the ozone layer has emerged, roughly-at least 12 months ago-the size of continental United States. On the latest readings it may be slightly smaller, nevertheless it is there and it is a matter of the greatest concern. As if that were not bad enough, CFCs also have a less publicised drawback. They could account for 10 per cent or maybe more of the `greenhouse' gases that are gradually overheating the earth.

So it is important that we have regard to the proposals under the Convention and the Protocol. It is to the credit of the Government that these Bills before the House, the Ozone Protection Bill, the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Bill, move at a faster pace than the agreed upon international minimum standards and will achieve a reduction in Australia of 50 per cent in the use of these substances within a five-year period.

The legislation provides for a system of licences and tradeable quotas for the production, import and export of so-called scheduled substances, CFCs and halons, and controls on the application of these substances so as to limit, so far as is practicable, the emission of these substances into the air. My colleague the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) went into some detail about the proposed licence system and the controls on the application of these substances, so I will not do that. However, I will mention that the controls on applications include the prohibition, from 31 December 1989, of the manufacture or import of aerosol sprays containing CFCs, except for some limited essential uses where there is no practical alternative-for example, a limited range of medical, veterinary, defence, industrial safety and public safety purposes. My colleague the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) referred to a particular asthma relief spray for which some members, Democrats, in the other place were not prepared to make an exception in an earlier Bill. Obviously, such exceptions have to be made. In addition to those controls, the Bill goes further than the Protocol by imposing an export ban on such substances from Australia in order to prevent the offloading of stocks on to non-Protocol countries.

So it is clear that this Bill does make a significant approach to this problem. I believe we have a very special interest in the matter because Australia is the nation closest to the Antarctica ozone hole, which appears to be moving northwards. One might also note that the 1987 report of the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Australian Environment Council has asserted that one per cent depletion in the ozone layer could lead to a 4 per cent to 6 per cent increase in non-melanocytic skin cancer. Australia already has the world's highest incidence of skin cancer, so the matter is of very direct relevance to us. It is further of interest that Australia has perhaps the highest per capita level of chlorofluorocarbon consumption, although we contribute only about 2 per cent of the overall CFC discharges into the atmosphere.

I would say that this matter has become one of considerable public disquiet and discussion. I am proud to say that the Liberal Party has been to the fore in all this. Indeed one of the Liberal States, Tasmania, has legislation which is a world leader to date. The Liberal Party, in its 1988 Federal Council, passed a strongly worded resolution calling for the speedy elimination of the use of all CFCs and there have been other significant actions by the State parties. Our own present environment policy states very clearly:

In Government, the Coalition Parties will pursue with industry and the State Governments, a timetable for accelerating the implementation of the Montreal Protocol for the protection of the earth's ozone layer. Australia will also take a leading position, in international forums, in the revision of the Montreal Protocol seeking stricter controls. In addition, through the research work undertaken through Australian efforts in Antarctica, further scientific investigation on the effects of CFCs will be pursued.

At this point I refer to an issue of concern that has been raised by the New South Wales State Government-namely, that section 4 of the Bill, which purports to `save' certain State and Territory laws, may in fact act to strike down State regulations which go further than the Federal ones. Section 109 of the Constitution is relevant there. I understand that in correspondence with New South Wales the Government has rejected this concern and claims that such an inconsistency would not arise. I cannot adjudicate on that matter, but I certainly ask the Minister for an assurance that more stringent State laws will not be invalidated.

In conclusion, this question of the depletion of the ozone layer is a very serious matter of international concern, despite some recent questioning of the data, but in this matter we are not going to wait on the scientists to agree. As was stated in a recent issue of the Economist, there is the good news that alternatives to most ozone damaging chemicals exist already. The bad news is that the ozone layer is not waiting patiently while industries switch to these alternatives and start to economise. The CFCs that are being emitted now will take many years to float up to the ozone layer. Once chlorine atoms have got there, each one can continue to destroy hundreds of thousands of ozone molecules. So if this generation hangs on to its hairsprays, cold drinks, air-conditioners and so on, it may already have lost something much more valuable. So I commend this legislation to the House and join in the bipartisan support it has been receiving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too, support very strongly the purposes of the Ozone Protection Bill 1988 and the accompanying legislation. The purpose of the Bill, as others have said, is to give effect to the obligations which will arise when Australia ratifies the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. It also provides for additional controls beyond those required by the Protocol. I think it is important-and I have to say this in this speech-that the intention of the Protocol is to protect the small amounts of ozone in the upper atmosphere from the depleting effects of certain synthetic chemicals such as the chlorofluorocarbons-the CFCs-and the halons.

SPEECH.PARA: I was intending to speak very generally on this Bill because I have been one who has been very concerned at the pollutants which are being poured into the atmosphere, not only from chlorofluorocarbons but from a whole range of other pollutants from industrial activity, and from domestic consumption. I was very interested to read the recent 1987 report of the Australian Environment Council and National Health and Medical Research Council entitled Environmental Health and Economic Implications of the Use of Chlorofluorocarbons as Aerosol Propellants and Possible Substitutes. I was looking at the summary and their recommendations. I noticed that in 1985 the Australian aerosol industry had achieved voluntarily a 70 per cent reduction in the usage of CFCs 11 and 12 since 1974. They point out that in 1985 the consumption of CFCs 11 and 12 was 33 per cent in aerosol sprays, 45 per cent as refrigerants and 22 per cent in plastic foam production. The production of the CFCs and, therefore, the consumption also, has been static at about 12,000 tonnes in recent years.

Looking again at the problem of the depletion of the stratospheric ozone, it is very clear that the result of CFC emissions into the atmosphere has depleted the stratospheric ozone in a very dramatic way. Although the scientific knowledge of the ozone depletion phenomenon has advanced considerably in recent years, it is still a little incomplete and we need to know more about it. This is, of course, one of these cases where it is absolutely essential that the Government provide research funding to allow such work to continue. I know that the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) agrees with me that it is absolutely essential that money be provided to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and the scientists of the Antarctic Division to enable them to do the work in the Antarctic which will enable us to know much more about what is happening to the ozone layer in our atmosphere, in both the Antarctic and the Arctic.

One of the points that is made in this report is that it is not only the chlorofluorocarbons that are causing problems-they are causing problems in reducing the ozone layer and its protection of all human beings from ultraviolet light-but the increases in carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide are also causing a significant warming of the atmosphere, and of course of the seas too which will develop over the next 50 to 100 years. The chlorofluorocarbons also contribute to that greenhouse effect-about 15 to 20 per cent, based on a growth rate of about 1.5 per cent per year going on indefinitely into the future. So not only are the chlorofluorocarbons causing problems with the ozone layer; they are also causing problems with the warming up of the atmosphere-the greenhouse effect, as it is called-and all the dangers that that entails. I have spoken in this House on that issue previously. There is no doubt that there is strong evidence of a connection between the exposure to ultraviolet-B (UV-B) radiation and the incidence of non-melanoma skin cancer. This becomes particularly important in Australia where so many of our young people like to lie out in the sun absorbing its rays to get a nice tan, but of course they are risking their lives and laying themselves wide open to contracting cancer later in life.

One of the reasons why I want to enter this debate is that the large pharmaceutical company Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd is located in my electorate. Other speakers before me, including the member for Dunkley, have talked about the general problems. I want to talk about the beneficial effects which Glaxo has provided and some of the concerns of that company in relation to the aerosol sprays it produces to help asthma sufferers. Glaxo is the largest manufacturer of metered dose aerosols, having about 80 per cent of the market. It is very important to realise that the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association Inc. (APMA) has argued in conjunction with Glaxo that these aerosols represent a small use of CFCs, about 200 tonnes per annum of the Australian production of 12,000 tonnes. They have also argued that there is most definitely a clear net health benefit for asthma sufferers. The level of diagnosis of asthma in Australia is definitely increasing, and these metered dose aerosols are right in the front line of treatment of asthma sufferers.

The problem is that at present no alternative propellant is available. A lot of research is being undertaken but it is not likely that alternatives will be available in the near future. Of course, this is an inert, non-toxic, chemically stable and non-flammable substance and therefore it is the only available aerosol spray for humans. It is capable of safely delivering controlled amounts of the active drug, and it does this in a reproducible cloud of minute particles which go directly to the target site in the respiratory system. It can be utilised in small, easily portable containers. A long period for toxicity testing and clinical research is required to gain government marketing approval. That takes at least five years, but I suppose realistically it would take seven to nine years to develop alternatives.

One thing I have noticed is that the second reading speech does not make clear that licences can or will be granted to pharmaceutical aerosol manufacturers to enable them to acquire a quota in the market. That is very much of concern. In the short time available to me I would like to raise the uncertain aspects of the Bill. These concerns have been drawn to my attention and I would like to bring them to the notice of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), who is at the table. First, pharmaceutical companies would like clarification-and I suppose I also would like clarification-that they will be able to apply for and be granted licences under clauses 13 and 15 of the Bill. The Bill seems to provide that, but it is unclear in the second reading speech.

Another concern relates to clauses 16 and 18, the provisions that effectively enable the Minister to refuse a licence or the renewal of a licence simply by not taking a decision within 60 days. That is a bit of a problem, because it seems to be a reversal of sound public administrative practice and responsibility. Another problem is to make sure that arrangements be made to ensure access to pharmaceutical grade CFCs, should problems arise in the future, while their medical use is essential. I hope that the Government will take account of some of these problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the second reading stage of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mrs KELLY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) After clause 11, page 5, insert the following new clause:
Recycling of scheduled substances

``11a. (1) In this Act a reference to the manufacture of scheduled substances does not include a reference to a process by which a quantity of scheduled substances is produced by the recycling of substances containing scheduled substances of that quantity.

``(2) For the purposes of this Act, where a process for the manufacture of a quantity of scheduled substances involves, in part, the recycling of substances containing scheduled substances of a lesser quantity, the quantity of scheduled substances manufactured in the process shall be taken to be reduced by the quantity of scheduled substances in the substances recycled in the process.''.
(2) Clause 29, page 14, line 2, omit ``magnitude'', substitute ``size''.
(3) Clause 33, page 16, lines 7 and 8, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:
``(2) The application shall:
(a) be in the prescribed form; and
(b) be given to the Minister.''.
(4) Clause 36, page 17, lines 39 and 40, omit ``, other than the Northern Territory''.
(5) Clause 36, page 18, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:
``(3) In this section, `Territory' does not include the Northern Territory.''.
(6) Clause 63, page 34, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:
``(11) In this section, `State' includes the Northern Territory.''.
(7) After clause 66, page 35, insert the following new clause:
Annual report
``66a. (1) The Minister shall:
(a) as soon as practicable after the end of each financial year, prepare a report on the operation of this Act during that year; and
(b) cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the preparation of the report is completed.

``(2) If this Act does not commence at the beginning of a financial year, this section has effect in relation to the period beginning at the commencement of this Act and ending on the next 30 June as if:
(a) if the period is less than 6 months-the period were included in the next financial year; or
(b) in any other case-the period were a financial year.''.

The Government proposes seven amendments, six of which are technical in nature. The seventh basically follows up an Opposition suggestion to insert a clause calling for an annual report with full reporting to the Parliament.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Kelly) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand the arrangements, it is appropriate that I speak on the third reading and make some general comments on the Ozone Protection Bill 1988. Firstly, I thank the Government for recognising the need for an annual report and for moving the amendment to insert new clause 66a. It is worth noting that the Opposition has considered this legislation carefully over a long period and, as the shadow Minister at the table, the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer), said, we welcome the introduction of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Many learned speeches have been made tonight and the issues have been canvassed throughly, but perhaps there is one point which has not been made and which should be made; that is, if one were sitting out in space looking at this world, the first thing one would notice is that it is particularly small. It is a small, delicate world, as all of us are becoming increasingly aware. There is a great interdependence, regardless of where we live and how we treat our environment. Indeed, an interesting remark was made this week in a tribute to the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) who has been a member in this chamber for 30 years. A famous saying of his is that everything depends on everything else. How true that is with regard to the environment and our world if one is looking at it from afar. The common future of mankind depends on how we treat the global environment.

This Bill is about the global village, for want of a better term, having got together in Montreal and recognised, on the advice of eminent scientists, that there is a problem with a man made substance which was introduced in 1928 and which we now know has been causing environmental damage that affects each and every one of us, regardless of our ideological position or where we live. As we work towards utilising the resources of this world, we want to develop policies of a sustainable development nature. We want to ensure that the substances we use today are not totally destroyed, so denying the opportunity of those yet to come to use those resources. There is a need for sustainable development policies and, as we get new scientific and other information that indicates that things we might be doing may be damaging, it is our folly to ignore that advice. The Montreal Protocol from which this Bill springs is an example of this part of the world taking a more global approach to its environment. The Ozone Protection Bill is designed to give effect to those obligations which arise from our ratification of the Vienna Convention and the Montreal Protocol for the international protection of the ozone layer.

My own experience of this began nearly 12 months ago when I visited a small place in my own State called Cape Grim which is a baseline air monitoring station on the far west coast of Tasmania, the foremost baseline atmospheric monitoring station in this part of the world. The readings they had had of carbon dioxide emissions over some time showed a trend of increase but the measured emissions of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), freons 11 and 12, that deplete the ozone layer, showed a build up from 250 parts per million in 1978 to 425 parts per million in 1987. There has been a whole range of other scientific advisings and data from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as well, over the Antarctic ozone hole which indicated a major problem.

Taken to its logical extreme, the ozone depletion will have major consequences for such things as population increases, food security, energy which of course is the fundamental unit of developed socio life, industry and urban life. Ozone is one of those elements which contribute to the greenhouse gases phenomenon that also runs analogous to what is happening in regard to ozone depleting gases. In regard to the CFCs, the ozone depleting gases, we do not now know how long it takes for an element of CFC to drift up to the atmosphere. This is a gap in our knowledge. We can surmise by mathematical models that it takes some particular time. We know that they last for perhaps 110 years. So massive use of CFCs, although we are now trying in this Bill to dramatically reduce them, may well have bad effects and the majority of this CFC may yet get into the ozone and in the years ahead ozone depletion may well increase. We have heard many examples of what will happen if that occurs. Several honourable members have referred to the environmental health and economic implications of the use of CFCs and I shall quote from the summary of that:

The environmental effects of ozone depletion fall into two main categories. The first includes those effects due to modification of the ozone layer with the resulting increase in ultraviolet radiation reading the earth's surface. Plants and aquatic organisms may suffer genetic damage and experience reduced productivity and anthropogenic materials used in the open, such as polymers, would degrade faster than at present rates. Increased UVB radiation may increase smog formation in cities.

The honourable member for Mayo alluded in his speech to that phenomenon. The second category of effects involves those relating to climate change, and climate affects each and every one of us regardless of where we live. Additional atmospheric warming due to increasing amounts of radioactive trace gases would result in an enhanced greenhouse effect to which CFCs will make a significant contribution of 15 to 20 per cent. Agricultural systems may be affected to the extent that crop and vegetation zones may shift and crop species exhibit varying responses to a specific climatic change.

Forest composition may also be affected in the long term. Changes which promote a warmer climate may also result in rises in sea levels which, according to most recent studies, would have significant effects on population centres located on or near global seaboards. Unless significant control of the emissions of the major greenhouse gases, carbon dioxide, methane and nitrous oxide can be achieved, the climatic changes forecast above may occur even if CFC emissions are eliminated globally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the House proceeded to this matter, the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill which because this is a cognate matter I can now proceed to debate, a reading from the environmental health and economic study shows that there was indeed a dramatic effect and that there was a need to limit chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) emissions and that without doing so we would see detrimental environmental impacts. My basic point was that this Bill represents a quantum leap in global concern about the environment and I believe that in that sense it needs to be welcomed. It is being supported by both sides of the House. This Bill has been put together in consultation with industry over some considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Association of Fluorine Consumers and Manufacturers in particular has been particularly helpful and it acknowledges that this Bill, even though it is perhaps detrimental to its economic needs, fills the need to make changes and, as a result, a 40 per cent decrease in the Australian CFC consumption over the next five years is the estimate. That is particularly important because the Montreal protocol sought only a 20 per cent decrease at about that time. In that sense Australian industry has responded well. Reference has been made to the concerns of the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association about the use of the pharmaceutical inhalation aerosols which utilise CFCs mainly for respiratory diseases such as asthma and the need to continue to allow the use of those CFCs as a form of propellant. I think the Bill takes account of that.

In Tasmania where we have the very first piece of legislation, a Bill called the Chloro- fluorocarbons and Other Ozone Depleting Substances Control Bill, which was introduced by my colleague in Tasmania the Minister for the Environment, Mr Peter Hodgman, gives exemptions for that particular use. Perhaps mention should be made of the Tasmanian experience. Tasmania went out in front. Many people seemed to think Tasmanians do not have a concern about the environment. How wrong can they be. If one lives on an island and has any knowledge at all about greenhouse gases and about the effects of ozone depletion and global warming-the very first people who ought to be concerned are my electors in the seat of Bass. Unless we take what remedial action we can take, we will all be living on top of mountains. We are close to the Antarctic and if the icebergs melt, the water will come in waves and hit Tasmania first. That is probably an unscientific observation on which, if the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) were here, he would take me to task.

I shall make one more point which is a serious matter. A press release was put out by the Earth Atmosphere Project Coordinator of the Friends of the Earth Atmosphere Project which has something to do with the Friends of the Earth group. It makes the point that this Bill does not call for a control, a limit on, and a total ban on the exports of CFCs and it believes that that ought to be the case. I am glad that the Bill does not go that far because it is important to realise that if all CFC manufacturers were closed down it would mean, for example, that Glaxo Australia Pty Ltd which puts together the inhalants for asthma would be required to import CFCs from somewhere else, thus running the risk of having CFC manufacturers set up in Third World countries or other countries that are not party to this particular protocol. I think that is a real danger that we ought to be aware of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that this Bill be now read a second time.
—The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 November, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to finish the point I was making about exports. I think it is important that there is some allowance within the Ozone Protection Bill for exports to take place because we run the risk of seeing factories set up to produce chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, in countries that are not party to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer. That would defeat the very purpose which this Bill and, more broadly, the Montreal Protocol, aim to address. In that sense I would have to disagree quite strongly with the people who put out this press release. I do not think it really addresses the issue and, unfortunately, it indicates a lack of understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: The only other thing I would like say-it is not very often that one would want to be saying this-is that the Government has done the right thing in bringing this Bill before the House. It is unfortunate that debate on the Bill has had to be guillotined and that not as many members who wanted to speak have been able to do so. There is some legitimate concern with regard to clause 4 of the Bill and the role of State legislation. State legislation should try as far as possible to run in parallel with this Bill. We have problems with food regulation in this country because of the diversity of regulations and Acts of Parliament and we do not want to run into the same problem in a new area of regulation. It is a necessary area to have regulation, but where there can be consistency of approach from State and Commonwealth governments I believe that that is particularly important. At the end of the day it makes it far easier and far better to live up to the principles in this Bill, which is admirable in its intent and is one that I gladly support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Company Law-Higher Education: Grey Electorate-Mobile Life Education Centres: Tax Deductions-Helicopter Service Tender: Port of Gladstone

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Kelly) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer briefly to the question of company law in Australia. Honourable members will recall that not so long ago we had a very lengthy debate in relation to this matter in which the Government put forward a proposition to alter the affairs of company law in Australia without reference to its constitutionality and without reference really to the business community of Australia. It was put through the House on the numbers, without consultation. It went to the Senate and a snide deal was done between the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and the Australian Democrats. Part of the deal was that a committee, the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, would be established to look at the unintended consequences of the changes to company law.

SPEECH.PARA: None of this would have occurred if the proposals had been put to the business community before they were presented here. This legislation was brought in, the drum was beaten and there was a great performance. When this legislation came into the House 18 hours of debate revolved around 280 amendments. What has happened? The Government has not even reprinted the Bills. The Government has had the Clerks office writing these amendments into two copies of the Bills. Why? Because it would cost the Government $40,000 to reprint the Bills. What about the $40m that the Government spent on the referendum campaign, which was a total disgrace? That money went down the drain. Company law is more important than the political ideological pursuits of the Australian Labor Party. This is an absolutely outrageous performance.

A small committee has been established to review what has been put forward in terms of company law reform. It is worth reminding the House that the Attorney-General said that there were no significant changes to company law. But there are. If there were not, the Government would not have a committee looking into the unintended consequences of the changes. So that was a deceitful lie to this House relating to company law in this nation. On top of that, this Committee has met once and will receive submissions from around the nation until 5 January. It then has to report to the House on the first sitting day of the next session. On top of that, it has to tour the nation and visit all the capital cities-Hobart, Darwin, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth, where there is no support, as the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) would know, for company law centralisation. It is no good for the Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department to say, as he did the other day, `This is not a takeover. We are not interested in centralisation'. What damn nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is he?

—Mr Rose. I have never heard such arrant nonsense from an official of a department in my life. The Federal Attorney-General's Department will be the greatest beneficiary of the takeover. That is the area from which policy and administration of company law will come.

SPEECH.PARA: Since when has Canberra been the centre of commercial activity in Australia? It never has been, it is not today, and it will not be for a century at least-not in our lifetimes. Yet this Government is requiring a small group of people, within a limited time frame, to look at the unintended consequences of changes in company law. What a fiasco. The Government did not try it with the public. It relied on the Business Council of Australia. The Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Business Council of Australia and the Government-the old big boys associations-were involved, not the business people. No honourable members from Western Australia want to be in it; no honourable members from Queensland want to be in it; no honourable members from South Australia want to be in it. They know that as well as I do, but they go along with it and put their hands up. The Labor Party says, `If you do not vote for it you will get chucked out'. Ask the honourable member for Kalgoorlie about that. Because of that they go on with this sort of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you endorsing Rothwells?
—I am not endorsing Rothwells. Is the honourable member endorsing Rothwells Ltd in his State? Your government got stuck into it.
—It was your lack of control.

—It was not my situation at all. If members of the National Party want to get involved in these things that is their problem, not mine. I make it quite clear that this approach to company law is absolutely wrong. Not one person in the smaller areas-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House a matter of the utmost importance to many families in my electorate of Grey-the opportunity to provide higher education for their children. Degree and course structures available at various colleges of technical and further education throughout my electorate and the one only South Australian Institute of Technology at Whyalla are limited. Many wishing to obtain higher education find it necessary to leave home and move to the closest city-in this case Adelaide. In some cases this requires a journey of up to 800 kilometres or more to access educational institutions.

SPEECH.PARA: The isolation of the child living apart from the family unit and the stress placed on the families is enormous. Many of the children have lived in rural Australia for all of their lives and find the transition from country life to the hustle of the city enough to cope with. However, many also find they have the added stress of wondering whether their hard-working parents are able to continue to support them in their efforts.

Apart from the very reasonable arguments I have placed before the honourable members here gathered on previous occasions, I find another problem facing those who are applying for Austudy-that is, that boarding schools require fees for enrolment purposes before the commencement of the school year, and in some cases midway through the previous school year where there are waiting lists. This means that parents are having to pay up front prior to being assessed as to their eligibility for assistance under Austudy or the isolated children's scheme. These parents are paying large sums of money in advance and find in some instances that they are not eligible to receive assistance. They then have to make the decision to either keep their child at school by further budgeting of the family's resources or, alternatively, remove their child from the school, thereby shattering their dreams.

In summary, the problem is that people in rural and country areas because of their isolation are forced to secure places at boarding schools for their children prior to applying for Austudy. How can they plan ahead on a question mark? Added to this is the uncertainty of income. Will this year be better than the last? Once again there is added stress. One example of this was brought to my attention by a family living in Kyancutta, South Australia, which asked the question: Do you have any idea of the number of Eyre Peninsula farmers who were going to be disadvantaged by the changes to the criteria for the isolated children's scheme and Austudy? The same farmers are currently suffering extreme hardship through drought. This particular family has had three years of below average crops and has seen the farm run at a loss due to bad seasons, lesser prices and loan interest repayments. However in the case of 1987 the family was fortunate enough to have an above average season. Because of this and the changes to the eligibility criteria of Austudy with the removal of the five-year averaging system, the family may lose its allowance as next year's assessment will be based on its 1987-88 tax return alone.

This farming year certainty assisted to keep the farm viable, but did not enable the year's trading to begin without a huge overdraft from previous disastrous years. The family is then faced with the problem of tertiary education for the children and the many problems associated with this. Suitable boarding accommodation must be found; many need to find a way to support themselves. They do not have their families and friends close by for influence and support in coping with the different lifestyle. This is causing, and can only cause in the future, many of our country's young people to give up their hopes for higher education and to apply for unemployment benefits.

I urge the Government to look at this situation that many people in country and rural Australia face and seek to find the solution whereby our young country men and women can be assured the right to obtain higher education if this is their preference. Many in rural and country communities see little future for their children in their home towns and are therefore giving them the encouragement and support necessary to develop careers in some other field, but those same country children are placed at a disadvantage to their city counterparts by having to pull up their roots to live in the city. I do not believe that these people should be disadvantaged by the sole fact that they live in the country when colleges and education institutions are in the city.

I trust that honourable members present today will give both myself and the young people of rural and country Australia the support to have this situation rectified as soon as possible. I urge the Government to correct this situation by calling for applications for Austudy and isolated children's allowance at a much earlier date in the year prior to commencement of study thus enabling processing of assessments to be made well in advance of the school year. This would give rural and country people the opportunity to apply to boarding schools with the knowledge of their eligibility. Finally, I ask the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) to treat this matter with the utmost urgency and change the harsh guidelines affecting country people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address my remarks in this adjournment debate to a private member's Bill which was introduced recently in this House by a member of the Opposition, relating to tax deductability for donations to the mobile life education centres. As honourable members will know, life education centres which have been established by the Reverend Ted Noffs are now spread right across Australia and are recognised not only around Australia but around the world as being one of the most, if not the most, successful forms of drug education that is available today. Certainly in the electorate of Gilmore we have a wide network of life education centres. A couple of years ago we raised several hundred thousand dollars in the electorate of Gilmore to establish three mobile life education centres to ensure that the youth of the electorate were fully versed in the dangers of drugs and the reasons why young people need to avoid them. As a consequence, we now have three mobile life education centres operating throughout the electorate of Gilmore and also in electorates such as Hume, Throsby, Eden-Monaro, Parkes and so forth.

SPEECH.PARA: One important point that has now come to light is that these mobile life education centres cost a lot of money to run each year, and donations that are made to them are not tax deductable. However, it seems ludicrous that these donations are not tax deductable when donations to the permanent centres in places like Sydney are tax deductable. There is an anomaly in our tax laws at present. Representations have been made by members of this House, including the honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), who is in the chamber tonight and who has been instrumental in establishing this debate in the Parliament. They have so far borne no fruit. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been asked twice in recent days questions without notice as to why mobile life education centres cannot be granted tax deductable status for donations made to them. The Treasurer on both occasions could not give an answer to the House. On each occasion all he would say is that he would go back to his office and look up the details. This is most unsatisfactory. There is no doubt that life education centres are one of the most worthwhile organisations that this country has going for it. They are delivering real benefits and positive results in our community today. If ever an institution was worthy of tax deductable status, mobile life education centres would have to be one of those institutions.

I find it particularly abhorrent that the mobile life education centre units cannot get tax deductability when organisations like the Jervis Bay Protection Society, which operates in Shoalhaven in my electorate, can achieve tax deductable status for donations made to it. I believe that there is a rort going on at present. The Jervis Bay Protection Society advertises in its magazine, which comes out monthly, that donations made to the Australian Conservation Foundation which, on request, are then forwarded to the Jervis Bay Protection Society, can achieve tax deductable status.

The Jervis Bay Protection Society is very much against the expansion of the Royal Australian Navy in that region, for various reasons. The other point about the Jervis Bay Protection Society is that it is a politically active group. Its members are peace activists. They are people who, I believe, are very much involved in the political arena. They were involved in the last Federal election campaign. They were involved in the last local government election campaign. By using the Australian Conservation Foundation as a vehicle to transmit donations to the Jervis Bay Protection Society, people can now deliberately donate money to the Jervis Bay Protection Society. That money can be used for political purposes, and it is all tax deductable.

I believe that the Commissioner for Taxation, to whom I have made representations on this matter, has not treated the matter seriously enough and has not looked into it properly. Apart from the failure of the Tax Commissioner and the Government in the matter of mobile life education centres, I think it is ridiculous that organisations like the Jervis Bay Protection Society, which is a political organisation, can get tax deductable status for its donations when life education centres cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some weeks ago in this House I detailed a series of irregularities suffered by Lloyd Helicopters Pty Ltd in my electorate. Lloyd was tendering for a contract to transfer marine pilots at the Port of Gladstone. The quote had to be received by the Department of Harbours and Marine by 5 p.m. on 23 September, 1988. Lloyd arranged for the submission to be hand delivered to the Harbours and Marine officers on the 22nd Floor, 41 George Street, Brisbane, before 5 p.m. on 23 September. The contract was let to another company, even though Lloyd had the lower price. The Department advised that the contract had been let and nothing would be done about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Since raising this matter, I have forwarded the relevant documentation to the newly established Public Accounts Committee in Queensland. However, in the Gladstone Observer of 5 November, a departmental spokesman for the Maritime Services Minister, Mr Neal, said four other companies lodged documents in the proper box but Lloyd left its documents in the wrong box. The spokesman also said that the Department was not bound to award a contract to the lowest or any other tender. I call on the Maritime Services Minister to make public now the tenders on the project. It appears extraordinary to the general public that his own Department, from its statement, does not appear to have any set guidelines on the letting of tenders. Action must be taken to investigate this matter immediately.

I turn now to the statement by the Department's spokesman that Lloyd failed to lodge the tender correctly. I have in my possession a statutory declaration signed by Caroline Louise Kay of 84 Huet Street, Wavell Heights. She states:
At 4.45 p.m. on 23 September 1988, Captain Peter Jones and myself took an envelope addressed to Mr J Leach, Director, Harbours and Marine Department, 41 George Street, Brisbane, 4000.

The Tender Box is located on 22nd floor of this address. I took the envelope to the receptionist in attendance (directly adjacent to the Tender Box) and explained to her I had to deliver the envelope before 5.00 p.m. closing time of the tender. After looking at the envelope she instructed me to place it in the Tender Box which I did.

It appears that the statement from the Lloyd's employee signed under a statutory declaration is at variance with the interpretation placed on it by the Department. It is essential that Mr Neal act to reassure the companies and the general public that the letting of the contract was carried out fairly and honestly. The statutory declaration leaves plenty of doubt on the omission of the Lloyd's contract from the tendering process.

I repeat that this is the second occasion on which the Lloyd group has been overriden on contracts. Nowhere has the Department or the Minister set out to explain the incidents in 1985, when, after the company had successfully tendered for a helicopter service for the ports of Gladstone and Hay Point, the Hay Point section of the contract was cancelled without warning and given to another company. Nowhere has the Department or the Minister publicly explained the fact that the other company was six months late commencing the Hay Point project or that Lloyd was asked by the Department to take over the Gladstone project for two weeks in October. The fundamental question which the Minister must answer is why this contract was awarded to a company which could not meet the commencement dates of its tender. Mr Neal needs to explain this to the public.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 26 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his statement on Australian nuclear safeguards (Hansard, 20 April 1988, page 1856), how can 2 quantities of nuclear materials be deemed to be equivalent.

(2) Under the principle of equivalence, is it possible for a quantity of nuclear material containing waste material to be deemed as equivalent to another quantity of nuclear material containing no waste material providing it contains the same amount of U235 atoms; if so, under what circumstances is this possible.
(3) If the answer to part (2) is no, what other regulations govern the determination of whether 2 amounts of nuclear material are equivalent.
(4) What are the operational reasons which would lead to permission being granted for the exchange of safeguards obligations between one quantity of nuclear material and another.
(5) Will he provide full details of the 17 conditions the Government has set down to ensure Australian uranium is not diverted for use in nuclear weapons; if not, why not.
(6) When did he decide that these 17 conditions were necessary.
(7) What were the reasons which led to the 17 conditions being formulated.

(8) Is he concerned at the statement by the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, Dr H. Blix that it is impossible to know whether Australian uranium is used in nuclear reactors; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The equivalence principle is based on the fact that all atoms or molecules of any substance are indistinguishable from one another and are therefore interchangeable. It is used in accounting for quantities of nuclear material when, for operational reasons associated with any nuclear process, the quantities lose their separate identity. Equivalent quantities of uranium must possess the same amount of the uranium isotope U235. While the equivalence principle is integral to the operation of Australia's safeguards agreements, it cannot be used to replace one quantity of nuclear material by another of lower quality, e.g. enriched uranium could not be replaced by an equivalent quantity of natural or depleted uranium. Any such replacement would require the prior special approval of the Australian Safeguards Office. No such approval has ever been either sought or given.

(2) Nuclear material which is deemed to be waste is material which is practicably irrecoverable for processing into a form in which it is usable for any nuclear activity relevant from the point of view of safeguards. It is therefore not nuclear material and cannot be deemed as equivalent to another quantity of nuclear material. Nuclear material in the form of residues from fuel fabrication in the form of UO2 pellets or excess UO2 powder can be deemed equivalent to the same quantity of nuclear material in another physical form provided that the two quantities are of the same quality.
(3) See (2) above.

(4) Operational reasons include avoidance of the need for the physical transfer of nuclear material; requirements of operators to have nuclear material available in a specific form and the preference of operators to have all nuclear material present in a reactor core subject to a single safeguards control system rather than a number of different and usually overlapping systems.

(5), (6) and (7) The conditions concerning the non-diversion of Australian uranium from peaceful use are embodied in Australia's nuclear safeguards agreements which have been tabled in Parliament and are public documents. The 17 conditions to which the question refers were formulated in 1986 in response to a proposal by Euratom with the objective of ensuring that any future exchange of safeguards obligations on Australian obligated nuclear material through an international flag swap (i.e. an exchange of safeguards obligations between two safeguards treaty jurisdictions) would be consistent with Australia's non-proliferation and safeguards policies. As Australia has not agreed to any international flag swap proposals and as negotiations are still continuing with Euratom it is not appropriate that Australia's conditions for an international flag swap be disclosed at this time.

(8) No. What the Director-General of the IAEA said was that Australian uranium may well be co-processed with safeguarded material from other countries such as Canada and the US. Because of this comingling, continued identification of individual atoms in commercial operations associated with the nuclear fuel cycle is not possible. Dr Blix then said: `In this sense I cannot say to what installation the particular atoms that come from Australia will go. But I can say that the quantity contributed will not add to fissionable material used for weapons production anywhere.' Safeguards obligations are allocated to the product material of processing in strict proportion to the input from respective sources based on equivalence of the U235 atoms. The Agency does not need to know to what installation the particular atoms that come from Australia will go because the total amount of the co-processed material in question, regardless of its origin, remains subject to IAEA safeguards. As Dr Blix stressed, therefore the quantity contributed by Australia could not add to the amount of fissionable material available for weapons production.

It should also be noted that in addition to IAEA safeguards, Australian uranium is subject to the terms of Australia's bilateral safeguards agreements. These require partners to report all movements of Australian obligated nuclear material (AONM).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts and Territories, upon notice, on 1 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When and where has Australia been represented at sessions of the Intergovernmental Committee for Promoting the Return of the Cultural Property to its Countries of Origin or its Restitution in Case of Illicit Appropriation.
(2) Has Australia been able to raise at these sessions such issues as the illicit export of Aboriginal artefacts from Australia and the illicit import of ecclesiastical icons from Cyprus.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Intergovernmental Committee for Promoting the Return of the Cultural Property to its Countries of Origin or its Restitution in Case of Illicit Appropriation was established at the 20th session of the General Conference of UNESCO in 1978 and has met five times, as follows:
Paris
14-18 September 1981
Paris
Istanbul
2-5 April 1985
Athens and Delphi
Paris
An Australian representative attended the first four sessions as an observer.

At the 23rd session of the general conference of UNESCO in October-November 1985 Australia was elected to membership of the twenty member Intergovernmental Committee. In this capacity an Australian delegation attended the 5th session of the Committee in 1987 and at the meeting the delegate from Australia was elected as one of the four Vice Chairmen.

(2) At the fifth session the Australian delegation mentioned the preparation by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs of an inventory of Australian Aboriginal objects already held in overseas collections and discussed progress with the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage legislation, which provides among other things for control of the export of significant Australian cultural heritage material including Aboriginal artefacts.

The Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Act 1986 also protects the cultural heritage of foreign countries by making it an offence to import objects illegally exported from another country and providing for the return of forfeited objects.

At the fourth session the Australian delegation expressed support for the concerns raised by the Cypriot delegation over illicit exports of cultural material from occupied Cyprus. The illicit import into Australia of ecclesiastical icons from Cyprus has been discussed between Cypriot and Australian officials, although it has not been raised as an issue at sessions of the Intergovernmental Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Secretary of the Department was approached by the Melbourne City Council for the services of an officer to assist with its bid for the 1996 Olympic Games. The officer concerned was formerly an officer of the Victorian Department of Youth, Sport and Recreation and was the full-time co-ordinator of the Victorian bid for the 1988 Olympic Games. Given the particular circumstances the Secretary approved the involvement of the officer subject at all times to the needs and convenience of the Department. The officer's involvement, which has now ended, amounted to attending four meetings, which in total did not exceed one day and which included out of hours meetings, at which issues relating to the bid for 1988 were discussed. All travel and other expenses were met by the Melbourne City Council and the officer received no remunerations or other reward from the Council. No other requests have been received. It is not considered that Victoria received any unfair advantage.
