ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Employment, Education and Training: Assistance to Aborigines

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 April 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Minister's Department or instrumentalities within the Minister's control have divisions, sections or units whose primary or major goal is to serve the Aboriginal community; if so, for each en- tity, (a) what is its name, (b) what is its role, (c) when was it established, (d) what was its establishment budget and staff level and (e) what is its current budget and staffing levels.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Yes, within my Department.
(1) (a) Aboriginal Employment and Training Branch.
(b) Responsible for managing specialised employment and training programs and services for Aboriginal people and for developing related labour market policies.
(c) Special measures were developed following the 1967 referendum.

(d) Specialised units were established in 1969 and the Employment Training Scheme for Aboriginals (ETSA) commenced with an allocation of $24,428. With the introduction of the National Employment Strategy for Aboriginals (NESA) by the Fraser Government in 1977, there were around 100 field positions with a program budget of $4.0m.

(e) The current staffing level is 253 ASL of which around 160 are in field positions and the balance is in State and Central Office administration. The budget for the Training for Aboriginals Program in 1987-88 is $70.805m.
(2) (a) Aboriginal Education Branch (AEB).
(b) To develop and administer student assistance schemes and special projects directed towards the special needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.
(c) The Aboriginal Study Assistance Scheme (ABSTUDY) commenced in 1969. Current establishment of AEB grew out of amalgamation of small units dealing with Aboriginal Schemes.

(d) The original establishment of Aboriginal Education Units was within the Central and State Offices of the then Department of Education and Science. Separate figures for staffing and budget were not kept.

(e) Current staffing level is 365 ASL of which 130 are in field positions and the rest are involved in State and Central Office administration. The budget for 1987-88 for ABSTUDY and other forms of Aboriginal education assistance is $81.025m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 23 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been draw to:
(a) 14 June 1988 being the 37th anniversary of the mass deportation of persons from the Baltic States to Siberia.
(b) The forcible suppression of demonstrations in Baltic capitals during the past 12 months and
(c) The likelihood of demonstrations on 14 June 1988 in Tallinn, Riga and Vilnius.
(2) Will he write to General Secretary Gorbachev of the USSR requesting him to permit the Baltic people the basic human right of peaceful assembly to commemorate the anniversary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes
(b) We are aware of demonstrations that occurred in the Baltic States in June, August and November last year. The Government deplores the suppression of such demonstrations.
(c) The Government notes with approval that Soviet authorities allowed this year's demonstrations to go ahead unhindered.

The honourable member may also be interested to learn that the anniversary of the Baltic deportations was commemorated this year by street marches and in press articles. He may also be aware that at the June Party Conference a decision was taken to build a monument in Moscow to the victims of Stalinism.

In recent weeks, important and generally encouraging developments affecting the Baltic people have been set in train, in particular the formulation and unhindered activity of Popular Fronts in Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Along with other honourable Members and Senators, I had the opportunity to discuss these positive developments with representatives of the Baltic Council of Australia at Parliament House on 31 August.

(2) I have consistently made the Government's concerns on human rights issues known to the Soviet authorities, and reiterated these in my discussions with General Secretary Gorbachev and Prime Minister Ryzhkov in Moscow in December last year. In these circumstances I see no current need to write to Mr Gorbachev as suggested. The Government will, however, continue to raise its own concerns on all appropriate occasions. If, as seems likely, Mr Ryzhkov visits Australia in the first part of next year, I shall discuss this, among other issues, with him then.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Prosser Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: Why is it expected that none of the $2.8m appropriated for grants for home acquisition by the Defence Service Homes Corporation will actually be expended in 1987-88, as revealed by the Statement of Savings Expected in Annual Appropriations released by the Department of Finance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In the 1987-88 Budget announcement on 15 September 1987, the Treasurer announced a proposal to make cash grants, instead of loans, available to eligible persons under the Defence Service Homes (DSH) Scheme. It was proposed to make cash grants of $10,000 instead of $25,000 low-interest housing loans to eligible serving and former service personnel. This proposal would have required the DSH Act 1918 to be amended.

The Government undertook to consult widely with the service community. To allow those consultations to proceed with minimal inconvenience to potential applicants, it was decided to offer the option of either the present loan or the new grant arrangements to applicants who lodged their applications before 1 January 1988. The amount of $2.8m was provided for the payment of grants in the 1987-88 Budget.

Following the Government's undertaking to consult, a review group was set up under the chairmanship of prominent businessman Mr John Uhrig AO, including representatives of the RSL, the Australian Defence Forces and relevant Government departments and agencies. Accepting the recommendations of the review group, the Government decided that the grant proposal would not proceed, and that a concessional interest rate loan would continue to be available to eligible applicants. As the cash grant scheme did not proceed, warrants of $2.8m were withdrawn from the DSH Corporation's appropriation.

During the consultation period the Government undertook to pay grants to those applicants who chose to defer settlement of their loan which would otherwise have been payable prior to 1 January 1988. Grants of $742,806 were paid to these applicants by the Department of Veterans' Affairs in the 1987-88 financial year as the DSH Act made no provision for the payment of the grants.

As the DSH Scheme is continuing to operate as usual, loan funds continue to be expended. Repayments from borrowers provide the principal source of DSH funds, supplemented by a small Budget appropriation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 3 June 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What level of passenger movements is used to determine whether the construction of an airport fire station facility at a country airport is necessary.
(2) What are the annual passenger traffic figures for Albury airport.

(3) Is the Minister's Department aware that one third of this traffic is through traffic between Sydney and Melbourne which may be reduced due to a change in airline policy in 1988; if so, why is the Minister's Department continuing with plans to build an airport fire station at Albury at a cost of $1.8m when the local fire station is in close proximity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The criterion for the provision (or withdrawal) of Rescue and Fire Fighting Service (RFFS) at domestic aerodromes is 150,000 persons-on-board (pob) scheduled passenger services per calendar year. The pob statistic includes uplift/discharge passengers and transit passengers as well as aircrew.

(2) The latest pob statistic available for Albury Airport is 314,458 for calendar year 1986. It was on the basis of that figure and the then forecast continued growth in passenger activity at Albury that the decision to proceed with the new fire station was endorsed by the Minister for Aviation in 1987.

(3) Yes. Criteria is still met without the transit traffic. However, a joint review was commenced on 1st May 1988 by officers of the Department and the Albury City Council into the most cost-effective method of providing rescue and fire fighting at Albury. That study group has consulted with the Aviation Industry and the NSW Board of Fire Commissioners.

Changes by Air New South Wales and East West Airlines in their pattern of usage of Albury together with other potential future variations in airline usage stemming from deregulation will be taken into consideration. A final decision to proceed with the construction will therefore not be made until a clearer picture of the long term pob forecasts is known and the joint review team's recommendations have been considered.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the level of cost recovery for the aviation industry categories of (a) international airlines, (b) domestic airlines (c) commuter and supplementary airlines, (d) charter, (e) flying training, (f) agricultural aviation, (g) other aerial work and (h) private aviation (i) since January 1988, (ii) since July 1987 and (iii) in each year since 1983.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery, which was established by the Government in 1983, reviewed the practice of the former Department of Aviation of reporting cost recovery results by industry sector.

The Inquiry Report concluded that the then existing arrangements lacked credibility, and were neither efficient nor equitable. For example, it was not considered practicable to split costs of shared facilities between industry sectors. The Report recommended that the arrangements for allocating attributable costs to industry sectors and reporting cost recovery results on that basis should be terminated.

The Government, in August 1985, announced its adoption of the cost recovery strategy proposed by the Independent Inquiry and accordingly reports on cost recovery results related to industry sectors are not available.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the radioactive substance americium being used in sections of the food and beverage industry in Australia.
(2) Is an import permit required to import americium or equipment containing americium; if not, why not.
(3) If an import permit is required, how many permits have been issued in each year since 1979.

(4) Is it a condition of the import permit that americium is not to be used in the food and beverage industry; if not, (a) why not and (b) will the Minister take immediate action to ensure that further import permits specify that americium is not to be used in the food and beverage industry until the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation's inquiry into ionising radiation has been presented to Parliament and acted upon.
(5) If americium is not to be used in the food and beverage industry, will the Minister take immediate steps to revoke the licences and require the americium to be returned to where it originated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Sealed americium-241 sources are integral components of automatic inspection systems used in the bottling and canning sections of the food industry to monitor the level of contents in containers on high speed filling lines. The instruments are not used in the preparation and processing side of the food industry.
(2) Yes.

(4) No. The level of radiation exposure of food or beverages from sealed sources of americium 241 used in inspection systems is insignificant and poses no public health risk. The level of radiation dose received by each can or bottle is estimated to be less than that received over an hour from naturally occurring cosmic radiation. The irradiation of food for preservation or disinfestation involves absorbed doses of billions of times these quantities.

The use of small radioactive sources for inspection purposes in the food and beverage industry does not result in any processing of the food. National Health and Medical Research Committee Model Food Standards Regulation, S3 Irradiation of Food, is not applicable.
Based on the above, I see no reason to take any further action on this matter.
(5) See answer to (4).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to confirm the accuracy of the claim made by Mr P Manning, Executive Producer of Four Corners, in Time Australia of 27 June 1988, that Four Corners has not had to apologise for a single error of fact in 7 years.
(2) How many complaints about errors of fact as set out in section 82 of the Broadcasting Act have been received by (a) Four Corners and (b) other ABC radio and current affairs programs.
(3) Who adjudicates these complaints and how many apologies or retractions have been made.

(4) Were any complaints about errors of fact dismissed on the grounds of insufficient interest; if so, who defined this concept and did it come into effect at the same time as, or subsequent to, section 82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question, based on information provided by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Four Corners has apologised once in the past seven years for a factual error when, on 18 August 1984, an announcement was made that the credit card Bencharge was owned by BFC Finance Ltd and not the Beneficial Finance Corporation as stated in the previous week's program.

(2) (a) The Corporation receives all the complaints under section 82 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 (ABC Act), and only one complaint was received about a Four Corners program alleging an error of fact.
(b) Since the ABC Act came into effect 16 complaints about errors of fact have been received by the Corporation about the other ABC news and current affairs programs.

(3) Under section 82 (4) of the ABC Act, the Principal Community Affairs Officer is responsible for adjudicating these complaints and ``if he decides that the complaint is justified'', the officer informs the Managing Director who ensures that the Corporation broadcasts or televises, as the case requires, a prompt retraction or apology. Of the seventeen complaints mentioned in item 2 above, eight were found to be justified and nine complaints were not upheld. For the eight justified complaints, four of these complainants received apologies/retractions which were broadcast/televised; one complainant did not want to further pursue the complaint and the three remaining complainants preferred not to have their complaints referred to again publicly and chose to receive a written apology from the Managing Director.

(4) Some complaints about errors of fact were not investigated pursuant to section 82 on the ground that the complainants did not have sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaints. Since the ABC Act came into effect in 1983, section 82 (2) of the Act has always included the concept of ``sufficient interest'':
``The Community Affairs Officer is not required to investigate a complaint if, in his opinion:
(b) The complainant does not have a sufficient interest in the subject matter of the complaint.''
As the concept of ``sufficient interest'' was not defined in the Act, the Principal Community Affairs Officer has defined it to mean:

``a direct and particular interest of the complainant in the subject matter of the complaint. For a complaint to be accepted for investigation, the complainant would need normally to be a participant in the program concerned, or be the subject of the alleged error of fact or invasion of privacy, or be directly affected in some other way. Intellectual, emotional, social and political concerns will not of themselves give the complainant sufficient interest.''
This definition has been published in the brochure ``How to complain to the ABC''.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 22 August 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the cost of the Australian stand at the World Trade Fair in Budapest.
(2) What did the Australian stand entail.
(3) What was its aim and purpose.
(4) How many persons were employed to staff the stand and who were they.
(5) What equipment was available for the purposes of the display.
(6) Did any of this equipment improve the display in any way.
(7) What information was distributed and what Australian products or materials were on display.
(8) When was the display staffed.
(9) Was the Australian Trade Commissioner present at the display; if not, where was he.
(10) Was there any gain for Australia in having the display.
(11) Was there any inquiry that could lead to trade with Australia and therefore justify the cost and effort of holding the display.
(12) Was the assessment of the value of the display made (a) before, (b) during or (c) after the event.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Sharp's question concerns the World Trade Fair in Budapest. Australia has participated on a regular basis since the 1970's in a fair in Hungary titled the Budapest Spring Fair and it is presumed that it is to this Fair that Mr Sharp refers. It should be noted that Budapest is bidding in conjunction with Vienna to co-host the World Trade Fair in 1995. Australia's participation is the responsibility of Austrade with funding for the stand coming from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in conformity with their trade relations objectives in Hungary.
Austrade has the responsibility for the organisation and running of the stand as it has the necessary experience and expertise.

The Budapest Spring Fair is an international industrial trade fair whose primary purpose is to demonstrate to both business and private visitors the ``advanced'' state of industrial and of international trade in and with Hungary. It is this ``Show-case'' role of the fair which makes official and private Western exhibitors especially welcome, their presence being seen as an act of recognition and acceptance of the host country and its trade and industry.

From the viewpoint of Austrade, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and Australian firms who exhibit at such fairs, the fairs serve a unique and irreplaceable role as a place where host country customers, and customers from other countries, as well as government officials can readily be met.
Responses to your specific questions follow:
(1) The cost of holding the Australian stand at this fair can be broken down as follows:
Stand Panels and Equipment AUD...
Space rental costs...
Energy, telephone and Incidental Expenses...
Total AUD...
(2) Australian participation costs of a 50 square metre information stand. The stand has been supplied over the past two years by the British specialist organisation Medinco-Expo.

The exterior is surrounded by a waist high counter, normally manned by a bilingual stand assistant who screens visitors and admits those judged to be of commercial significance. The exterior features a continuous video program displaying Australian products and general information on Australia.
The interior comprises a reception area of 6m x 4m, a small kitchen, Trade Commissioner's office and storeroom.

(3) Specifically, the purpose of Australia's presence at the Budapest Spring Fair is to provide a visible and distinctive Australian presence at the fair, and to provide an attractive environment for Australian business participants to promote their products to Hungarian customers. It also provides an opportunity for Hungarians interested in developing trade with Australia to obtain information and advice and to identify new trade opportunities for Australian exporters. Generally, Australian involvement provides an act of recognition sought by East European trading partners as well as an expression of interest and commitment to the development of trading links and therefore fulfils an important trade relations requirement that is necessary in dealing with Eastern Bloc countries.

(4) One person was specifically employed to act as an assistant at the stand. This person was a professional interpreter of Hungarian nationality. The stand was also manned by two Austrade employees; the Senior Trade Commissioner, Vienna, who has responsibility for Hungary and the Austrade Trade Correspondent in Budapest.

(5) Equipment for display. The stand includes a television set and video cassette recorder on which video cassettes promoting Australia and various commodity and high technology products were continuously operating.
(6) This equipment very much improves the display by providing continuous and eye catching promotion of Australia and its products, serving both the general public and business visitors.

(7) There was no product on display at the stand. The material on display consisted of video footage (submitted by firms) and printed Austrade and company promotional material as well as material on Australia. In addition to the video presentation, a wide variety of Austrade and company promotional material was available to business visitors, and postcards bearing general promotional information on Australia were available to the general public.
(8) The display was staffed throughout the hours the fair was open, i.e. 10 a.m. to 6p.m. daily.
(9) The Australian Senior Trade Commissioner based in Vienna was present throughout the fair.

(10) The Austrade participation fulfilled all of the aims of holding the fair, i.e. promoting Australia generally, promoting specific products, and assisting actual and potential exporters as well as strengthening the trading relationship.

(11) There were several enquiries but two points should be made on the issue of justifying costs by comparing the cost of the display with gains from a particular sale. As Hungary is a centrally planned economy normal commercial considerations do not play as significant a part in import purchases as they do in the West. Accordingly it is important to `show the flag' not only to maintain good will thereby increasing the likelihood of further trading opportunities but also to maintain the current level of trade. Exports to Hungary in 1987-88 were valued at $8.9 million.
(12) A report is written at the conclusion of each fair by the Senior Trade Commissioner, Vienna. The report forms a basis on which to review Australia's participation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 27 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did he write to the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled (ACROD), responding to earlier letters and submissions from ACROD, stating that the Budget provision for the Disability Services Program for 1987-88 was increased over the previous year from $135.2m to $160.9m.
(2) How did this figure of $160.9m become $148.8m as stated on page 157 of Budget Paper No. 1.
(3) How many persons will be affected by the decision of the Government to reduce the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Training Allowance, as announced in the 1988-89 Budget.
(4) How did he derive the figure of 600 persons being affected by this move, as stated in a departmental document distributed amongst industry representatives to supplement the Budget Papers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Minister for Housing and Aged Care wrote to ACROD on 12 August 1988 regarding Budget matters and advised the figures quoted by the honourable member.
(2) The figure of $160.9m included an amount of $10m for expenditure by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service (CRS) program for costs associated with client services.

The 1987-88 Budget provision under the Disability Services Program Appropriation Item, which does not cover rehabilitation services expenditure, was $150.9m. The amount of $148.8m shown in Budget Paper No. 1 was the appropriation item expenditure for the Disability Services Program, following a supplementation for National Wage Case movements and the transfer of $2.5m from the Item for payment to State and Territory housing authorities to assist in housing attendant care applicants.
Rehabilitation services expenditure is now defined separately from Disability Services Program outlays following refinement of the program budgeting structure.
(3) I estimate that, of the persons currently in training courses, 600 will continue into 1989 and will be affected by the decision to reduce the Training Allowance from 1 January 1989.
(4) The figure of 600 was a Departmental estimate of the number of CRS clients who were in training at that time and would continue into 1989.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 28 September 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the National Resources Information Centre (NRIC) be established.
(2) Where will NRIC be located.
(3) How many members will the advisory committee to the centre have.
(4) Who will be the members of the advisory committee and how will they be selected.
(5) How many meetings each year are envisaged for the advisory committee and where will they be conducted.
(6) To what extent will the role of the NRIC duplicate or affect that of the Bureau of Rural Resources and the Bureau of Mineral Resources.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The National Resources Information Centre (NRIC) was established on July 1 1988 as outlined in the May Budget Statement.
(2) It is located in the offices of the Bureau of Rural Resources at John Curtin House, Brisbane Avenue, Barton.

(3) While the numbers have not been finalised, the advisory committee, to be hereafter called the advisory council, will consist of representatives from each state together with relevant Commonwealth Departments and any technical experts required.
(4) State and Commonwealth representatives will be selected by their respective organisations. Technical experts will be selected as relevant at the Minister's discretion.
(5) It is envisaged that the Council will meet twice yearly in Canberra.

(6) NRIC is designed to expand and complement the existing facilities and expertise of the Bureau of Mineral Resources and Bureau of Rural Resources. By increasing access to relevant resource data within Australia, it will improve the information base for the policy and decision making processes of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in natural resource management issues.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 11 October 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: To which positions does Cabinet make appointments.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Cabinet considers for approval Government appointments or re-appointments in the following categories:
positions on major boards, commissions and authorities and to statutory offices other than those established by Territorial Ordinances;
Secretaries of departments and to full-time executive positions at comparable levels in statutory authorities and similar instrumentalities;
other full-time senior executive positions in major statutory authorities, particularly where there are only part-time office holders;

acting appointments within the categories outlined above, where the nominee is being proposed for the first time or where the acting appointment will be of substantial duration (that is, three months or more); and
other appointments, including non-statutory appointments where issues of national or political significance are involved or where a Minister judges it necessary to be considered by Cabinet.
(2) Appointments approved by Cabinet are made either by the Governor-General in Council or a Minister.
(3) Information on procedures for submitting appointments for approval by Cabinet is set out in Chapter Seven of the Cabinet Handbook.
